text: The restaurant is located inside Caesars Palace all the way in the back near Mesa Grill.  We ordered the following: -Lt. Dan; an alcoholic ice tea lemonade perfect for those who like strong herbal tea flavors.  -Snake in the grass;  a classic mojito with lots of mint.  -Pan Seared Scallops with Couscous and Citrus Sauce;  three jumbo size scallops cooked to tender perfection on a bed of couscous with pesto and citrus sauce. The  couscous was delicious and blends very well with the thick pesto sauce; however, there was that additional sweet and sour like sauce  that the boyfriend and I weren't fond of because it didn't add to anything.     -The Porkbutt with whiskey apples and bacon emulsion was the most popular and recommended dish, but had mixed reactions from us. I'll admit the pork was so tender, so moist,  and practically melted in our mouths, but I found the porkbutt and bacon emulsion too salty and overwhelming. If you love salty foods like the boyfriend, then this is a must try dish.  I do love the whiskey apples which added a crunchy texture and pickled flavor to combat the salty and fatty porkbutt.   Overall, it was a good experience and we will definitely come back to try the duck next time.

Having heard such praise about this place from a friend, we opted to take a few out-of-town friends here as their first Phoenix area dining experience. We were not disappointed! Recently opened, Searsucker is sure to become an even more popular restaurant.  *The lounge-like atmosphere gives you a choice of seating in a community table, bar, couch area or regular dining setting. This venue would work well in Manhattan. On busy nights (we went on Saturday), be weary of reservations in the couch area--you can reserve anywhere!   *We were told of a reservation there in advance and instead of rushing, we chose to sit at the community table (just to the right of the DJ), which was at that point empty (@730 pm). The upbeat music complemented the good service and great ambience . By the time we were leaving at 10 pm, the lounge area was so packed that we had to weave our way out.   *As a group of 5, we ate mostly Bites, Ands, Greens and Smalls...you cannot go wrong with the fried brussels(~$6), mushroom and burrata(~$13) and squid(~$8), and of course, nothing gets the evening started like the cheddar puffers. Of course, that is about as much as I remember before Peter Rabbit(~$12) coyly took over. They do valet but I was not driving.  *Peter Rabbit: If you are not sure about what drink you are feeling, then search no further, this must be your choice--Pimm's #1 (based on gin), bruised basil, pressed lemon, and pickled carrot=a delectable mixture of yummy.   Prices seemed fairly standard for Scottsdale restaurants in terms of entrees (aka Ocean, Ranch and Farm)--$15-33, appetizers (Ands, Greens and Smalls)--$6-15, and drinks (specialty cocktails, infusions, wine and beer)--$7-12...but I am oh so curious about the ribeye "tomahawk" with cognac + horseradish=$75....maybe next time, because I would definitely go back!
This place is insanely good. Great food, great bar and awesome atmosphere.   Highly recommended!!

We enjoyed our evening at Searsucker. The decor and service were excellent. Food choices were limited and not for every taste. Both small plates we ordered were very good. I had Ono and did not care for the fish, it was dry and chewy. The topping on fish was very tasty. We were a party of four. Two of us said we would return.

THIS PLACE IS CLOSED.  I made reservations at the beginning of the month through Open Table and had been looking forward to going all week as a date night with the hubs. We received a confirmation email yesterday for our reservations last night, but when we arrived there was a sign on the door saying that Searsucker was closed. I thought it a bit rude that they didn't even call us to let us know. When I looked it up on-line today, I found out that it is closed permanently (and seemingly suddenly). I hope that all of the workers can find new positions; otherwise, what a crappy way to start the new year.  (http://www.azcentral.com/thingstodo/dining/articles/20140108searsucker-scottsdale-closes-closed.html)
The staff was very accomodating. Food was excellent. We had the mussels small plate, Mahi and Scallops entree. They were all great! Great restaurant and great food. Thanks!

I LOVE their brussel sprouts with walnuts. I would go back and just order that as a meal. As my entree, I ordered the flank steak. It was good, but I would probably order and try something else. It was nothing special. They said the pork butt was a popular dish.  5 stars for customer service. Our waiter was amazingly awesome.   I will definitely come back the next time I'm in town.

Our server was quite attentive until we only ordered 3 appetizers, a soda and a beer (for 2). Then he seemed annoyed and virtually disappeared.  The food was great and our "small bites" meal was still $60.

I recently moved to Vegas this year so I blindly started to find my way around this 24 hour city.. it being the Mecca of gourmet restaurants, I've been excited to explore the culinary side of the strip. I play poker at various casinos but Caesars has been my recurring spot lately. I found Searsucker a few weeks ago and being new to yelp, I realized I could express my experience publicly as the appreciation is properly due. This causal fine dining restaurant falls nothing short to to expectation. They combine a sports like atmosphere with the TV's at the bar and an almost California rustic lay out. The pretty blonde bartender was the most funny, entertaining person. I made a few friends at the bar because she interacted with all of us together, it's actually a pretty amazing talent to give multiple people so much comfortability and attention that it breaks down that awkward barrier everyone has these days, especially with technology in the way. Bars are meant for that. To pull someone away from their phone and space bubble is hard to do. She honestly illuminates that bar with her personality and it shows. All the bartenders helped guide me through the menu and I ended up devouring the recommendations. I like the simple fact that their menu has causal bar food as well as upscale selections with a twist. The frenched lollipop wings, bone marrow and brussels sprouts were outstanding. I wish I could have ordered the calamari and shishito peppers but I will have to wait until next time. Overall the dishes and service were memorable. The way Vegas should be.

Place is not worth the price. Way over priced food and drinks. Place has a strange atmosphere and customer service was truly lacking. It takes you forever to get your order in and to get anyones attention. Their menu is difficult to understand and servers are wasting time explaining everything to customers. High end restaurant pricing with casual environment. Save your money and go elsewhere for the money you will drop here.  Very disappointed for the owner to be a winner of Top Chef.  What a let down.  Walk around the corner from this place in the Casino to Bobby Flay's, you will be 100X better off for the same price if not lower.

Fabulous! Excellent service. Excellent food.  Servers really know the menu. Go for the drinks or the food, or (I recommend) both.  Signature drinks are worth your while and then some...but the food...oh my. So good!  The beet salad says it all:  simple, yet fantastic. The goat cheese balls make even the non-salad fan happy.  I have no favorites, it was allllll good.  We had an assortment of "smalls" (appetizers) and entrees and even dessert...each one was superb.  I'm especially a fan of the Squid "Sweet Heat".  Visually intriguing and the taste was appealing!  The bavette "flank" was perfection.

This is one outstanding restaurant!!! Shouldn't be missed by anyone loving interesting and different food. We had a fantastic time with the whole dining experience. Great service from the moment the bar manager saw our drink order and rushed over with enthusiasm to discuss the  possibilities, to dessert. We didn't get beyond the small plates. Between the four of us we ordered 9 different small plates and loved them all, interesting flavor combinations.

The space is very cool, the music way too loud and it is really hard to hear in this restaurant.  I've been to 2 business lunches and one group function and it was the same on all three occasions.  They also have mismatched chairs (on purpose) but some of them are downright uncomfortable.  The 3 salads I had were all pretty bad.  First was a Caesar with grilled shrimp.  The shrimp is all that was worth eating and it was "ok", nothing special.  The lettuce is drenched in "caesar" which is really just a white, flavorless sauce.  There is absolutely NO flavor to this dressing. Bland.  On the next visit I ordered the Cobb Salad.  The menu is very misleading on this one - there is nothing remotely resembling a Cobb salad.  Nothing chopped on it...it comes with exactly one half of a hard boiled egg, a little mediocre bacon and maybe tomatoes if I remember correctly.  I ordered chicken to be added to it.  It comes out as a breast served in large slices (again not chopped/diced).  The worst part is again the dressing.  You've been warned - this is not a Cobb salad.  My dining mate on this occasion asked for a roll to go with his Cobb salad when he saw how small/unappetizing it looked and they brought him a slice of wheat bread (like toast).  Just plain weird.  On the last occasion I was at a group function and we were served the caesar with chicken.  I already knew I hated the dressing and I don't care for their chicken - it is sort of on the "wet" side and it has no flavor either.  And the chef must really not want to chop anymore than he has to...I hate big huge pieces of chicken that I have to cut over the lettuce.  Someone told me that salads are not their thing (the menu would leave you to think otherwise) and to order meatier things there.  Honestly, none of the sandwiches that went by me looked good and I doubt I'll give it a 4th try just for a sandwich.    I'll stick to LGO, Chelsea's, Fox restaurants and a whole lot of other places that serve great lunches!

I brought a group of 37 clients/colleagues to Searsucker on 10/22/13.  Thanks to Kelley, Zack, and their staff, we had a great time!  The space was perfect for our group and both the service and the food were fantastic!

I came here for happy hour with some friends. We tried a bunch of the happy hour appetizers. The spicy shrimp and grits and the mussels with chorizo were my favorites.  The service was great and ambiance is super cute, just the location is very poor.  I would not have found it if I hadn't looked it up. I had the Peter Rabbit and a jalape√±o margarita. Both were really good, but I would have liked the margarita spicier. I will for sure be back for dinner.

Fun atmosphere, kind of like a high end dive bar. Food was invigorating, lots of flavor with ever bite. Fish tacos were great and so was the iced tea lemonade cocktail. The Chef was going around greeting everyone and chatting at tables for all those top chef fans out there.

Hands down one of the best experiences I've ever had from a culinary perspective.  The Service staff was exceptional.  It seemed like every time I was finished with a drink or plate it was immediately picked up and the table was reset.  Server was extremely versed in his craft and made the experience very fun.  He suggested that we just let him lead the way and he essentlally just paired multiple appetizers and two entrees for a table of 4.  Before I go on about the food I must also say I had some of the most unique cocktails I've ever had.  Done very simply but genius at the same time.  Our server once again asked if he could just order for us and we definitely weren't disappointed.  Peter Rabbit was spectacular and he suggest we have the Coyote chase the Rabbit after.  The Coyote was a take on a Bourbon Mule and it was one of the best drinks I've ever had.  I was told it was in house infused Cinnamon Whiskey, Fresh Lime Juice, Gossling Ginger Beer and soda.  Topped with beautiful Cinnamon Stick and Lime.  Oh my God so good.. Ok back to the food.  The appetizers were absolutely spectacular especially the Bacon N' Eggs and Shrimp N' Grits.  Each don't sound great but both we're some of the finest displays of pairing very basic food but taking it to another level you've never tasted.  Brilliant!!  I'm going to end this saga with the best cut of meat I've ever had in my life.  This isn't a B.S. statement.  I will put it up against any Steakhouse in Scottsdale.  I won't name names but I was across the street the week before for steak and this blew it away.  It's called the Tomohawk.  It's a 28oz bone in Ribeye with a Horseradish/Cognac Demi glaze.  This steak was cooked to perfection and had the best flavor I've ever had in a steak.  Over the top good.    I could go on and on about this place.  The vibe, the bar, DJ, ect.. Do yourself a favor and check it out.
While the decor is unique & fun, and the names of the dishes are playful & young, overall it wasn't someplace where I left saying "wow, I want to go back again!!"

Searsucker is good and I'm confident will get better. We went there one week after opening in Scottsdale. It took a server way too long to actually greet us and take our order. However, they were very friendly and accomodating. The menu is so large is why I'm guessing all the food wasn't great.The shrimp appetizer was just ok but the calimari was exceptional. For dinner we had the swordfish which was very good. I look forward to trying this place again and I'm sure it will be improved.

Food was ok, service was awful....server kept leaving the restaurant probably for some extra curricular activities.  We had to flag down the manager to get our check. Save your time and a lot of money and go somewhere else.

Our server was so exceptional. Dez, my wife was not feeling well when we arrived and by the time we left Dez had cheered her up and pampered her so much she was in much better spirits. We will defiantly be back, the food was great as well.

Frustrating with the manager as they told us that this place is full but wasn't even full and force us pay 60 per person   Poor management and will not return.  Brought over 18 customers.  Thanks for providing horrible experience at the end.

I had peter rabbit, tried it cause of the name, was not impressed. Ordered sangaria, waited for more than 30 min, after asked waitress about my drink several time, my friend finally went and got it for me. The meat ball was not impressive, but the presentation was nice. The "Shrimp with Bacon Grit" was a turn off.  I don't mind going there with friends for an outting in the future, but I doubt I will suggest going there to friends.

We recently had dinner at Searsucker at Caesar's Palace. Never having visited any of their locations, I was a little nervous about their over-emphasis on "social dining" -  sorry, I'm not interested in making new friends during dinner - but, honestly, I didn't notice this in action at the restaurant; we had a four-top for the 4 of us and from what I could see, each group dining had their own space. So that was a relief.  I had no expectations going in and was really very, very pleased with everything we order, from the cocktails to the apps and entrees. We eat a lot in Vegas, like most people, and have eaten both at medium and high end restaurants in that city. For us, particular standouts were the eggs + bacon "pork belly", with pork that I swear melted in your mouth, it was so tender, and my loin "filet" (not sure why they love to put words in quotes so much...), with lobster butter + mushroom demi glace.    Even though this is a positive review, I do need to add one negative note. Here's what drove me crazy about Searsucker: They have a bathroom attendant in both the men and women's bathroom. In this modern day and age, there is absolutely no f*&#ing reason to have an individual in a bathroom whose sole purpose is to hand you a paper towel, and to be tipped for doing so. But what makes it worse here is that, at least the men's bathroom, is TINY- there is only ONE vanity sink, hemmed in a very small area and this tuxedo-clad attendant (who, upon my entry, startled me by yelling "Hey, Boss! Welcome to the Men's Room!") and I had to awkwardly jockey for position in front of it, with him adding value to his service by waving his hand in front of the faucet motion sensor to get my tap started. It's completely ridiculous, awkward and uncomfortable and I know several of us at our table were actually painfully putting off trips to the bathroom just to avoid it. So, if you are reading this Searsucker, ditch the ridiculous bathroom attendants!  But otherwise, we were really very pleased with drinks, food and service. Vegas has too many great places to eat for me to promise to make it back here, but I also wouldn't complain if that ended up happening.
Inside Caesar's Palace. Really nice atmosphere. Great wait staff. A good island of casual calm inside the loud hustle and bustle of the casino. Yummy bites too!!

Tried Searsucker for a pre-opening dinner with some friends and was quite impressed.  Every dish we tried was quite enjoyable from various appetizers we got to the main courses to the desserts. The service was good given the circumstances of being a pre opening dinner and I'm sure its on point at this time.   I really liked the decor and it seemed a nice step up from a lot of the other spots in town. There was a "hipness" to it that I just don't see at a lot of the popular spots in this area that I certainly enjoyed.  The bar is quite good and the crafted cocktails are recommended.   We are definitely interested to try it again when we are down in that part of town.
The crab and avocado spread was delicious; skilled bartenders; I personally didn't enjoy the grass-fed strip steak because it was tough on the outside

I was excited to try this restaurant because of the top chef association, but not good. We arrived early and were greeted nicely and offered drinks. The service issues started when I ordered a sangria and it was really sweet. I went to the bar to get some soda water added and literally sat there for 5 minutes while the bartender chatted with two men at the bar. The bar had 4 people total sitting, so it wasn't busy. Literally, the bartender would not turn around. I went over to the other side of the bar, interupted his conversation, and said the drink was really sweet and he helped me out. He did not offer me another drink, but added the water.   We were seated at a really awkward bar table and we were a party of 15 - very strange when a regular table was available. Maybe they were trying to make the bar look full. The chairs were high, had no backs and everyone was uncomfortable. We received appetizers and they were ok, not great. One pet peeve, they brought appetizers and served bread slices and they only included enough bread for one slice per person, when there was a much larger quantity of the cheese and dip to eat. Then they pulled away the appetizers before people were finished. I was not really impressed with any of the food, the entree was dry and uninspired. The desserts were served family style on a big slab of wood, again awkward. Oh and the strangest thing, the bathroom smelled like a sewer, don't know what's wrong there, but not good at a nice restaurant.

I went on a Saturday night and the place was absolutely gangbusters. The bar staff was very helpful and the cocktails were delicious. Unfortunately, that's where the rave review ends.   The three small plates that my girlfriend and I sampled were terrible. The seared scallop came out raw. The crab cake (all meat, no filler- was pretty excited about that) was gross. Maybe the meat wasn't as fresh as it should be? Finally, the mushroom dish was burnt served with "french toast style" soggy bread. It just didn't make sense.   After the sampling of terrible food, the bartender closed us out by asking, "were you ladies abused well enough this evening?" To that, I should've replied "Yes. For the price you are charging and the quality of the food- we certainly do feel abused. Thank you for asking." Maybe they were just too busy and the kitchen couldn't keep up with the crowd? Or maybe, this place has just been so undeservedly overhyped. Either way, I won't be returning.

I've been to the Searsucker in San Diego which is amazing so I had high expectations.  Overall, the Vegas Searsucker was only ok.  I think they are still trying to work out their preparation since it's new.  We started with a Ballerina and the Czar cocktail which was amazing.  We had the farm bird lollipops and they were very flavorful.  The shrimp and bacon grits dish was over sauced and the hot sauce flavor was so strong you couldn't taste the bacon.  The mahi mahi was overcooked and had the consistency of chicken.  The short ribs were excellent as was the strawberry and champagne vinegrette salad.  The warm chocolate chip cookies were absolutely to die for.  They bring a cup of cold milk for dipping.

I was excited to try this location of Seersucker, since the San Diego location is fun!  However, I would have to say my meal was probably in top 5 grossest things I've ever had in a restaurant and I've had Mexican food in London!  If rating on just my main dish, I would have given zero stars, the 2-star rating is because the place itself is nice and our waiter was pleasant.  For the main dish, both my friend and I ordered the quinoa.  I want to say that I love quinoa dishes and order them frequently around town.  I have always loved them which is why I thought the roasted vegetables and quinoa here would be delicious!  IT WAS NOT.  It was gross - basically soggy tasting dirt.  There was a big mound of really wet quinoa, not flavored at all except for the gross dirt taste, a couple sliced sweet potatoes (that were kind-of hard and just tasted plain) and there might have been a couple slivers of kale.  I kept trying to take some more bites, thinking it couldn't be so gross as I thought, but finally I had to give up.  My friend also thought it tasted gross.  I was kind of surprised the waiter didn't say anything when he took our plates, since both were almost completely untouched, he didn't even ask if we liked it.  Not that I expected anything - I obviously made a bad choice, but thought it was weird all the same.  I will not be coming back here.  I think they should be embarrassed to serve such a bad dish.  For the money we spent I really expected something great or at least edible, not soggy dirt.  Gross!

We ate at Searsucker for the first time last weekend and will definitely be back! Our server Tim was very attentive and offered up great suggestions on the menu. The chicken lollipops are very yummy- think chicken wing meets a sausage meatball. Three of us all tried a different seafood plate (scallops, swordfish and mahi) all were great, matched with excellent sauces. And last but not least the dessert was something i would definitely order again- red velvet cake- some of the best. If you are looking to try a great new restaurant in Scottsdale this is a must- its a little hidden in its location but plenty of parking options.
Visited on Jan 3, 2014, I oredered dinner at the bar, great food. There were 2 bartenders The bar as vary slow. The worst service ever, had to flag them down for drininksmand water. Will not repeat.
Duck fat fries were okay. The pork butt was very good. My husband steak and the Mac and cheese were over salted. Waiter was decent but pushing the up sell on everything.

Expected everything in Vegas to be overpriced... but undersized portions with terrible service? Only at this location. We have these back home in San Diego and they're always great. Our server treated us like crap because we were savvy to their happy hour menu. We still ordered off the regular and he treated us with such hostility. We ended up paying another $100 at a different restaurant to get what we wanted

The menu is fun, unique and really intriguing!  It was great to just order a bunch of items with our group to pass and share.  Some thing I was hesitant to order were very good.  Service was good, a little on the slow side, but not annoyingly slow.  Will visit again!

Awesome ambiance! Took them a minute to find our reservation and get the table ready, but not a big deal. Our group of 5 shared several small plates.  Our group's favorite: Bussel sprouts Short rib Squid Mushroom burrata french toast Shrimp ceviche (so good and very different!) Duck fat fries  Skip: Mussels  Dessert: Ermagahd is delicious Smores is ok  Great waiter and very very attentive service. Would definitely recommend to a friend!

Brought my wife out for a Vegas vacation.  We don't gamble so food is an important part of this vacation.  Searsucker exceeded my expectations as a foodie!  We were here to see Absinthe and didn't want a huge meal so we went with the small plates.  We did the Tuna Poke, Duck Fat Fries, Scallop special, and S'mores desert.  Each dish was excellent and easily filled us up.  We will come back once more before we leave

Hello delicious :). Searsucker is a unique dining experience, and it's one that I've really enjoyed. The way that the menu is set up is different in that you will see many of the ingredients in a dish listed, but not necessarily how it is prepared. Some people will probably be irked by this, but I enjoyed it for the places it lets my mind wander. Also, the restaurant itself spouts a "social dining environment" as in they'd rather you speak with your guests or staff, than be on your phone. Or watching TV, which there is none of in the restaurant. So, if you have a question about how the dish is prepared, don't be afraid to ask and become engaged by it! 2 of my favorites are the artichoke appetizer and a fancy cocktail called "the bootknocker". You'll need to ask for Roberto for that one. Cheers and enjoy!

This was our first visit and we will definitely be back.   Everyone was friendly and engaging. Marcos, our server, was attentive, charming, informative and helpful...without being intrusive.   The food was outstanding. The menu is eclectic...and fantastic!  I have never enjoyed Brussels sprouts...and tonight I had seconds.   The scallops were excellent. Others had the filet and the salmon...and everyone rave about it.   Not cheap. Very much worth it.

A new place at Caesars palace right beside the new nightclub Omnia. Its a casual but above average restaurant, with both tables and bar seatings available. If you are by the bar, you can watch sports and ppl passing through the casino for fun.  Quality is also above average and affects pricing which will leave you around $30 for a main. Service is quick and in line with the concept overall, and handles your requests with a smile.  The decor inside gives a cool atmosphere and the open kitchen sets the right ambience for the room. Even though it can be a sports bar, you may not wanna go here if you want to combine a quick bite(read cheap bite) with sports.   I would instead consider this as a new fresh restaurant, where even though you agreed having dinner out, can get away with sneaking in some sports and still leave the place with a ring on your finger.

The restaurant is beautiful, the wait staff terrific, and they pour a good glass of wine.  But the food is disappointing.  I was very hungry for lunch, but couldn't get through my utterly tasteless (though highly recommended) chicken sandwich.  My friend sent back the crab and corn soup (described as a chowder, but more like a bisque), and didn't finish her salad.   Guess I won't try dinner....

Worst experience yet... For a highly acclaimed and talked about restaurant, the place was revolting and an utter disappointment. Now to be fair...the ambiance and atmosphere was very hip, but the hostess and waitstaff were rude and unprofessional. Even simple things like requesting a refill of a glass of water fell on deaf ears. Our particular waiter was a complete moron who could not even remember his own name let alone an order. And the food was over priced and under flavored. In summary, there are far better ways to burn your money...

Started the meal with the calamari, which was one of the best I've ever had. Had the short rib as my main and it was melt in your mouth, cut with a spoon tender, and packed full of flavor. Our waitress was very attentive and gave us excellent service. The cocktails and atmosphere were a bit lacking.

We went to Searsucker for a bachelorette party last night.  We were seated at the comfy couches that I had reserved. Amy, our wonderful server, came and greeted us and began popping open champagne that one of the bride's friend had per-ordered for the group. We had drinks and appetizers flowing. The meatballs, lollipop and brussels sprouts were a hit.  I had a skinny apple-tini that was excellent.  We had brought gifts into the restaurant and the staff was ok with our bride opening them up. Mr. Brian Malarkey himself was in there last night and we got a chance to have him say hello to our group.  I had told him I had been to his location in San Diego and this was how we picked this spot for our party. The drinks were flowing and the food was great, the atmosphere charming, and Amy our server kept up with all 11 of us ladies quite well. I definitely will be back and recommend it to others to try.

Whoohoooo!! I hesitate to give this place 5 stars because it was so easy for me to get a reservation here, I don't want others to know about this gem of a restaurant.  But I shall share with you all my enthusiasm for this place. The food is unpretentious, well, at least by new American cuisine standards. Having recently dined at fellow Top Chef contestant Richard Blais' restaurant (Juniper & Ivy in San Diego) where I found the food to be very fun and creative, but lacking heart and taste/satisfaction, Chef Brian Malarkey's restaurant really knocked it out of the park for me. The food is simple, and instead of getting fancy, they focused on just preparing the food perfectly.   Of note, their duck breast confit was perfectly prepared. Not a single complaint. Even the bed of white beans it sits on top of was delicious, and I haaaaaate beans! Their scallop dish is priced a bit on the high side, but they give you three very decent-sized scallops, and again, it was made perfectly.  You must try their sweet and spicy squid. Even if you're not a fan of squid, this dish totally won me over. I don't know how they prepare it but the squid is not chewy at all. It's got a great texture that reminds me of scallops. Anyway you must try it.   The only disappointing dish was the short rib. Ugh. If I see short rib on one more menu I'm gonna scream, but the waiter recommended it. It was dry, bland, and boring. It even sat on top of a pile of boring mashed potatoes. Avoid this one.   I will definitely be back again!

I always give a place the benefit of the doubt when I read such mixed reviews.  If something is stellar, then it is worth paying for..  This was not stellar.  In fact, it was more miss than hit.  We had 4 appetizers - the habanero & pickle was interesting and I would recommend it.  The squid which was mediocre to poor.  The farm bird lollipops were just ok.  The tuna poke was the one dish that was stellar.  We each had a glass of wine and that came out to $70.  Definitely not worth it with so many other fabulous restaurants in town.

I watched every episode of The Taste and was so excited  to go to Searsucker Scottsdale Beautiful restaurant,staff so nice,Chris was an awesome waiter I had my heart set on the lobster roll,not on the menu anymore The guys wanted a domestic beer,none I think $11 for a glass of wine at lunch a little high Same wine 750 lt at store $15 The hand ground filet burger with pork belly was great I had the drunken chicken sandwich,very disappointing Too big for a lady to eat,dark meat in the sandwich So with the side salad served I basically had a chicken salad The food prices are a steal,liquor prices are over the top Good luck to the Malarky team

We love searsucker.  Everything I've had here is delicious and on our last visit they put us at the kitchen table which was a blast.  The owner, Brian Malarkey, hung out with us and the chef brought over all sorts of food for us to try.   It was an awesome evening.  The atmosphere is fun and our service has always been spot on.  Great cocktails too.  This is a perfect place for girls night out.

Underwhelmed by our dining experience at Searsucker...there are so many better chef-driven restaurants in Scottsdale. Very trendy decor, but the dining experience just does not delivery. Chef Malarkey roamed the dining room promoting the Taste, but he would have better served his restaurant had he spent the evening in the kitchen.  The entire dining experience was rushed -- we were in and out for dinner in little more than and hour.  The eggs and bacon small plate was cold, which was sad because the flavors were promising. The chicken and waffles and franks small plate was also cold.  The filet was underwhelming.  The short rib small plate was redeeming. The duck fat fries were greasy and, again, cold. The brussel sprouts were, well, burnt, (not caramelized) and doused in vinegar.  It is disappointing that a meal that was so rushed, was served cold. The server was also not interested in our comments about dinner, disappointed we opted not to order dessert.  We will choose to dine elsewhere and skip the hype of Searsucker.

Thank you Searsucker for a wonderful evening!  This was our first trip to Searsucker and we LOVED it.  The atmosphere inviting, trendy and fresh.  Great addition to the Scottsdale area.  We were greeted with a group of smiles upon our arrival.  Had some drinks at the bar (the bar stools a little uncomfortable so moved to a nice seat in the deep seating area..) and then continued on to our table for dinner.  Our Brazilian/NewYorker server, Marcos took very good care of us focused on every detail to ensure we had a perfect dining experience.  He recommended just the right pairing of a full bodied Chilean cabernet to go with my filet. Friends had the salmon and scallops and they were divine.  Go and enjoy!  Can't wait to go again!  Well done Brian Malarkey!
What a fun place! Everything from the service to the food was amazing. The overall atmosphere was so lively i will definitely be back to dine on my next trip to vegas!

Went here without know what to expect, ended up with a new favorite spot.  I was a bit hesitant to go here, because Old Homestead is my absolute favorite restaurant and its literally around the corner from Searsucker.  I decided to change things up a bit and try this brand new spot at Caesars.  Started off with the eggs + bacon "pork belly"and it was outstanding, I highly suggest it, as it's quite a difference from your normal appetizer. Me and my mother split the tomahawk with a side of bacon grits, and I have to say this steak was unbelievable.  Was it as good as Homestead's ribeye?  Obviously this stuff is subjective, and I'm biased towards them,  but I'll definitely say it's up there, and a bit better than STK's ribeye.  Honestly one of the top 10 meals I've ever had, and we didn't even do dessert.

My expectations were high after reading about awards it's received.  Over-hyped should be their next.    Liked:  cool & swanky decor - drinks - short rib "cali-belgique"    Where things fell short: * The fried brussel sprouts should be renamed "charred" brussel sprouts.  I was debating between the brussel sprouts & the cauliflower.  My waiter pumped up the brussel sprouts and made them sound like heaven.  Then they came served black & crispy.  :-(  * The scallop diver surf & turf...where's the turf?  For real.  Don't advertise turf and serve flakes of corned beef with a $35 price tag for 3 scallops.  I better be wowed and just wasn't.

Was in Vegas for business and had the pleasure of dining at Searsucker last Saturday night.  We had a 7:00 reservation and although the place was packed when we arrived we were seated right away at a really cozy table at the back of the restaurant.  Our server was really helpful and made some great recommendations.  We started with the warm spinach salad, which was absolutely delicious.  The hubby had the swordfish with a side of Cauliflower and I had the shrimp with a side of corn.  Everything that came out was flavorful and perfectly cooked.  My husband said it was the best fish he's ever had. Only regret is that we totally cleaned our plates and didn't have room to try any of the desserts.  Overall the experience was really great.  Good service without being pretentious, good drinks, and excellent food.  Will definitely come back next time we're in town.

Loved it. Bartender very familiar with a "quirky" but wonderful menu. Had cowboy "caviar" (bull balls), spicy squid and an amazing pork belly & poached egg with hollandaise (talk about gilding the lily!). Best bacon eggs I've ever had. All very delicious. Wondering why the restaurant was so empty the evening I was there. Will recommend and return. If you're a foodie, want something a little different from mainstream boring menus, this is the spot.

Searsucker is for sure the hottest new restaurant in the valley... I had the Peter Rabbit, which i was told is one of their signiture cocktails.. it was amazing... i also had a few smalls.. the egg and bacon.. which it was describe as one of the best thing in this planet... brioche bread, top with pork belly and poach egg on a hollandense sauce.. my server didnt lie.. it was out of this world.. we aslo had the shrimp and grits..  which is server with buttermilk cheddar cheese grits. it was amazing.. Opah with Almonds and cherry and the Filet with the lobster butter are two of the best entrees me and my wife ever had...  to finish our night we had The King Sundae.. wow.... we were speechless.. awosme dessert..,  our server was very knowlodgeable and he guide us from the begging to the end of ojr meal.. best service ever.  we will be coming soon and letting all our friends know how great this place is...

Everything about this place is awesome!  Great vibe from the people and the food is delicious!! Definitely recommend the Bone Marrow to start and end with the Hanger steak. This place is the real deal!

Just got back from dinner, and had the best time there! The mahi I had was so beautifully done, also loved the music and live dj they had, was a little warm for my boyfriend but hey it was busy. Overall this has become my new favorite restaurant in old town Scottsdale.

My absolute favorite restaurant in Vegas!  Great cocktails and food. The mango mai Tai is a treat. Love this place so much we came back the next night!  You can get oysters by the piece, they come with a pomegranate mignonette that pairs so well with the creamy oysters. The biscuits with butter and bourbon infused honey are delish. The steak tartare was creative and tasty. I had the bone marrow the second night and it was amazing!  Perfectly cooked and the sweetness balanced the slight bitterness of the crispy Brussels sprouts. The staff was attentive and knowledgeable - the manager came by the table each night to make sure we were happy with our food. I highly anticipate my next visit to Vegas so we can eat there again!
One of the best Restaurant week experiences I've had the pleasure of experiencing.  Must gets:  Bone Marrow app and Short Rib Main.  The cookie sandwich was also delish!

Was going for shared plates menu. 6 person group with sometimes overlapping tastes. Menu offered nice selection of choices. Had 6 or 7. Ordered large plate of short rib. Prob favorite of group. Not sure why it wasn't busier since felt the food choices, quality and atmosphere and ultimately the location were 4 to 5 ratings in each category. Service was very attentive. If only had short time would recommend as food started arriving within couple of minutes.

Went with the Bestie to this spot and at first had trouble finding the entrance but entered a totally trendy, hip, casual restaurant.  LOVE the look of the dining room. LOVE how the "warehouse" ceilings are very high.  This place just looks so cool inside.  The bar is to the left and had people staged there and there are couches to just hang out with your drink.  The kitchen is open so you can see the cooks back there.  If your looking for an aesthetically eye-pleasing spot- go here. Service was great, our server was knowledgeable on the menu and ingredients, waters kept being refilled, and our table was checked on throughout the meal.  We started with the shrimp and grits app. (very good 5 decent shrimps), I ordered the mahi, and Mal ordered the chicken.  We both ordered a cocktail as well and those were VERY strong! My fish was a pretty large piece and had some horseradish sauce on top (meh- coulda done without it or at least on the side.)  The fish was cooked very well and I enjoyed it.  Mallory's chicken was a huge piece of like a breast, thigh, and mini-wing attached.  It looked so juicy!  She said it was very good and I got to try a piece and it was great.  The sides are a la carte so we chose mashed potatoes, and the cauliflower.  The cauliflower was really good and seasoned with lemon and other spices.  The mashed potatoes was blended so much it was almost soup.  I've had better potatoes. bill was 107.00 for the two of us. The meal was good and the place was very trendy.  If you have a birthday or other special celebration coming up totally go here.

Had Thanksgiving Dinner here yesterday. Our waitress Desiree was amazing. The food was fabulous.  But the reason I did not give them 5 stars is because the food was barely warm and the second on dressing was burnt. They did not offer to adjust anything. I did ask for hot gravy to warm up the dressing and meThey also charged extra for biscuits.  Overall it was a good experience.  Our first time here. Also finding the restaurant in Caesars was a Maze. There are no directions for the restaurant. Good luck if you go.

Went to SS for the first time last weekend. The menu was confusing for a steakhouse guy like myself, but the bartender Monica was outstanding and handled everything from cocktail to appetizer and entree selections. She nailed it! I'll definitely be back and hopefully she'll be there to save the day again. Best restaurant experience I've had in some time.

This restaurant is overrated. The food is not as good as any Mastro's or Fox owned restaurant in my opinion. There are too many items on the menu so there isn't enough attention put on quality, so the food is just sub-par. The service was so-so. The best service we got was from the bus boy, he was hard working and very attentive. It took the waiter 10 minutes to come to our table and take drink orders, and they weren't that busy. The ambience is very nice however, wish the food matched. And the napkin is huge??? Won't be back.

My friends and I had the pleasure of going to the Friends and Family night at Searsucker Scottsdale. The restaurant is very large and open. It was a little cold where we were sitting, but beautifully decorated. They had a DJ spinning some great tunes. The vibe was very hip and upbeat. Here's what we had from the menu:   Cheddar Puffers - Meh Olives, garlic & heat - Yum! No shishito schoos peppers- Skip (no one liked these as they lacked flavor). Brie "triple," grape jam, roasted grapes - Great for sharing. Everyone enjoyed. Shrimp "spicy," bacon grits - A MUST ORDER! EVERYONE LOVED THIS! Mushrooms, burrata, toast - Delicious! Another table favorite. Beat, champagne, walnut & goat - Average salad. Nothing spectacular. Loin Filet with lobster butter & cognac - TABLE FAVORITE! Ribeye with cognac & horseradish - Everyone enjoyed it. (It's priced a little high though) Jalapeno-chorizo - Great side dish for sharing. Lots of flavor.  Fennel, fingerlings & yolk - Great for sharing. The yolk brings an interesting flavor.  We also had this chocolate mousse on top of a brownie with peanut butter ice cream and caramel. It wasn't on the menu, but it was excellent! Overall, I'd come back again, but stick with the small plates to share and bring a jacket!  **Make sure you order a Peter Rabit drink. It sounds a little strange, but it won't dissapoint!"**
Tammy pointed out our order and right off the bat was amazing. Jeasus made us super cozy and the food was to die for. I had the strawberry  salad, shrimp and grits and  crab cake. All me. All good.

Hmmmm - not sure how this place has won awards or was so busy the night we went.   We were greeted promptly and seated right away, always a plus. We were greeted by two different waiters - not a big deal as they were busy. BUT when our waiter came up to the table (and it's really loud so it was hard to hear him) we weren't ready to order drinks yet, and after greeting us he just walked away. Again, it was loud so I'm not sure if he said anything but it didn't look like it.  When he came back, we ordered drinks and asked about appetizers. He recommended the lollipops and was forthcoming with offering suggestions, which again was good.  The lollipops were minced up chicken meat rolled up and fried - extremely strange. They menu made it sound like they were more like skewers or chicken wings, not minced chicken meatballs. And the taste was off too, just a weird app.  Ordered the salad with strawberries - way too much dressing, I couldn't even finish it - should have gotten the dressing on the side :/.  My husband ordered the shrimp and grits that he shared with our friend, but again the taste was just off. He's from South Carolina and loves his shirmp and grits and orders it anytime he can. But he didn't even finish his portion.  I will not be visiting this place again, which was a disappointment because it looked so fun and the menu looked great. Oh well.

So I was in Vegas with the weekend planned...UNTIL SS!!! We went to SS with a group of friends, and my first gripe is the fact that they don't allow outside drinks. Yep, toss that Fat Tuesday out! Its Vegas and for a pretty pricey-not so amazing- restaurant the "no outside drink" rule is obnoxious. Second and even worse, my beau got the FISH and CHIPS and GOT FOOD POISONING as a result! I think his meal was not only around $30-40 but then it made him very very sick. And he got sick to the point where we had to cut the rest of our Vegas plans short because he had to be treated for his food poisoning. And NO, HE DOESNT DRINK SO IT WAS NOT ANY REACTION TO ALCOHOL! Third, I was at a table with about 14 people and several people sent back their food because it was salty! No go with salty and over priced meals! Anyway, BYPASS this Cesars not so royal restaurant! METHINKS NOT EVER AGAIN!!!

Space is nice but very sparse (ie very few patrons here on a Saturday night). Food and service were nice, but not special in any way. Beautiful bathrooms.   The DJ played outdated techno music. Apparently it is not an establishment that allows current dance music or hip hop. In fact, the DJ said Management would never allow him to play Snoop Dog or Warren G.  I freakin love Warren G. It's Searsucker's loss, unfortunately. The sounds of Warren G cross through cultures and generations. Oh well.

I really liked the meal I had here. I started off with the field greens and pear salad which was very good. The goat cheese was smeared across one side of plate then salad placed on side. I had never seen that before and it was sorta good but also made me think, what if they just didn't wash this plate? Lol As main course had the beer braised short ribs with horseradish mashed potatoes. That was delicious, I had been on a no carb diet and eating those potatoes was like eating a rainbow for me. Very tasty. I didn't really get the 3 onion rings on top 1 would have been plenty but didn't think it really went with rest of dish.   For dessert had the milk and cookies which was amazing and couldn't finish them all so got some for breakfast snack.  My server was great.

This place have mediocre food that is grossly over priced. There are much better options around the Vegas strip. The only plus for this restaurant was that there was no wait to get in while other places had 1-2 hour wait. Now i know why.

I just went to searsucker today for brunch and I can't tell you how much I love that place!!! Our awesome waitress Cindy couldn't have been more helpful! The first thing she suggested was the Peter Rabbit cocktail...amazing!!! I purchased the cookbook that had the recipe in it and went straight to the store to pick up the ingredients to make them at home!!! The pork belly egg dish was also so good and the portions are generous. I can't wait to go back! Ask to sit in Cindy's section you will not be dissapointed!

Five stars might be an under statement for Searsucker. The first impression is the design...unique and clever...it is inviting and comfortable all while being hip.  The host staff was just as inviting with warm smiles and a true display of hospitality.  There was a short wait for my table so I decided to enjoy a craft cocktail.  I had the Peter Rabbit .  Anyone that dines at Searsucker MUST drink one...that is if they have the will power to indulge in  only one.  I was seated and served by Lorie.  Great energy and fun.  I ate shrimp & grits as an app and for my entree the pork butt.  All out of this world delicious.  I will be going back soon.  Scottsdale needed this place badly...it is a great departure from all the average chain style dining in the valley.

After hearing about Searsucker in San Diego with Top Chef's Brian Malarkey we couldn't wait to try Searsucker when it opened here in Arizona. We saw a Groupon and decided to try it right away. If you haven't been, it is in an odd location in the edge of the mall. You have to mark at Neman Marcus or pay $5 to valet. In our opinion, if you don't have a parking lot for your restaurant, you shouldn't charge for valet, or at least validate. Also, I must admit the statues of animals out front are not our taste, but that didn't stop us from being opened minded about the food.   That being said, the first thing we tried was the cheese bread they give you before you order. We thought it was overly spicy and not very good. We hoped the tapas would be better.  We decided to go with a few different tapas. We tried: 1. Meatballs - These were the best thing we tried. They are homemade meatballs in a tomato basil sauce. They are very nice, but they only give you 5 small meatballs in an order. 2. Tuna Poke - This wasn't horrible, but it wasn't good. It also wasn't tuna poke. It was more  like a tuna tartare that looked like cat food. It wasn't fishy or anything seriously wrong with it, but there was nothing that stood out about it either. I've had it better at many other places.  3. Duck Fat Fries - These were very heavy and not very good. You could taste the duck fat and it was overwhelming. We've had these at other places and enjoyed them much better. The tomato jam that came with it was sort of pretentious and not very enjoyable. I would have rather had ketchup. 4. Cobb Salad - This was by far the worst thing we ordered. The dressing was some sort of cross between ranch and blue cheese and was super watery. Gross. The bacon came in the biggest pieces I've ever seen and basically took over the whole salad. The avocado wasn't fresh and it just left much to be desired. I could have had a better cobb salad from the Cheesecake Factory.  5. Scallop - The scallop was cooked perfect, but the sauce was too sweet and overwhelmed the taste of the scallop. If you like that sweet asian sauce on your scallops, then this was good, but it was too much for us.   I'd say the food here was very average at best. The reason I didn't not give Searsucker 3 stars instead of 2 is because of the prices. Everything is extremely expensive and for it just being OK, it is just not worth it. We won't be back to give it another try.

This place is amazing!!!! Service is on point, the sangria is delicious!!!!! chops is Phenomenal!!!! We received VIP service and the food is out of this world good!!!! The beef tar tar with the quail egg and the pork belly toast and poached egg were to die for!!!! I will absolutely be back! I loved everything about this place!!!!

Food and service was very good. We ordered several shareables and had plenty of food for four people: Mac & Cheese was excellent and the chicken sliders were some of the best I've had. The biscuits - seriously amazing and not to be missed. I didn't love the duck fat fries, they didn't have as much flavor as I expected.

Wow. That's all I can say. I am a fairly picky eater and my friend was like, just try it. First off the homemade cheese puffs are on point. We had the peppers which were sweet and spicy at the same time. Then the pork butt came out. Name threw me off but was so good. The finale was the chocolate chip cookies. You will never have a better cookie in your life.

If I could give zero stars I would. We made reservations weeks in advance for dinner for a bachelor/bachelorette party for 12 people. Any smart restaurant manager would have that ready and waiting because it is an easy $1000 tab. We got there and waited for 25 minutes and the little snot hostess told us they are cleaning the table for 25 minutes. I asked what is going on that we had a reservation and they are not honoring it, she replied with extreme attitude. I have been several times to the Searsucker in San Diego and loved it so we were excited to celebrate and dine here with our friends. I will never return to eat at this location, as a restaurant manager myself I have never come across such an unprofessional establishment. Shame on you Las Vegas Searsucker.

Now added to the list of restaurants I'll return to in Vegas. I was on business; would consider it pricey otherwise. Knowledgeable professional server made the evening. Biscuits - yum. Peppers also very good. I had the Mexican shrimp with asparagus and was completely satisfied. Cozy atmosphere - a little noise, but not terrible for Vegas. Had a fun vibe with well done food.

This place is amazing! We went back 2 nights in a row! What brought us back was the strawberry jalape√±o margarita (SO good) but we also tried several dishes. All were amazing. Ambience is modern with a fun twist.
Awesome experience. Everything we had was delicious. Our bartender Adrian was extremely friendly and insightful about the menu. I highly recommend the "infused" cocktails and the s'mores dessert.

Food was ok, not blown away, a little over priced for the serving sizes. Service was alright, friendly, but server forgot some of our order, never wrote anything down. There is room for improvement here. The take on the chicken and waffle small plate was the best thing going. That was very good.

From the moment you walk in the door you are aware you are in the 'ultimate of cool' hot spot of the moment.  Four girls in super tight black outfits and 5" heels greet you as they did on opening night.   We were followed in by a fellow with a partially shaved head with spaced 'poodle' balls of hair and no one seemed to notice.   Note: they need a little grammar lesson; the girl asked us "Are you ready to be SAT ? "  Before dinner we had a cocktail at their fabulous bar; our bartender Chris was absolutely The Best!   I inquired about their 'infused' vodkas, and since he could tell we were interested, were told they make them on premises and then told us the entire process, and gave us some tastes.  He took the time to make our drinks meaningful! The very berry vodka martini was delicious!  As usual, the 'cool' element is accompanied by a noise level which had the 3 of us screaming across the table, coupled with sitting near the kitchen.  Those guys were on fire back there, sounding like they just delivered karate chops instead of entrees.    The menu is initially confusing, as all plates just list 2 or 3 of the ingredients, accompanied by a 'plus' sign.  But let me say, the food is absolutely delicious and we loved every bite!   We had Tim as our waiter and he was also The Best!  - patient, friendly, knowledgeable, just a sweetheart!  We had 3 salads and 3 entrees but next time we'll be more adventurous with the small plates.  Swordfish with drunken cherries was a '10' as were the briussel sprouts.    Brian Malarkey is a hard-working genius of cuisine and restaurant concepts.   We have eaten at Burlap, Gabardine, and Herringbone, 3 of his restaurants in San Diego, many times, and it's always an entertaining atmosphere, coupled with good food!

I like the decor and vibe at this restaurant. The cocktails were pretty good. I went with the Skinny Jenny and then had a champagne cocktail.   The hamachi appetizer is excellent. The beef tartar was also good. It could have used more quail egg.   My boyfriend and I split the Tomahawk ribeye. I was so excited for this, but it was lackluster. Especially for an $85 steak. I found it to be tough and too fatty. And to the smart ass (Erik S) who called out that I should get a clue about a ribeye being fatty, I understand that the fat is what makes a ribeye delicious but when half the steak is fat I don't feel like I'm getting my money's worth. I've had plenty of ribeye steaks that are more meaty. My review, my opinion.   My friend had the pork belly entree and said the flavors were good, but it was too rich to eat more than half of it. Pork belly is rich so you have to be in the mood for it.   This place is worth a try, but I'm not running back.

Really wouldn't waste a trip here again. We waited at our table for about 8-10 minutes before even being greeted by our server. Then, when he did come, he just asked if we were ready; didn't ask if we wanted drinks or explain the menu at all.   We ordered the mushrooms and burrata: it was good. The mushrooms were nicely seasoned but that's about it. We then ordered the shrimp and grits; nothing special. The food runner did great explaining the dishes though, so that was a plus. They then dropped off the lollipops (which we didn't order). I stated that we did not order them and the guy said that they were on the house. We weren't sure why. We tried 2 of them and weren't impressed so we just had them take them back. Our server then informed us that whomever dropped them at the table, made a mistake, so they really weren't "on the house" or compliments of anyone; it was just a mistake.   Based on the two starters, we quickly decided not to waste the money on an entree. We ordered the ermagerd sundae and continued to wait for about 20-25 minutes before getting it. Really?! Being a pastry chef, it was obvious that everything in that dish was premade and just needed to be thrown together. The server came over after about 15 minutes to apologize and tell us that the person who makes the desserts also makes the salads and was in the weeds because of a large party. We got it about 10 minutes later. It was ice cream and two baby brownie bites and bananas; there's nothing bad you can really say about it.  The service really killed the experience. For two of us that work at a semi-fine dining restaurant in Chicago, we really expected more, but weren't that surprised. These places turn over thousands of guests, and it was apparent that they had that mentality. We wanted to spend a good penny here and order a bunch off the menu, but it all just started so poorly. Kinda a shame ..
The food was excellent food! Really tasty. Albacora with procciuto and quinoa were my favorits
I received a birthday offer from my work. The small plates were all amazing, the shishito peppers and shrimp scampi were amazing. I suggest this restaurant at my job as a great date night option!

Since we heard this was a restaurant by a celebrity chef, we've been wanting to try it out. We finally had the opportunity this past weekend to go along with family from out of town. We were in a big group and we expected longer wait times to get our food. The service was great but that's about it based on our experience. I ordered the seared tuna, which was recommended by the waiter. Boy was this tuna a big disappointment! It was overcooked and dry. It was like eating a flavorless dry chicken. Other people in the group who ordered the same were overcooked as well. I even tried other seafood dish ordered by other people like the shark, which turned out to be overcooked and salty to no surprise. For the prices of these entrees one would expect a much pleasurable dining experience. But this was not the case at all! To top off the bad experience, the group had to witnessed two cockroaches crawling up and down the surrounding drapes!  I'm not the type that normally write Yelp reviews, but this experience was bad enough for me to vent my frustration.

Everything about this place says Cool. The vibe and decor is rustic yet modern. The long wooden tables make it feel homey yet trendy.  All of the food is fantastic- shishito peppers, biscuits, chicken, steak, shrimp..   Everyone was very happy with what they had!

We went here on a Sunday night and it was very quiet.  Sat in the bar and ordered cocktails until the rest of our party showed up.  Wanted to try a signature cocktail but in the end I opted for a cosmo. My hubs ordered a martini- dry up with olives.  He said there was something sweet to it.  They serve a cheesy bread type thing with the cocktails.  I'm not a big bread eater but tried one and it was ok.  Now on to the food.  I ordered the tongue in cheek which was the beef cheek.  It was very good but a little on the salty side and I like salt.  I also ordered the brussel sprouts which were tasty.  My friend ordered the salmon which she said was good.  There was also an order of  eggplant which I thought was delicious and seasoned just right.  Came in a small cast iron skillet.  Perfect size for a light meal and pipping hot.  I also tried a mushroom dish with toast but I don't recall what it was called.  It was very good.  This place has a cool vibe and the service was very good.  Not the very best meal I have ever had but I would certainly come back here.  It is sort of in a weird spot in the bottom of an office building.

As a southerner, searsucker represents classic southern charm and sophistication. This place was definitely shooting for that theme of country chic I guess you could say. They had decorated with pallet wall accents and some food was served in mason jars. The menu (especially apps) seemed to be twists on traditional southern favorites. We had the beef tartare and it was served in a mason jar with a wooden spoon. It came with crunchy toast and a small bowl of insanely good spicy pickles. The tartare hit the mark for sure. We got the pear and goat cheese salad which was also quite delicious. We ordered cocktails and wine during our meal and the service was definitely on point. We didn't wait for anything and our waitress checked in frequently. For the entree we got the swordfish grilled plain (there is an option for sauce that I skipped) and we got the shortrib. The shortrib was excellent although not the best I have ever had. But I can say the only place that ever beat it was a small farm to table restaurant in our hometown. The swordfish was lacking. Maybe I should have gone with a choice of sauce with it but I am a minimalist when it comes to food choosing to really taste the freshness and the quality of a meat over the accoutrements. It was a little over cooked but the side of Brussels was some of the best I've ever tasted. It came with an assortment of roasted peppers that were very tasty as well. We got the duck fat fries as a side for the shortrib and these are a must!   The atmosphere is a mix of country meets Vegas and it comes off a little weird to me. The theme could have been pushed a little more to really drive it home but I understand this is a Caesars palace restaurant and the type of customer it caters to. I can say that the bathroom attendants were very pushy and overbearing but that has nothing really to do with the food. Overall...this is a great restaurant with some unique twists on dishes. I wouldn't say it's spectacular and we did have better food for the same price (around $200 for two people). But I am definitely not regretful we tried it....the beef tartare, pickles, duck fat fries and service made it worth the experience.
Smart design, talented presentation, and amazing flavor profiles. Not for the chain restaurant goer. A welcomed gastronomical feat in the gate if old town without a plastic scene. Bravo.

My wife and I tried this place last night and it was amazing! There's a tricky first step to get into the restaurant, so watch out for that.   On to the food, I ordered the flank steak and my wife ordered the chicken. The food was absolutely delicious, one of the best meals I've ever eaten in Las Vegas.   Our server did such a great job, took care of us and was on top of everything. Great vibe, food and service.

My recent visit for lunch left me chuckling! I arrived and took a seat at the bar since I was dining solo.  Another couple was at the bar.  A very sweet bartender took my order.  She couldn't answer any questions, though, because it was her first day serving lunch.  Nice job training staff. I ordered wine, a simple salad with lemon vinaigrette, and the chicken meatballs.  Quite a bit of time went by when I overheard the manager apologizing to the couple at the bar because the kitchen fired chicken meatballs for them instead of regular meatballs.  She gave them the dish gratis. Yep, they were my meatballs. The bartender figured it out and admitted to me--no apology or even a word from the manager.  Then my food came out-both the salad and meatballs together.  Could it hurt to train the server to ask if you want both served together? I ate the meatballs first, which is a good thing because they were barely warm.  They were kind of tasty, but had a Costco prefab texture. The salad was inedible due to copious amounts of salt thrown on it.  Bartender finally asked me how everything was, and I told her that the salad was inedible and the chicken meatballs (while I ate them all because I was starving) were barely even warm.  Manager came over immediately, apologized and said they would fix the salad and comp the meatballs.  I told her that I would pay since I ate them, but she insisted. She went on to say that they were probably not that warm because they rushed to get them out and probably didn't cook them long enough. Eeeek!! Did I just eat undercooked chicken? Well, I didn't get sick so I'm guessing my thought that they were "pre-fab Costco" type meatballs is probably correct.  They are possibly pre-made, pre-cooked and just warmed up when ordered.  For $12 for 5 tiny meatballs--unacceptable. The restaurant is attractive inside, but there were a number of workers sitting at community tables doing paperwork--they were obviously not customers. This is a pet peeve of mine.   For the hype, the price, and the parking hassle, I don't think I would bother giving Searsucker another try.  Oh by the way, the second salad came out perfect.  Simple fresh greens, a little radish, and lemon vinaigrette. Hard to understand how they screwed it up the first time.

You have to be kidding me! All the buzz about this place is way over rated!  The best part of the place is the place itself. Cool design, innovative, comfortable (if you overlook the AC running at 65 F).  Short and poor selection of wines, the menu doesn't make sense, the deserts are poor executed, service barely OK and all of this with a way overpriced tag.  Cheese bread at the beginning was good, probably the best executed dish (puzzle face).  I had a glass of a French wine which had one of the most awkward wine tastes I've ever tried, but again, the selection is not that great.  In their web they have a beet salad but I didn't find it in the menu. It seems that they replaced the beets for strawberries. When I asked why, apparently beets are out of season. (Really? I'm not a farmer, but I had beets last weekend in another restaurant, oh well). Salad was barely average.  Then I had the marrow bone. It was OK, I was expecting a little more of a flavor from the onion jam and the bread used was kind of boring for such a dish.  For desert I had the rum and coke. It should be called sweet bread. No taste of rum or coke what so ever. Just a spongy bread super sweet with whipped cream on the side with an unknown flavor and a jelly with a hint of lime.  I also tried the doughnuts with chocolate. The doughnuts (bites) were crunchy (in a bad way) and the chocolate was more in the side of dark than milk, so didn't love them either.  There was a guitar player for all the three tables and 4 people that were at the bar. When he was gone, a DJ started spinning tunes for the whole 7 tables and 3 people at the bar that were there when I left.  It will be hard to make me go back ever.  There're plenty of places where you will do way better for this kind of money.
Pass on this place.  Bad attitude and POOR manners by the hostess.  Loud venue, drafty.  Brunch menu very limited.  I give it one year.

First time at Searsucker and it did not disappoint. Get the classic old fashioned, it is a great drink especially if prepared by Heather, a great bartender.  Get the burger and chipotle ketchup. Only 20 burgers are sold/made daily and it's worth every bite. Great place, great vibe, and great people there.

Dang good. Dannnnnnng good. Went with some buddies. All got different entres and all were top notch. Got beer braised short ribs. Beef was so tender i never picked up my knife. Did I say dang good? Lindsey was super on her game. Knew the menu, made the experience top notch.

Stopped in for a drink and a snack here on a Sunday evening.  I was thinking of going to the steak house, but the menu prices scared me away.  So I sat at the bar and had a drink and biscuits.  The drink - a "Smoked Old Fashioned" was really great.  Just fruity enough, a bit of campfire taste.  I also had a Long Island, which was adequate.  I ordered the appetizer biscuits, and I wasn't disappointed, but I was burned.  Literally - they arrived on a cast iron skillet and I burned my arm reaching over the skillet for my drink.  Didn't notice then, but the next day I had a blister on my arm, and it's still healing two weeks later.  But I contacted them (which wasn't easy, text messages or facebook page eventually found me the "security department" who relayed my message), and I was satisfied with their response; hopefully they will cover the handles in the future.  Because the biscuits were really, really tasty.  The only other strikes were the staff grumbling to each other about how hard it is to find a good job in Vegas, and the lingering stench of 50-some years of cigarettes and sorrow in the carpets outside in the casino I had to walk through to get there.

Great food, excellent service, yummy drinks and a bargain happy hour - what more could you want?   The first time we went we missed happy hour, but went anyway because we were hungry. We had the short ribs (to die for!), mushrooms on toast and drinks. The waiter very sweetly brought us a dessert on the house because of missing happy hour - it was delightful, as thoughtful things always are!  Went back the next night for happy hour, and tried to eat them out of house and home. Duck fat fries were outstanding, more short ribs, cheese puffs, a couple of salads, shrimp and grits - everything was on point and delicious, plus bargain priced. Don't miss it!
I've tried this place twice and food is just ok! I rather spend money across the street at City Hall.  Wierd Menu....drinks are ok.  Not impressed with food and service.

Amazing in every way. We came around 5:15pm and walked into their Happy Hour (5-7p) and fell in love with the place. We ordered the shishito peppers, Bone Marrow, Tomahawk Steak with roasted mushrooms with herbs and the Walnut Brussel Sprouts. Definitely sit at the bar, it starts to get busy around 6p. Amazing food, awesome drinks and SPECTACULAR SERVICE!!!
Searsucker never disappoints. The filet I had was amoung the best I've had. The staff was friendly and the service outstanding.
I had dinner and the food was great. Highly recommend this place if you're in Vegas. it's not outrageously priced and a good atmosphere.

After unwelcoming reception at Old Homestead, we opted to sit at the bar at Searsucker.  Living in San Diego for the last 20 years, am well acquainted with Brian Malarkey's hospitality style and it mates up VERY nicely with the Las Vegas "thang".  The entire joint was jumpin' at 6:45 pm(Happy Hour daily 5:00-7:00 pm) on 1/21/17, Heather was our mixologist/server and we were instantly happy and relaxed.  I picked the "Blueberry Ginger Smash"-Old Forester / ginger / honey / blueberry / mint($8.00)...it was tremendous, packed a punch and had great flavor.  My friend had the Ballast Point beer, can't remember which flavor or how much it cost.  For eats, we had the Sliders($9.00 for two/order two, you'll want it!)-chipotle / cheddar / bacon....like a chipotle aoli topping, the beef was a nice size, two/three bites, juicy and flavorful....very, very nice, will be watching in the future to see if that stays on the menu.  We also got the tuna tacos ($9.00 for three) which were equally dilish!-blackend ahi / avocado/ jalapeno relish.  Deep fried shell, very thin and perfectly seasoned....highly recommended.  A word about Heather.....funny, smart and on her game, she will be sure to go far by reading the signs a customer is giving and paying attention to the small details.  Awesome person and Searsucker is lucky to have her!  Any Yelper in the vicinity of Caesar's should check this joint out and have a great time.  My experience was virtually without any fault, get to it!  Ambiance/Cleanliness-no bs here, it was good to go from the moment we sat down!...5 stars  Service- very nice, no major problems......4 stars  Food-see above for a food review, it was very good, but not in that rarified five star experience....a well deserved....4 stars!

What a bummer. Took some friends back after a fantastic first-time experience at Searsucker and ended up with some major disappointments.   What was still good: Most of the food, ambiance, drinks.  What I learned this time that I didn't know last time: Happy Hour pricing is a gimmick and only available at the bar.  What slipped this time: - The duck fat fries - for lack of a more eloquent way to put it - sucked. It was my FAVORITE dish and I was so eager to order it again. I was the uber hype woman for this dish. Imagine my disappointment and frankly embarrassment when my friends tried it along with me and found it to taste exactly like normal fries. No more savory/umami flavors. I asked the waitress what's up. She said they switched over to fresh not frozen fries recently. I'm not a food chemist so I can't say if that affected the taste of what but it was night and day. I would not order this again. - The buffalo wings are midget (ahem, I mean 'size challenged'). Super duper tiny. - Service. Our waitress was present, but sometimes we had to wait awhile for her to come around, otherwise we didn't see her at all. May not be her fault in a busy part of the restaurant. She was also brusque and a little sarcastic, which I didn't anticipate given the warm service we received the first time by someone else. - Website says you can get complimentary entry to Omnia. We asked about it on the way out. Turns out you need to buy a certain amount of food for each complimentary entrance, which is reasonable. What bemused me was that it took them about 10 minutes to sign off this perk for us. Required a manager's approval so we had to wait.  Don't know what happened this time, but the allure definitely faded. If this was my first experience at Searsucker, I would not have returned.

Awesome! Tried Searsucker last night for the first time. Can't wait to go back!! Try the Peter Rabbit, even if you think you don't like Gin. It's terrific! The shishito peppers are terrific, too! The 63 degree egg was absolutely scrumptious- the best breakfast ever!! We really enjoyed the rest of the meal, as well. Everything was done perfectly and the service was top notch. Thanks, Tim!
Pretty good place on the strip. Drinks are awesome and happy hour specials are perfect. Give it a try if you're nearby.
3 things to recommend off the menu: the bone marrow, scallops, and the rocky road bread pudding

I had one of the best meals of my life at Searsucker on this trip to Vegas. The atmosphere is amazing, the servers were awesome, and amazing at accommodating my gluten allergy! Can't recommend this place highly enough. Holy wow the meal was seriously so good - if/when i go back, I don't even know what I'll order because everything was so amazing!! Our favorite dishes of the night:   Drinks: - Strawberry Jalapeno (if you like spicy margaritas, get this!!) - Fizzy Lifter  Dinner: - Short rib with horseradish potatoes - Roasted cauliflower with pickled chilis, pine nuts, citrus - Heirloom roasted carrots with thai pesto and crushed peanuts - Scallops over kabocha squash puree, caramelized mushrooms, butternut squash and bacon bits - 36 - Salmon with white bean ragout and herbs - 29  Also. For dessert, we had the daily scoop - mango sorbet and salted caramel ice cream (or gelato)? AMAZING.

Wow, where to begin...  I was lucky enough to go to Searsucker with a large party of people. I say "lucky" because this allowed me to try a lot of different menu items.   First things first, though the seating and the vibe are perfect for large parties, the restaurant is extremely loud. Also, we were seated at a long, rectangular table, so in order to speak to someone across the way, you either had to shout or temporarily move seats. This made for a difficult dining experience conversation-wise.  However, I have relatively no complaints about the food. Though I would like to mention that I was tricked into eating a Rocky Mountain Oyster (bleh, yuck). For all of you sweet, innocent souls out there (like myself) that have no idea what Rocky Mountain Oysters are, please read the following statement; they are testicles. That's right. If the idea of eating such a thing makes you squeamish, then do not order the Cowboy Caviar. I honestly cannot attest to the taste, as my opinion is now completely jaded by the fact that I had never, ever wanted to eat bull testicles in my life. Ever.   Moving on; I personally ordered the Duck Fat Fries with Chipotle Ketchup. This was, of course, delicious because...well, because it's fries all done up fancy and such. I also enjoyed the smoky ketchup, and I'm not necessarily a fan of chipotle in the first place. Along with the fries, I ordered the Tomato Soup with Toast and Cheese (AKA, grilled cheese). Yum, yum, yum was it good. The soup is drizzled with some sort of pesto sauce on top. The grilled cheese is greasy, melty, and super-cheesy in all of the ways that matter. Finally, I also ordered the "Spicy" Shrimp Bacon Grits. And I died...from deliciousness. Wow. For all of you that are wary of spicy foods, I would say the spiciness level is "medium". It's slightly hotter than mild, but not too hot. In the picture I've supplied, it looks very different from how you'd expect grits to look but rest assured, they're there - under all that shrimp and sauce and delicious flavor.
