As a party, we also ordered the Hamachi Tostadas, the Artichoke Hearts with Cheddar and Mozzarella, the Brussels Sprouts and the Scallops (entree). Of all of those, I particularly enjoyed the artichoke dip the best. It comes with cheesy toast, as you can see in the picture.   All in all, eating at Searsucker was quite the experience. I only wish I had heard about it when I was still living in San Diego, as they also have a location there. Hopefully Reno will get one eventually as well! It's definitely a must-try.  Happy feasting!

Was here with a group of 8 people in which we decided to do family style dining and order several different things and just share. I'm sad to say the best thing I had that night was their Duck Fat Fries and the Cheddar Puffers. The item I was most looking forward to was the Tomahawk Ribeye but it was over-salted, which seemed to be a theme for them that night. I also tried the Duck which was nothing special and the Mahi which was tough and flavorless.   Honestly the only reason they got two stars was that their cocktails were very well done and the half priced bottles of wine for locals.   Overall I'm not in any hurry to return or recommend this place to anyone.

I've been to Searsucker twice now and I am very, very impressed.  My first visit was during one of their friends and family nights, where much to my delight everything was "on the house". My girl friend and I enjoyed a glass of white wine and one of their signature Peter Rabbit cocktails. I wasn't a huge fan of the Peter Rabbit, but to be honest I don't usually have mixed cocktails like that with dinner. Admittedly it was a little too "advanced" for my palette ;) The bartender who took care of us was very friendly and knowledgeable, and perhaps most important - not offended that I didn't care for the drink.  As far as nibbles, we sampled the "no shishito" peppers, spicy pickles, bone marrow, and eggs & bacon pork belly. I had never eaten bone marrow before and while I was intimidated a little bit, I thought it was tasty. The eggs & bacon pork belly, however, hit it out of the park. Delicious, melt in your mouth!   For our entree we shared the diver scallops. If you have read any of my other reviews, you know I am a sucker for scallops, and these were exceptional. It escapes me now what they were accompanied with, but it doesn't matter because they were so scrumptious. Just do yourself a favor and order them.  My second visit to Searsucker was on a Sunday for brunch. I was shocked to find a less than half empty restaurant, what with it being a lovely sunny day and a DJ playing fun music. Anyway, I opted for the $15 bottomless mimosa deal, while my friends sipped on some fancy-pants bloody mary's. For food I selected the "green eggs and ham" which was their infamous pork belly on brioche toast, eggs, and herb infused saucy deliciousness. Needless to say I practically licked my plate.  Service, atmosphere, and food are all excellent! A+ :)

My first time at this place was amazing. Service was awesome. I was so excited to come back to Vegas to eat at Searsucker. It was such a disappointment. We went during happy hour on Wednesday. We sat and waited for a server. We ended up going to the bar for menus where the bartender said our server would be with us shortly. After waiting 15 minutes we ended up ordering at the bar. The place wasn't busy. In fact, I saw a couple employees standing at the bar. When our food came out it was delivered by someone who worked in the kitchen, we had to ask him for silverware and plates. Nobody ever checked in on us and we ended up going to the bar again to ask for our check. This place was one of my favorite stops when I visited and has become the only bad experience on my vacation. :(

We ate dinner at 8PM on May, 23, 2013. I really had high hopes for this high end happening restaurant. I made reservation for a table of 5 and told the reservationist that we had another party of 5 under my friend's name. We were part of a meetup group that loves food and came together for AZ Restaurant week to eat and socialize.I don't know why but the reservation person at Searsucker called my friend over the phone and pressured her to agree to making our 2 separate reservation into 1.Meaning our party of 8 would be seated at a long table. When I arrived, I was shock to find out we were seated all together at one long table. By this point, everyone had already gotten comfortable so we decided to stay put enduring the tight space even though the restaurant was half empty!!!!  There's more!! I was not given a napkin nor a glass of water till I ask 2 times for it.  I ate my appetizer, entr√©e, and half of my dessert before I got the napkin I asked for.  Our party waited at least 30 minutes, before anyone came to get our order.  The air conditioning was not working well that day and so we were sitting there sweating.  I notice, the table next to us was also fanning themselves with the menu. If you are reading this Searsucker, please write me back at xxxxxxxx  and I will make sure to contact you right away. Thank you for reading this review.

My boss recommended this place to me because he had heard great reviews from the one in SD. Decided to have my birthday dinner here and overall the food was remarkable. The mussels with chorizo were amazing, the chorizo bits were so tasty gave the whole dish an amazing taste. The squid sweet heat was probably the best squid I have had and this tends to be a dish I order at every restaurant and is by far the best tasting here at Searsucker. All of the appetizers came in large sizes. We also got the duck fat fries with chipotle ketchup towards the end, and OMG, loved them! I'm not a duck fan but you really couldn't taste duck. I got the mahi baja dish the meat was so tender and those almonds and drunken cherries just blended in very well in every bite. My boyfriend got the hanger butcher steak and he thought it was okay. The only disappointing thing and the reason why I didn't give five stars is because the entree is literally just the piece of meat, the dishes don't come with anything else like a side. Good thing we had ordered the duck fat fries along with the entrees. Their cocktail ballerina and the czar was good. To end the dinner our awesome waitress recommended the s'mores bar for dessert, so glad she did! Not one crumb was left of that. Oh, not to mention the service was great our waiter was so friendly and kept checking up on us to make sure our experience was going great, she even started a conversation with us and mentioned how she loved locals coming into Searsucker.

Super friendly staff (super attentive) food was on point. I've never felt more welcomed at a restaurant before. I would highly recommend the strawberry jalape√±o margaritas so D'lish!!! Definitely coming back with all my friends and family again .

Let me start by saying we should have known things would not be outstanding based on the crowd. It was completely dead!!!!! We stopped in for quick appetizers and drinks before omnia. Drinks were delicious and decently priced. Food, not so good! Jars on the menu is quite literal... The food comes in s jar. We ordered about 6 appetizers for 5 girls and that was enough. I absolutely loved the crab and avocado but that's about it. Beef tartare came up short, as did the tuna tartare and honestly the rest of the food was so mediocre I can't even remember what else we ordered. The scene is cute and it's a great location but not really up to par with the competition.

Walk. Don't walk. That's the sign at the entrance. Much like a pedestrian crossing light. This place must be fun! The hostesses were welcoming and promptly offered an invite into the restaurant. Once my friend arrived we were shown inside by the lovely Stephanie who showed us the bar and the kitchen area, as well as our "people watching seats". It's nice to see the kitchen operation in action. Everything the chefs were working on looked fresh.  Desiree was our server. She came to us right away to welcome us and brought the Happy Hour menus. We had about 15 minutes before their Happy Hour was over so we promptly ordered four cocktails and 2 appetizers. The cocktails were crafty and delicious. The fuck dat fries, sorry the Duck Fat Fries with chipotle ketchup had just the right combination of flavors, they were pulpy, fresh and crispy, not too spicy (thank goodness for me!). I couldn't taste the duck but they were delish nonetheless . The short rib "the harlot" though was soooo freaking good! It was tender and juicy and the mashed potatoes and the crispy onions OMG I could eat like 3 or 4 or 5 of those orders! Yumm! We followed with the strawberry walnut goat cheese salad, Wow great combination of textures, with fruit and crunchiness and fresh greens. Then the Tuna albacore wrapped in prosciutto, sherry alioli and balsamic balls (gooey balls, yumm!) with a delicious Fris√©e salad, barely seared but definitely rear tuna (sashimi grade for sure!) was sooooooo good! The tuna just melts in your mouth! By then I was starting to feel full but I couldn't stop eating it. Unfortunately we had no room for dessert but the chocolate chip cookies looked finger licking good. Desiree was super friendly and informative and kept us entertained in between dishes. She made some excellent recommendations. You could tell she enjoys talking about the different menu items and how much she loved trying them all during pre-opening. If you are lucky enough to get Desiree during your visit, you will be a pampered guest! Her assistant Ahi (Aji?) (I called him Ajilipollas) was friendly and always kept our water glasses topped. I can't wait to visit Searsucker again so I can try the other items I wish I could've eaten today. I'm no terminator but "I'll be back!".

Hubby and I shared the pork belly and the short rib small plates. I Loved the Pork belly. We also ordered 2 desserts. The alexis michelle terrine and the ranndy jackson presents: "the sundae". Both were really good but OMG the sundae was so delicious the bacon caramel popcorn was a unique idea and was such a great addition to the dish.

I had high hopes Searsucker but left disappointed. The atmosphere was industrial blended with chic touches.  The serves was average to poor, we saw our waitress three times over two hour span and one of those was to drop the check. Plus, I did not have the opportunity to get a second drink let alone a refill on water.   We ordered several small plates, Cobb salad, and the Randy Jackson dessert. Of the small plates we ordered, Brussels sprouts, chorizo corn, peppers, duck fries, and chicken and waffles. The Brussels stouts and the Randy Jackson was the best but nothing I would go back for.  Out of all of the small plates, I was mostly disappointed by the duck fries. The fries were bland and almost undercooked. The chicken and waffles was fair but for $14.00 I expected a larger portion or more flavor.   I hope you have a better experience than my party for almost $100.00 :(

Check it out between 5pm - 7pm for happy hour, they have some great deals and the food was fabulous. I would recommend their duck fat french fries and hummus. The bread that they serve with the hummus was fantastic, it was warmed and oiled lightly. The hummus had roasted chickpeas mixed in, grilled lemon, and was spot on. The potions were good sized and we ended up having enough that we didn't need any dinner later. The cocktails can get very pricy here (15++) but again they had some great craft cocktails for $9 during happy hour so split some appetizers and take advantage of the deals. Love this place!

Food here was really good, but super pricy. I really liked the tuna tare tar the best. It was so flavorful and tasted perfect with the crispy potato chips. We got free pickles with a check in with yelp. It was good, but super salty, so you have to eat it was other things in your meal the balance out the saltiness. The portions were small, so we had to order a lot of food and it was so pricy.  I felt like our server was awkward and forcing us to order things off the menu that we didn't really want. I probably would try other places when I am in Vegas again.
Braised short rib, eggs & bacon, calamari, quinoa, and other things. I ate a month ago so I forgot. I just remember the food was legit. The service was impeccable.

Wow, what did I miss that the other reviewers found so exciting about Searsucker?  Though I've never been to Searsucker in San Diego, I only assumed that the San Diego location must be well established in order to open a Scottsdale location and a  transition into Scottsdale would not be hindered with "working out the kinks".  The restaurant is cold - not in style but in air conditioning.  It seems that the temperature cannot be regulated and it's either on or off.  The food was okay, enjoyable but nothing special.  My friends ordered flatiron steak and really enjoyed them.  I had a short rib that was pretty good, though it was served lukewarm.  Another friend ordered tartare, which she returned due to excessive salt.   Service was slow despite being a Sunday night with a smaller dining crowd.  Overall we were disappointed by the slow service, cold temperature of the restaurant and the expense of the food - very expensive for service and quality of food.  We all thought the red velvet cake was completely tasteless and the chocolate mousse on a brownie nothing more than pudding on a stale brownie.  Maybe I'll visit again in a few months to see if I feel differently.

I decided to dine here before seeing Celine Dion (which was canceled that day because she got sick). The menu looked pretty enticing online and I was eager to try a few dishes.   Unfortunately, I wasn't impressed. I felt the food was mediocre and overpriced.   I went with small plates so I could sample different things:  Pig ears - I was so excited to see pig ears on the menu. Growing up in Taiwan, pig ears is a common dish where they marinade with Chinese five spice and make it crunchy but not rubbery. I haven't had pig ears for couple of decades so I was looking forward to this dish. Unfortunately, it wasn't what I expected. The ears were chewy/rubbery and way too salty. I guess if you are drinking beer, this would be good beer bar food. It's not very good on its own.   Calamari steak with chili honey glaze - The server recommended it to me. While the portion is decent and the meat cooked right, the flavor isn't impressive. Maybe it's because I grew up in Taiwan so I'm so used to the sauces that it's nothing new to me. They basically flash fried the calamari steak and the tossed them in some Chinese spicy and sweet sauce that you can buy at 99 Ranch store and call it the day.   Duck fat fries - Tasted just like regular fries. Nothing special.   I was quite disappointed with this experience. If you aren't used to Asian flavors, you might enjoy this place. Otherwise, skip it.

Excellent place to meet up with friends.  I really loved their scallops and chicken entree. The steak was ok.  They make excellent cocktails and I highly recommend going for their happy hour.  Price point is about average..just like anywhere else on the strip.

I was traveling for work and some of my coworkers wanted to find some place nearby for happy hour. They had some really good looking dishes on happy hour but the really selling point was the price! Drinks $5-8 and apps for $9 is pretty much unheard of in Las Vegas, especially on the strip. We each got a drink, nothing special. For apps my favorite was the duck fat prosciutto dusted fries. They were perfectly crispy, probably twice fried. We also got the tomato burrata which was delicious but didn't really fit the theme of the other food. We also got there sliders (opted for lettuce wrapped) and the seasoning of the meat was very good. There was cheddar and bacon mixed into the meat itself which you could tell it really enhanced the flavor. My coworker got the tuna tacos, which were in wonton wrappers. There was a pretty large about of tuna but she said they weren't seasoned very well. All around, I would go back for happy hour by stick to the sliders and fries.

Made reservations about a week ago.....received confirmation emails last week and a reminder today.....showed up for my wife's birthday only to find a CLOSED sign on the door.....thanks Searsucker for not even sending us an email or giving a call!!

We stopped in here on a recent trip to Vegas for a quick happy hour tide-over before our late dinner reservations. We went right when they were supposed to open at 5, and we were basically told they weren't ready to open. So we waited for a bit until they were. Then we were seated in the bar area. It took quite some time for a server to approach us, and when she did, she wasn't exactly bursting with excitement about her job. I ordered the sliders and partner ordered some sort of taco thing. Both were okay, but nothing we would have raved about given the other high end options we visited while we were in town. As others have mentioned, it's dark and loud, so while it was fine when we first got there, but about 6 p.m. it was crowded and overbearing. In all, I probably would have gone with 3 on the food and drink alone (and the happy hour deals were nice), but the service was poor enough that I took it down one star.

Had a great time, for new Resturant it was great. We loved the smalls, next time we all agreed to order two courses of these. The house red was so good- we ordered a bottle, very good. Only a few areas of focus, one main was over salted, and for some reason the bar staff could not make a very dirty, very dry martini!!! But all things considered great new Resturant. We will be back

I recently held a work event here and I cannot tell you how amazing the night was! The catering director was amazing to work with and made all the details easy, the staff was fabulous, and the food and drinks were just outstanding. I would highly recommend dinner or an event at Searsucker.

I love the searsucker in San Diego so my friends and I just had to check out the Las Vegas one. It's pretty different but the experience/ambiance was just as good. I like how the lighting was dim. We sat at the bar for happy hour and each got a specialty cocktail that was so so...but once we started talking to the bartenders they steered us in the right direction. I would recommend changing the cocktail list on happy hour because the couple sitting next to us weren't very impressed either. We had so much fun with the two bartenders. Phill(?) and the blonde girl were so funny! it started our night off right. The girl told us about the wings, peppers and that tomato bruschetta type dish was a must have and she was right. So yummy! She explained how the wings and peppers were prepared because personally, I've never heard of them before and I'm glad I tried something new.

Located in ceasars. We had made ressies and were promptly seated. Ambiance is beautiful - lots of wood and ropes channeling a very natural and warm space. I got a drink that was lychee and sake based and it was just ok. Normally those are my favorite type of drinks. We got the tuna poke as a starter and that was 5 stars!!!! The tuna was deliciously seasoned and loaded on a very delicate crisp seaweed chip. I could've eaten 10 more of those. For dinner we settled on the 2 lb lobster meal for two along with potatoes and Brussel sprouts. The lobster came out quickly and was perfectly grilled with a side of butter of course. My only complain is this meal will likely leave most people hungry. Most of the meat is in the tail which wasn't much and there's some in the claw. Thank god it came with sides. Both Brussel sprouts and mashed potatoes were good. For dessert we tried the bread pudding which came loaded with lit s'mores. Cool concept but the timing is pretty important here and the s'mores were very burned by the time the dish arrived at our table. It looked pretty carcinogenic so we didn't really touch it and the bread pudding was just ok. The dessert menu was pretty limited and the other 3 options were all cold. Would've liked to see a chocolate cake or something. Overall great experience. Apps and entrees seem solid. Cocktails and dessert are more of a hit or miss.

The food was good, my party of 4 had 3 really good dishes. My dish, a chicken with a poached egg was okay.  It was missing something like a thicker sauce ( perhaps a simple wine, cream and morel sauce). However; my hubby's Mahi Mani was Delish! Right amount of sauce, some type of fruit or currant(I don't recall) but great! The Pork Butt, OMG,so good and cooked perfectly. It was a whole meal, there were a few pieces of greens on the plate. My daughter, a 14 year old princess had the $40.00 filet, and she would not give me any! She is a steak conisure and she orders medium and she said it was cooked perfectly. I think she has a picture I will upload. The only downside,it was a lacarte, we didn't eat the sides much, the water at $9, was overpriced so we spent way too much. I think the prices are a little steep but if you hVe the money...go and enjoy!  I almost forgot...the service is great! The Server was really knowledgeble and they are quick to refill and take dirty plates away. Service was top notch!

We had all shared plates. Delicious food made uniquely; octopus, calamari, chicken wings. Service was very helpful and took care of us without interruption. Not the best view nor atmosphere but once the food came it didn't matter. They were also quick to get out the first plates. I would go back again to try other plates and enjoy again some of the previous ones.

Great customer service!  The calimari was not that great smothered in sweet sauce. And fries too much seasoning. The burger was good but not great. Their house wine sweet ;/ but great ambiance and staff. And convenient if in Caesars.

Went here for my birthday dinner, just the boyfriend and I. We shared two tapa like plates (short ribs and spicy shrimp with grits) both very delicious especially the shrimp and grits and we also shared a main plate (tuna wrapped in prosciutto) this was ok kind of bland tasting. The service was excellent and they brought out our ordered dessert with a candle and sang happy birthday to me...the cocktail I also got was delicious, definitely had a kick... jalaberry strawpeno!

Went there the other night without knowing much about it. It was a lot better than I expected. The food and service was very good and even the decor was pleasantly nice. The calamari was delicious for an appetizer but if you want my advice, if you go, make sure you get the braised pork. You'll thank me later. It was done to complete perfection.

My friends and I bought tickets to attend the #VegasStrong benefit show at Omnia, and Oliver at the Hakkasan concierge group reached out to me with a dinner deal at Searsucker. $55 a person for either the prix fixe menu, or spend $55 on the a la carte menu. The entrees are around $30ish, so if you get a cocktail and an appetizer or dessert you're pretty much set. The bonus was a bottle of wine for each four people, and expedited entry into Omnia, which is a huge plus because the lines can get pretty crazy.  I don't remember our server's name, but he handled our party of 12 really well. We opted to do family style sharing plates, so he basically just ordered the menu highlights for us and made it work out to $55 a person. I think we probably would've gotten more food if we would have ordered on our own, but I'm much more of a tapas girl so small portions and bigger variety are right up my alley. They were super nice and even brought out different plates for my gluten-intolerant friend. I lost count, but we probably had about a dozen dishes in all.   Highlights were the burrata, scallops and the skirt steak. The beer marinade on the drunken skirt steak is amazing. The calamari was also really good - strip cut instead of rings and tentacles - super tender, with a yummy chili honey glaze. I'm a huge fan of short ribs and had high expectations for theirs, but it wasn't as "fall apart" as some other ones I've had. We also had hummus, poke, wings, heirloom carrots, brussels, and the brick chicken - everything was good, just nothing super special. I also had a smoked old fashioned, which was really well done. I wish I would have stirred it first though, because I had a sip that was all smoked maple syrup and almost dropped my glass. But once everything was mixed together the flavors were amazing! We skipped dessert because we had to head into Omnia for the show, but I could've easily put down an ice cream sandwich.   Ambiance wise, the restaurant was packed, not a ton of room between tables. EDM music is blasting; I assume because of their partnership with Omnia. Luckily for me that's right up my alley, but it's loud enough that I couldn't hear my friend two seats away. If you're going for dinner and convo, this probably isn't the place for you. But overall, I think it's a decently priced place on the strip with good food, and a great place to grab drinks and small bites before a night out.

Hubby and I had a date night at Searsucker this past weekend and it was awesome!   I had visited one time before for an event, but this was my first "sit down" meal at the restaurant. We had a 9:00 reservation and were seated right away at arrival.   The dining room is modern and unique, with a nice bar, some loungy couch seating beside some wingback chairs and coffee tables, and a typical dining area. The chairs are mismatched which would usually drive me nuts but worked in the space. The chandeliers are rope-y (presumably as a nod to the Southwest) The music was loud when we arrived but chilled out a bit once the DJ started at 10 - this surprised me! The crowd was pretty eclectic, running the gamut from a group of bachelorettes (Who couldn't seem to stay seated at their table) to a dinner party of septegenarians in expensive pantsuits.   Our server stopped by pretty promptly to take our drink order, and a runner brought our drinks to the table shortly thereafter - he set them down along with an order of their Cheese Puffers (they reminded me a bit of the Cheesy biscuits at Red Lobster, which might seem like a backhanded compliment but seriously, those are the only things that can get me into a Red Lobster, and they a freaking addictive, so it is actually high praise)   Then... we didn't see our server for awhile. Like, at all. Nowhere to be seen in the whole dining room. It got to a point where I began to get anxious when Matteo, a floor manager, popped by the table to check in and make sure that everything was good. I briefly mentioned that we were just waiting for our server to come to take our order and he immediately apologized and offered to go ahead and take the order from us. He was kind and hospitable and got us completely taken care of - I mentioned that we planned to order several appetizers "tapas style" and he handled that with aplomb, suggesting that since our table was so small, he would course out the items to leave us enough space to dine. This was a perfect solution and was greatly appreciated.   We ordered a variety of items: Steak Tartare with Taro Chips and Quail Egg - YUM! Super flavorful and a perfect portion size. It was a bit on the salty side, but I think that this just enhanced the beef instead of overpowering it.  Bacon + Eggs - Pork Belly, toast, and a perfectly poached egg... this was really good! I love me some breakfast for dinner, so this was my kind of dish.  Farmbird Meatballs with Snake Bite Sauce and Blue Cheese Fondue - I had these on my first visit and they're what brought me back - amazing! Their version of Buffalo chicken, the combination of flavors is just perfect. The sauce on the meatballs definitely has a kick which is perfectly neutralized by the blue cheese fondue. The portion is nice - 5 good sized meatballs. Tons of flavor - absolutely recommend these. Chicken + Waffle - yet more breakfast for dinner, just my style! Nice combo of salty/sweet. The chicken was moist, the waffle was tasty.   Dessert - We shared the King sundae, which included peanutbutter cup icecream, bacon caramel, whipped cream, and bruleed bananas. Hubby was in seventh heaven.   The service during the remainder of our meal was perfectly timed - the runner who took care of our drinks was well spoken and attentive and our server checked in with us a few times to be sure all was good.   I've been looking forward to Searsucker for awhile and after this experience, I really can't wait to come back again.

I popped in here because the hubs was playing Texas Hold 'Em.  I sat at the bar, ordered a glass of wine, did my Yelp check in, and poof, up pops an offer for a complimentary habanero and coriander pickle.  Never to turn something spicy down, I asked for it.  Well, shut it...that damn pickle rocked my world.  Spicy brine, nice heat, and um, hello, it's a pickle.  What is not to love about pickles?  Nice wines BTG.  Cool menu, creative flavors.

This place was so good. We came in on a Sunday and they had football playing on the TVs. Their menu was small and appeared to have only football snack foods. We ordered anyway. We ordered the buffalo wings and fried chicken and eggs. The food was sooooooo good. All of it. I think my fianc√© got the biscuits, also delicious.   The only reason it didn't get 5 stars is because they were training the bar back to make drinks. Well, they said they were training him but every time he got a ticket for drinks he would let it sit there and wait until a waiter or a bartender would come by for them to make it. (I know this because I sat in view of the bar).   Waited too long for our drinks. When you're in Vegas that's the last thing you want. Disappointed in the training and in the barback.

I was waiting for my parents while they were gambling in the casino. I sat at the bar and tried to get the attention and service from a tall woman/young lady bartender. She had a Raiders t-shirt on so I asked her if she was from the Bay Area or if she was a fan. She replied with a no, then mentioned to me that she was from LA, then walked away. I had to wait for another employee to ask me if I would like to place an order for food and drink. I was treated and welcomed nicely by a gentleman bartender and sat by very friendly patrons. If management is reading this, I would offer her your love until  she learns to love herself. I will pray for her. God Bless.

came here for a private cocktail event. great atmosphere. It is right next to Omnia so it was the perfect place to go before hitting the club. the cocktail was amazing and the hors d'oeuvres were great. tried its crab-cake, sliders, lollipop wings, and tomato & burrata. I find the lollipop wings to be on the salty side but everything else was great! slider is extremely delicious. i would definitely come back again.

Oh my goodness. It isn't often that I feel compelled to write a 5-star review, but this place demands it. Hubby and I had the most wonderful meal here. First of all our server, Charles, was hilarious and engaging. This place labels itself as "a social dining experience" (hey, it's on the receipt like that) and I think they mean because from the moment you walk in, they try to get to know you. The hostess asked us a few questions, and clearly passed that onto our server before he came over to our table, because he was prepped with the info. He started off with a little joke of singing something, which my husband and I quickly joined in on, so we immediately started off on the right foot. Dinner consisted of all small plates. We got the duck fat fries, mushroom burrata toast, egg & pork belly, and short ribs. The fries are tied for first place as the best fries I've ever had. They were perfectly light and crispy, without being dry. The mushroom & burrata toast was incredible with such flavorful, rich mushrooms. The pork belly is essentially grown up eggs Benedict on broiche toast with Hollandaise. It was good, but sadly not warm when we finally got around to eating it (we ordered too much food!) and the short rib, while tender, was not terribly exciting in the flavor department (think pot roast) but still well cooked and falling-apart tender. After seeing a bunch of desserts pass by the table, hubby and I had some room left in our tummies from just sticking to small plates, so we ordered three, yes three, desserts. The desserts are awesome here. The apple crostata was a lovely rustic pie crust purse filled with caramelized apples. After the warm apples, we went the other direction and got something cold with the Ermagerd Sundae. The peanut butter gelato in this sundae is heavenly. It had such rich peanut butter flavor without being too heavy or losing it's creaminess. We had them bring one dessert at a time so we could digest enough to press on. After all this, we still had another dessert on the way. The finale was the S'more bar. The honey flavor in the graham cracker crust was very robust and I had tasted that wonderful honey in a couple of other dishes. I would love to know what kind of honey they use, it's a good one. The chocolate on top of the crust is a very heavy bodied, rich chocolate mousse, topped with whipped marshmallow topping that is torched. It was all delicious. Our server was great throughout the whole meal and we enjoyed him a lot. The meal was excellent all around and I will definitely come back here each time I go to Vegas. Do not miss the desserts here.
Pretty good. Becareful, they will try very hard to upsell you big time, esp with water!

We came here on a Saturday night after we learned about the Omnia Nightclub deal. Basically, each person in your party must spend $50 and you will receive a "chip" that will allow you complimentary expedite meaning, you do not have to wait in line. Now you definitely need to pay to get inside the club, so this chip only lets you come in front of the line. Try and get on a guestlist by looking up on IG etc, then you may get lucky and receive complimentary entry as well. (We wanted to go see Zedd, so we used this chip and got on a guest list that gave us free admission until 1am; arrived around 11:45 and the club was already packed!!!!)  Anyhow, for the food, we had the tuna tacos and octopus for appetizer. Honestly, I expected more but it was very mediocre, not especially tasty or flavorful. For our entr√©e, we ordered the lobster which was AMAZING. The lobster came with mashed potatoes and brussel sprouts that paired well with the lobster.  Would I recommend this restaurant? Probably not, but if you are trying to get into Omnia yes, I think it is a great deal.

We tried Searsucker fourth of July weekend and really honestly wanted to like it. We did our research and we were excited to try several of the menu items. We were "greeted" by the two completely unenthusiastic hostesses and taken to our table. Our server Tammie was knowledgeable when it came to menu and drink suggestions. My husband wasn't thrilled with his unbalanced rather sweet "signature" old fashioned. But being in Vegas we were both still looking forward to enjoying our dinner.    We were seated in the open kitchen area, which we love! and were shocked to watch the chef touch every raw garnish of every plate of food and then wipe his hands on his apron-less pants, face and phone. Not appetizing in the least. We then watched the manager (at least that's who think was the manager) touch every bit of face, eyes, nose, lips and then proceeded to touch the raw garnish on a dish before sending it along with a food runner. Obviously once we saw a few of these incidents we began to notice even more of them. Kind of like a train wreck- you just can't look away!   My husband and I both work in the industry and are sensitive to some of these issues.  We are never THAT table (unhappy without merit or reason) but we found ourselves being irritated with the compounding service issues. Everyone was on their phones almost the entire time! And I don't say/write this lightly.  The chef, the "manager" and a woman who we assumed was an assistant manager were on their phones for significant periods of time, constantly texting. I get it, we all have lives and communicate constantly but step off of the floor and send your quick text but to stand out openly in the dining room for 5 plus minutes on your phone makes no sense and is unacceptable.  The "assistant manager", a younger woman, did not put her phone down once, seriously not once the entire evening. We were laughing about it by the end of the night, that's something that we have never seen before.  Neither the food nor the signature cocktails were a saving grace unfortunately.  We tried a few appetizers wanting to get a good idea of the concept and the Chef.  We started with a couple of the "jar" dishes, the first was the crab, very one note.  The crab was hammered by Sriracha mayo and gargantuan pieces of Avocado.  Next the tomato and burrata jar, was perhaps the "best" appetizer we had, but the burrata itself was begging and pleading for salt, which is not offered on the tables, lol!   We also ordered the bone marrow and pork belly both of which were incredibly sweet.  We didn't even touch the third bone because the sweetness was overwhelming which honestly is saying something because we are both huge marrow fans.  The only thing we remember about the pork belly was how sweet it was.    Lastly we ordered a grass fed NY steak with two sides.  We ordered the strip medium rare, it came out BLUE, completely cold in the middle.  As we took 5 minutes contemplating sending the steak back we realized we were also missing one of our sides.    We NEVER send things back to the kitchen but were at this point rather frustrated and wanted to at least finish our meal and get out of there. The steak was returned to us warmed through a healthy rare but at least edible.  When the corn finally arrived it was by far the best thing we ate that night.  It had a nice balance of smoky, spicy and creamy. The cauliflower was good at first but quickly became rather one vinegary note.   As a last note, while the manager and Chef were steps away from us the entire 2 plus hours we were having dinner, neither of them bothered to acknowledge, greet, check-in, chat, smile, or honestly look at us.  Why even have an open kitchen if you aren't invested in engaging the dining room????   This was the LEAST expensive dinner we ate on our trip and the MOST disappointing by far. IMO service was awful, food was mediocre.  All in all we left feeling frustrated that we wasted an evening of our trip at Searsucker, what a bummer!

The ambiance and food is good. We ordered many of their small plates to share: calamari steaks, octopus, hamachi, duck fat fries, brussels, cauliflower and bone marrow. Everything was OK, there was nothing I ate that I would say was exceptional. However, everything did "look" pretty tasty and while it did taste good, again, nothing special.  We ordered the grilled cheese, a couple salads, the tuna tacos and some sliders. I would say the grilled cheese was the best of all these selections. Nice presentation and really tasty as well.  My one gripe about our experience was our waitress, she seems so over it before our wine even came out. It was a bummer because I truly believe the experience is a huge part of eating out (at least for me). She was dry and emotionless and seemed annoyed overall, which put a damper on our experience, unfortunately. Also, the place was pretty empty, which was weird for a Saturday night in Vegas at 9 pm.   I think I prefer Herringbone Las Vegas...but probably wouldn't turn down coming here again, the food was decent enough to try again.

One of my favorite experiences. A friend invited me and I got there late and everything was almost completely devoured. What was left and that I was able to eat was incredible.  Woooow. Will visit again.

It was our first time here and it was more amazing than we what we heard. Servers were upbeat and wonderful. Desiree was awesome and had great knowledge of the menu. Definitely coming back for more. Ermahgurd!!

This place is located right next door to Omnia. We came here for dinner with plans to go to the nightclub afterwards. The food was surprisingly delicious! We ordered a bunch of different items to share amongst our group, and a whole lot of cocktails to get the party started early. I tried my friend's "Fizzy Lifter" cocktail and it was light, fruity and yummy! I would recommend that for any girls who like fruity drinks. My favorite item out of everything we ordered was the spicy hamachi and avocado! I don't usually do spicy food, but this dish was very tolerable. The guys also got the 36 oz ribeye tomahawk. Let me tell you--that thing is massive!!! They couldn't even finish it. Overall it was a wonderful dining experience.

This place is ok, nothing to die for. They have limited wine by the glass and I had the caramel scallop...1 scallop. It was good, but the rest of the menu is overrated.  If you like eclectic food that's all show, less on taste/substance, this may be spot for you.    The positive was the cheese bread they start you off with.  That was best thing.  Oh, and the service was good, they brought a free desert for my sister's birthday which was nice.
Happy Hour Review - Skip the humous, order the sliders, duck fat fries or bruschetta.  Don't order the martini with the honey and blue, way too sweet.

Amazing drinks, delicious food and a great atmosphere is the perfect combination for a relaxing and enjoyable dining experience.  We tried this place because we liked the menu online and live in SoCal and with the options near home it was a good way to try some yummy food that we may also be able to try when home.  We will be trying the restaurants near home for sure too.    The service was solid but we also were there during Happy Hour so it was a slight slow at times but over all very solid.  We went during Happy Hour and got a collection to share at the table to try several different options.  Hummus - very flavorful and the bread was delicious alone but the hummus added to It.  Potato fries - anything fried in duck fat is going to be amazing and this did not disappoint.  The prosciutto dust added to the flavor.  Slider - perfectly cooked and had a nice spicy to them.  Tuna taco - fresh and flavorful

Cocktails and food were delicious, great atmosphere.  I would give it a 5 but my steak came out well done instead of medium rare the first time but they corrected it with grace.  Definitely will come back.
Stopped by for happy hour before a show.  Nice atmosphere and decor.  Hummus was excellent and the pita bread was housemade.  Tuna tacos were also very good.

Just okay. Service was pretty annoying. Either they wouldn't leave us alone so we could finish certain items, or we had to ask for every little thing. They bugged us constantly as we ate, then literally disappeared for 15 minutes after we finished. I cannot stand bad service when I'm paying at a high price point.   Best part - Short ribs with horse radish mash. So so good. Worst part - over cooked New York that the waiter held in 'better light' over my friend's head to show us that it was 'what we ordered.' So unprofessional and quite rude. My husband is much more forgiving and just ate it since the waiter argued with us about the degree of cooking. We were sharing so I actually didn't eat any steak. Thankfully my friends shared the short rib with me.   Pear goat cheese salad was good. Kale Ceasar was good. Mac and cheese was good. Butter potatoes were good. All was just good. Vegas, Ceasars Palace, Saturday nights....I want great for the amount of money we are paying.   I won't be back. Not with 100 other options in a 1 mile radius.

Being the good wife that I am, I took my husband out for dinner at Searsucker.  Having dined here before I knew he would enjoy their tasty dishes.    I originally just wanted to stop in for happy hour but since they had an event going on in the bar area, we stepped in for a full dining experience.  Service was great! Before we met our waiter, another waiter stopped over for drink orders.  He noticed ours was busy with another table and didn't want us to go unnoticed.  Very thoughtful and attentive! During the rest of our meal service was nothing less than excellent.  He was professional and courteous.   We started with the lollipop buffalo wings with the blue cheese fondue.  Well it isn't really fondue so much as it is just a small cup blue cheese dressing.  But the wings are good.  The meat came right off the bone so easily.  Tasty starter for sure.    The delicious meals we ordered were wonderful! I enjoyed the beer braised short ribs served over horseradish potatoes topped with two onion rings.  So tender, flavorful and mouthwatering.  I should have stopped at eating half but it was just too good to stop.    My husband ordered the filet medium rare as usual.  His belief is that a steak should not need any sauce to be good.  Well they nailed it here.  The perfectly cooked steak was before him.  There wasn't any doubt it was good since he cleaned the plate.    Chef Malarkey has done a fine job with Searsucker.  I'm looking forward to my next visit!

Best burger I've ever had.  How can you go wrong? Beef burger with pork belly, cooked to perfection with gruyere cheese, caramelized onion and baconaise all nestled between a butter bun.  Soooo good!  My friend had the Drunk chicken crust sandwhich that was equally as delicious.  Can't wait to go back for dinner with my hubby!

We were on the Strip at Caesars for a show and wanted to grab a light dinner afterwards. Seersucker had decent yelp reviews and was very close to the theater so we thought we would give it a try. Almost immediately after we sat down, Tyler, Our server came by to greet us, get our drink orders, and explain the menu. Immediately made us feel very welcome. Because we were not terribly hungry we decided we would go for three small plates and their corn bread muffins. For the small plates we got the calamari, the octopus, and the short ribs. Tyler told us that the calamari is one of their house specialties. He did not lie. They were quite good. The octopus is grilled. It was tasty. But nothing really special. The short ribs with mashed potatoes were short ribs with mashed potatoes, also nothing really special. The cornbread muffins with the specialty butter actually the highlight of the evening. Quite tasty for only five dollars, If you consider a restaurant charging for 7 really small muffins to be OK. So if the calamari was quite good, and the cornbread muffins were also good, and the service was excellent, why only three stars. You have to take into account value. Each of the small plates dishes were $18. I thought this was a little on the high side even for the strip. In addition, they nail you put $12 in parking.So when you figure 3 small shared plates, no adult beverages, and parking plus tax and tip was $90. Not a great value. Definitely would not go back here and would not recommend

This place is very lively for happy hour, I recommend stopping by and grabbing a table at the bar. Our happy hour menu did not look like the ones that people posted on here so they may have updated it or they have different menus different nights.  We ordered a bunch of cocktails but really loved the matador and skinny jenny. We also loved the pork chips, fish tacos and sliders. I could have eaten 3 orders of the pork chips, they were wonderful.   The only things we didn't love were the chicken wings and the shishito peppers, they were both fine just not what we were expecting.

We came here for happy hour, the drinks were priced ok for Vegas $5-9.  The food was good, I guess we expected more from a top chef restaurant.  The biggest issue that we had was we had asked for the avocado on the side of our ahi tuna tacos because I am allergic to avocado but my wife isn't.  The bartender that took our order explained it was already on the side.  After my first bite into the taco I realized it was on the bottom of the taco as well.  Very disappointing. We also order the lollipop wings which were $9 on happy hour.  They had good flavor, but I don't think they were anything special.

Date - June 15, 2015  After have a decent, but not great, dinner at Hakassan we cabbed back to Caesars (our home base) for dessert at Searsucker. The place was fairly crowded but we got seated right away.  The decor is interesting and the ambiance is extremely loud - there is no intimacy and conversation is very difficult.  Our waitress seemed overwhelmed - everything was very slow. At one point she came to check on us well after we had ordered and said, "How is everything? Oh, I see you don't have your desserts yet." That pretty much sums up the experience.  The desserts were OK  ... we had two orders of the warm apple crostata (it wasn't very warm) and one order of cookies and milk. We ended up taking two of the cookies with us and they were thrown away the next day.  I don't need to go back.

Good food but pricey. I enjoyed our meal, the Yelp check in offer is SPICY but delicious, would purchase next time I go, so good business tactic there. I wouldn't mind trying more food on the menu, we came late at night and sat down close to closing time, but nobody seemed to care and we got good service, but we didn't do the usual appetizer, drink, entree approach; however, the food we did have was tasty and good portions. You might feel out of place in shorts and a tshirt, so go to your room and change if you were just at the pool or something.

The food is overpriced but good!  The staff was great.  I had the short ribs.  The horseradish mash wasn't spicy at all and the habenero pickles just tasted like sweet pickles. The grilled cheese was very tasty and the fries were crisp and delicious.

My boyfriend and I dined here during happy hour and sampled just about everything. The service was absolutely excellent. Our server sent over a complimentary appetizer as well as comped our dessert as it was my birthday. The food quality, portions and prices are all great for being right on the strip. There was also a great beer menu. Also a bonus, the owner (prior Top Chef contestant) was in the restaurant the day we dined there. We would definitely go back and would recommend this restaurant to everyone.

At Laurie's birthday 11/20/2015..9:33pm. Party of 14. My New York Steak - worse than gross. Denny's is like Mortons compared to this. I ordered medium. Barely ran past the fire. Lobster Mac n Cheese disgusting. Bearded Waiter - convinced this stuff was going to be good... Maybe it is sometimes. People at our table really liked the bone marrow dish.  Crab cake was good. Calamari was very good.

So was very excited to try this place but it fell flat. The cocktails served were just ok, the game has been uped so much in Vegas on this front that these served were just boring and lacked any craftsmanship on prepration, service or presentation.   The food was good, not amazing, not phenomenal, it was good.   The bartender server was not engaging, didn't introduce self and staff on our way out failed to thank or say bye. I asked what their infused liquors were and instead of telling me their offerings she (the bartender) gave me the definition of infusion... sigh.
Excellent drinks and service! Make sure to say "Hi" to Adrian at the Bar, awesome bartender!
Good service, food was great. Presentation was wonderful, small portions for the cost but overall good. Hit up the happy hour for the best value!

We went for a friends bday party and after reading a few other reviews, I agree.  One, the plating was prety.  Two, some bites were really good and some were like "WHAT!"  Everything we tried ie: pickles, bone marrow, fingerling potatoes, cauliflower, shark, filet, and pork had good bites, and had bad.  for instance.  My shark had crab meat on top, couldnt tell if it was fresh or from a can.  It was so super salty it literally felt like I was a horse... if that make sense, licking a salt lick.  I ate around it and the outside of the shark was super salty too!  Like literally salty!!!!   i even told the manager he was like... oh im sorry... i had to ask for some lime to tame the salt.  I shoulve asked for a shot of tequila too.  Either way, drinks were amazing, and the steak was nicely done.  The server wasn't that on top of it, the horsd'oevre  came before the drinks :/  and it wasnt even busy.  anyways.  it was all right.

Malarkey's Duck Fat Fries are the best way to celebrate National French Fry Day. As always there is no better fry than a duck fat fry and these guys make some good ketchup too. Had the flank steak and jalapeno chorizo corn. Delicious. Simply, delicious.

I've read and heard mixed reviews about Searsucker Scottsdale so I decided to go check it out for myself.  I went with a friend in town so I was a bit nervous to explore unchartered territory. I can understand the mixed reviews.   Great atmosphere. NIce for romance or groups. We ponied up at the bar and had great service.    I ordered a handcrafted cocktail that was a special and not on the menu. It was DELISH!   Decided to order a few appetizers instead of entrees:   Shishito peppers = standard but delicious   Pork Belly + Egg on Brioche = tender and decadent. Great flavors.   Chicken + Waffles = Surprising preparation. Ask your server. VERY good!  Kobe Carpaccio = Meh! I enjoyed the razor thin slices. But the flavor was bland and the hearts of palm slaw in the middle ruined the entire dish.   I'd definitely go back!

The food is solid, and HH has some pretty good deals... but the service is terrrrrible- hit up HH 4:30-6PM for food and drinks at half price or less, but show up half an hour before you want anyone acknowledge you. No exaggeration. Oh, and then double check your receipt to be sure you were actually charged HH price instead of regular.   DUCK FAT FRIES + TOMATO JAM: All of my LA friends raved about duck fat fries like four years ago and I never tried them. These are some damn near perfect fries, but I was expecting some sort of distinct "duck fat" flavor and didn't really pick up on one. The tomato jam seems to just be a house-made ketchup with a bit of spice to it. STRAWBERRY + CHAMPAGNE + WALNUT + GOAT: It's a salad, fresh for summer. Instead of goat cheese crumbles or large circles, the cheese is served as a "fondue" on the plate. I found the sauce a little light on flavor and missed the texture it usually brings to a salad. "COBB" SALAD: Good portion, $6 for HH. Very fresh, lots of ingredients, cut to the proper size, and something I would get again even though it's far from a unique dish. TUNA + RADISH + TARO CHIPS + SPICE: The taro chips are huge and provide great texture. The poke itself was spicier than I expected but was exceptionally fresh. Not sure I'd get this again though.  EGGS + BACON "PORK BELLY": Cue the hallelujah choir! Perfectly poached egg, generous and thick cut of pork belly, drizzled with a delightful hollandaise with a slight sweetness to it, all atop a thin slice of toast. I'll wake up early every day if this is for breakfast! CRAB CAKE JUMBO LUMP + FENNEL + LEMON VERBENA AIOLI: Slightly salty but otherwise great! Made with very little filler, allowing the simple ingredients to shine. Server said this also had a Tabasco tobiko that I really enjoyed. Pretty pricey though at $17 regularly, a steal at $10 during HH. SHORT RIB "HARLOT" + HORSERADISH + FRIED ONION: It looked dry and didn't have much sauce, but was very tender and shredded easily. The fried onions and butter potatoes were simple but perfectly executed.  SWEET HEAT SQUID: Calamari in a sweet and sour sauce, with julienned apples. Fresh, good variety of textures, generous portion for HH. BF really enjoyed this. SHRIMP GRITS: Not a great version. Several shrimp, bland sauce, overcooked grits. This was a bit saucier than I liked and needed seasoning. Would not get this again, it's on the HH menu and I think it's priced appropriately there. MUSSELS: The broth was missing something, but was nicely fragrant with a large portion. The accompanying garlic bread was perfectly soft on the inside and crusty on the outside. Would get this again.  The food is pretty decent. Bar staff are friendly, but I have twice been assigned to a server who waited nearly a half hour to show up at my table, and nearly as long to bring the check. Given my two dismal service experiences during HH, it's not a place I'm willing to return for a full meal.

Amazing food!! Could not go wrong with whatever you end up choosing. Calamari steak was excellent!! That was probably my favorite of all the dishes we tried.   Calamari Steak 10/5 Lollipop wings 5/5 Fish & chips 5/5 - presentation is gorgeous! Spaghetti Squash Scampi 5/5 Short ribs 5/5 - super tender!! Pork belly 4/5 - I'm biased though cause I'm not a big pork fan.  Ice Cream Sammies   Cookies & milk   I gotta go back for happy hour one day!

What a great joint!  Awesome service too.  Seems like the menu has changed.  This is what was there tonight.  Starters: Potato Fries - unreal.  Crunchy and delicious.   Lollipop wings very tasty.  There was a crab and avocado dip with crusted covered chips - unreal.  Few beers on tap.  Good selection.  Specialty cocktails we had: Achilles Peel and the Indian Summer - both delish, but I thought Achilles was stronger!!  (and no complaint on that) ;) ;)  Dinner: The fish & chips is the BEST I've ever had.  Hands down. One diner had the steak and spinach.  Steak was a bit over done but still good and great spinach.  Another diner had the swordfish - was awesome.  Very disappointed on the dessert.  The profiteroles were three teeny tiny puffs and a tablespoon of peanut butter ice cream and gelee squares on the plate.  True profiteroles are BIG puffs with ice cream in the middle.  I get you need to make your artistic mark on your food - but not dessert, people!  Make 'em normal.  Still a great night.  Would recommend and would return.

Pretty delicious, trendy place inside of Caesars. If you're staying at Caesars, definitely check out happy hour!   The food is pretty delicious, and the drinks are very good! We had the duck fat fries (pretty darn good), the short rib with horseradish mash (really good), and the spicy shrimp and grits (sooooo spicy, but delicious).  Plus, the Happy Hour drinks were creative, and strong!   It was a great place to stop for snacks and drinks, but I wouldn't pay the full menu prices for the food we had. Go during happy hour, it's totally worth it.  We got dinner and 3 drinks for $55.

This place is pretty good! I don't know if I will keep coming back for dinner, but the cocktails are awesome and the food is good.  The head chef is Brian Malarkey who was on Top Chef and is now on The Taste if you are into cooking reality TV :)  Honestly, the ambiance is amazing. Its really a nice place to just hang out have a few drinks and even happy hour is great. The best drink is the peter rabbit . It is pimms, basil, and has a garnish of a carrot which is pretty neat. As far as the food, the cheddar puffs are awesome as is the lamb. It is cooked a little rare, but I liked it. The flavor was awesome.  Check out the happy hour for cheaper drinks and apparently there is a brunch which we are looking forward to trying!

This place is delicious. Great casual atmosphere and a variety of food. For appetizers we ordered an avocado/crab dip and calamari that were both amazing! I ordered the tuna, rare, and it was perfect. My favorite part of dinner, the milk and cookies(not on the menu, but you have to order!). The only thing that threw me off was that this restaurant is supposed to work together with Omnia and they are 2 completely different atmospheres. They do not blend well at all. Overall, awesome restaurant.
Pricey.  I had the beet salad, which had way too much arugula. No one likes arugula that much.   Good service and the water glasses are cool!

Good food and good service. We had a large group and needed to be out by a certain time. The chef was really great about creating a tapas style meal. The ahi tacos, steak tartar were good. I wouldn't write home about the entrees, steak, chicken, and fish. Those were alright, not great. The Stars were definitely the more appetizer style dishes. I would come back if prompted.

I have nothing but wonderful things to say about the experience here. From the moment you walk in to the moment you leave you are VERY well taken care of in all aspects. We were greeted by the manager, Ashley, whom was very knowledgeable about the items on the menu from the food to the cocktails and ALL of her recommendations were WONDERFUL.  A+ to you and all of your staff !!!  Thank You !

All around, I really liked this new restaurant. And that really is saying something, considering I had some weird food issues causing me to be very picky about ordering the night I visited Searsucker. I must first say that the service was impeccable. Our waitress, despite my many questions and requests to leave ingredients out of my dishes, was personable, helpful, and attentive.   I had a small plate (the meatballs with tomato sauce, basil, parmesan cheese, and polenta) and a side dish (roasted root vegetables and squash, without the farmer's cheese that normally accompanies this item). Both were delicious, albeit rich. The small plates were very generous in size, which I love, because it enables sharing. I also thought that the complementary cheddar and black pepper (?) biscuits were amazingly tasty. My friends raved about the cocktails, and I was impressed when the waitress told us that all of their cocktails have no added sugars or preservatives.  The desserts are especially worthy of mention. Although somewhat pricey at $9 each, they were absolutely wonderful. We had the sundae, which had some sort of bacon brittle, peanut butter cup pieces, ice cream, caramelized bananas, and peanuts. It was so good, I was practically licking the bowl. The combination of textures, plus saltiness combined with sweetness, was perfect. We also had the cinnamon sugar doughnuts with a dark chocolate dipping sauce, which was a HUGE portion and SO yummy. The doughnut holes were steaming hot and just chewy enough. We couldn't finish those suckers, there were so many!  Also, I paid $30 total, including tax and tip (one small plate, one side, two desserts split with 3 other people). I thought that was impressively reasonable for the high quality of the food and the service. I would go back!
Great place, unique tasty food, wonderful service!!  We will be going back soon

I am so bummed that I waited so long to go to Searsucker! It was absolutely fabulous. I will admit that my fondness for Top Chef and the adorable Brian Malarkey was the first reason why I wanted to eat at this new Scottsdale restaurant, but the food and ambiance will be why I go back again.  The restaurant is tucked off Camelback road and Fashion Square Mall and has these funky looking animal statues outside. Hey, I guess you gotta do what you can to get people to notice you, right? The staff was very friendly and welcoming to us. There was a DJ in the bar area and many people enjoying happy hour. The dining room was pretty dead, but it is July in Phoenix and that can be expected of many restaurants. The restaurant was very big, much bigger than I anticipated. The ambiance was casual and sexy at the same time.  I started off with a La Primavera cocktail and it was delicious, but not remarkable. My husband ordered a red wine suggested by our server. It was very good. Of course my husband will always Google a wine on his phone if he likes it so he can compare prices. I guess it was overly priced per glass vs what you could get the wine by the bottle in a retail outlet. Oh well, that is Scottsdale. We started off with the Smalls: Pork belly "bacon" + 63 degree egg. It was not only gorgeous in presentation, but really tasty! Kinda like breakfast for dinner.  Next up, we split the "Cobb" salad. Oh. My. Gosh. I know it is just a salad, but it was amazing. The blue cheese vinaigrette was amazing. The flavors of the toppings were incredible with every bite. I'm crazy about veggie sides, so I almost ordered all of them with dinner so I could take a few bites of each, but we decided to just do 4. They were the bacon grits, the cauliflower, brussels sprouts, and chorizo with "corn off the cob." The sides were ok. Nothing that wowed me. The brussels were overly salty and I couldn't taste any of the flavor of the other veggie sides because there was so much extra stuff involved in them. But I'm glad I tried them and now know. Luckily, my chicken entree was fantastic. Absolutely delicious and perfectly cooked over a bead of bulgar and sweetbreads (I don't know where the sweetbreads were unless they were mixed in really well with the bulgar,) but they were fantastic. Loved this dish and would order it again. For dessert we split a sundae, I can't remember the name of it, but it was clever. And it was really good. A sweet ending to a great evening.  I can't wait to go back...maybe with a group of friends. It seems like a great place to go for big girls night out.

Searsucker has been a the best overall addition to the Caesars restaurant line-up in years.  In both visits, we have opted for appetizers and sides to sample its cuisine.  Flavors here are extraordinary. Best brussels side of any restaurant anywhere and ive had it everywhere. The corn n chorizo side is also stellar rich in citrus flavor. The sliders we ordered was piping burning hot when we bit into them, rich in flame grilled flavor and a nicer portion than at Spago. Both salads were first rate. Loved the lemony zest of the Caesar without thr garlic overkill and the Pear & walnut salad was taken up a notch with the whipped goat cheese garnish   The Calamari was just ok. Liked the asian twist and apples. Would have liked it better served traditionally cut thin in rings and tentacles.  Friendly service at the bar and s'mores dessert was killer good. One day ill get around to ordering an entree. In the meantime, im hopeful Searsucker becomes a Caesars fixture for a long time to come.

Wasn't horribly impressed. The menu is not cohesive enough to give the kitchen any rythym to service, hence, there are huge swings in quality of the food. The duck fat fries were so ovely seasoned it was obscuring the pancetta and the unctuousness of the duck fat. The chicken was under seasoned and dry, traded that out for a mid rare filet that was totally bloody... but we ate it anyway since the demi glace was plentiful and delicious. It was very loud too, too much of everything to be wonderful at anything. You blew it on this one Brian! Chef Jill

I was excited upon seeing a lively rustic chic lounge/bar/dining room. Atmosphere and service were great all-around but there was a noticeable gap between appetizers and entrees.  Of the appetizers, the scallop (one) stood out and the tender squid was fantastic. I'd pass on the dry meatballs. The bacon sounded good but I didn't try it; I just heard the crisp from the other end of a large table.   Entrees were meh. Portions were tiny for the price. My filet was overcooked and the meat was tough to cut into. Salmon portion was also laughable and I noticed four differently-sized pieces on four plates. I'm sure they go by weight over shape/size but still, perception trumps reality. The red velvet cake I had was dry and bland. Among the worst I've had for the price.    Halfway through dinner, a live DJ starting spinning house tracks. I don't think it fit the restaurant vibe and average age of patrons. I found it slightly off-putting and made it difficult to hear my dinner party. Another tip: park next door at NM (one minute walk) for free and avoid the valet.   Overall: another "celebrity"-chef hype failing to meet expectations. Avoid bedtime texts with dining partners about how hungry y'all still are. Spend the same amount elsewhere for a much more satisfying, and filling, meal.

Pricey Vegas hotel food, however each dish has its own unique character. The waiters and waitresses are all very friendly. Each person came by with a smile. We were served cream-puff looking biscuits after we sat down. They taste exactly like Goldenfish or CheezeIt's even. Not bad, probably wouldnt have ordered those by themselves.   We ordered: Squid w/stripes of apple -  yum!  Pork butt - has a great tasting sauce Short rib -  pass on this, ive had better Shrimp ceviche - eh, i'd also pass on this Duck fat fries -  not bad either, reminds me of truffle fries.   I'd say this place is tapas-style. Everything comes in small portions but decorated so eloquently. I expected more food for the price.

Eric was an amazing server and so helpful. He was amazing at blending the needs of the group with his own recommendations. And his recommendations were spot on- the braised beef was some of the best I've had (and I'm from the Bay Area, home of braised beef). Overall, an amazing experience for is and our bachelorette group of 12.  Also, from the bachelorette party organizers, this place is perfect for flexibility of a large party and also lets you count drinks toward the max (which some places done).   So good!!

For our last night in Las Vegas, we decided to go to Searsucker. Located in Caesar's Palace, Searsucker is the restaurant by chef Brian Melarkey, who has had stints on Top Chef and the Taste. I didn't realize this until after the fact, I was just excited by the menu.  The vibe is modern chic meats rustic. Reservations are recommended, even during weekdays, which we did. We started with drinks- they have a decent wine list but also have an interesting cocktail list. I decided on the skinny jenny which is basically a moscow mule with lavender and other surprising ingredients. I loved it. It was a light, refreshing, and well made cocktail. For my meal I decided on oysters and mac and cheese (not in the same dish). The oysters were delicious and came with a refreshing pomegranate sauce. The mac and cheese was also quite delicious and very filling. Rich in flavor (and in cheese), it was definitely a tasty dish.   Service was very good throughout our meal. We were never without an empty water glass and our server made good recommendations. Yelp check in gets you a free appetizer of their house made pickles. It is a pricer meal but definitely worth it for the experience.

So we decided to try this place for our anniversary (14 years).   It started really well. We had 1/2 dozen east coast oysters. They were delicious (although, I'd have preferred them a little colder).   Next we had bone marrow, also delicious. Seriously, it was very good.   For our entrees, Mike had thr scallops, and I had the burger, medium, which is pertinent to this review.   The burger is supposed to be a big deal, they only make 20 a day.   When my burger arrived, I took a bite out of it, raw. Like, not even warm in the middle.   After I found our server, Giana (she seemed put out to be serving us from the beginning), I sent it back.   Then we waited... and waited...  Then I got my burger, which was the exact burger I had sent back. I know this because I could see the bite I took out of it.   Seriously, if I went to McDonald's they would have made me a new burger, you'd expect a celebrity chef (as stated on the menu) to at least have a service standard on par with a fast food joint.   I started eating. And I just got more angry.   It's a burger with relish and avocado. Why would you reheat that? Gross!  And is it even sanitary?    Do you want to have a steak cooked on a grill after some stranger has taken a bite out of it.   I felt bad for the manager though. He tried. He came over and acknowledged the problem.   Offered some short ribs, which is nice, but I hate that.   I'm supposed to eat by myself, while Mike watches, because a fine dining restaurant doesn't know how to cook a burger.
Amazing cocktails and atmosphere. The cookie for dessert is delicious! Great place to check out with friends

Great customer service and the short rib plate was delicious. However, the duck fat fries weren't the crunchy consistency I was expecting, in fact they were pretty soggy. The pork slider was okay, but that's it just okay...

My husband and I went here to celebrate his birthday. The service was impeccable and the food was amazing!  We made a reservation and were seated promptly. After being seated we admired the interesting decor, kind of modern meets rustic. Our server came over and I expressed to him my dairy issue, he then went out of his way to check with the chef to see what could be made dairy free. He then came back a made several recommendations on what to eat. We had the following: Mussels: a generous portion in a white wine sauce, with chunks of chorizo Tongue & cheek: perfectly cooked tender meat, with flavorful pieces of tongue Lobster butter steak: amazing flavor and cooked very well And for dessert they gave my husband a complimentary birthday cupcake which was really good too. I would highly recommend Searsucker, I can't wait to go back.

Tried this restaurant for the first time last night. At  our table, we had the filet, the shrimp and the pork butt as well as the duck fat fries, the calamari, the tuna wanton tacos and the biscuits. Everything was great, including the sides (buttered potatoes and Brussels sprouts). We will definitely be back.

Props for barrel aged cocktails in this margarita town. I preferred Jeff M.'s barrel aged Martinez to my Latin Cinema (tasted like a regular margarita to me). Onto the food--cheddar biscuits were delicious, and so was the corn off the cob and the chicken & waffles. The tuna entree was meh. Next time I am sticking to sides and apps.

We went here for dinner. This place is over priced, serves a very small amount of food. And the food tastes horrible. Avoid at all costs. We got the chicken wings, we got like 4 tiny wings. The burrata was tasteless and tasted stale.

I've been wanting to go here for quite a while. I loved Brian M on Top Chef so I knew that his food would be inventive and fresh. Reservations are a must for dinner.  I started with my fave, a dirty martini. Very well made. Perfectly dirty, like I like it. :P  We were a group of 7 women so we all had cocktails and for food starters, we opted for the raw choices of poke and ceviche. Devine. Served very rustically on wood boards in mason jars. I kind of like the presentation....it was cute and unexpected. But the theme is throughout the decor as well, so it fits.  We moved on to share the calamari (and ordered another as it was THAT good) and the shishito peppers (just like everywhere else).  I ended with scallops that were wonderful and a few others had the salmon or steak. Everyone was pleased and satisfied.   This is a great option in Vegas.  It's a bit loud, but it IS in the casino. And of course, as most places in nice Vegas hotels, it's a bit pricey. But if you are out for a decent meal in a cute setting, definitely try Searsucker.

So excited that their Vegas location has opened! Searsucker San Diego has always been a favorite of mine. Plus now the Vegas restaurant is perfectly placed in Caesars next to Omnia Nightclub, and with extended hours. So we can grab some green eggs and ham (seriously! A must try) after working up an appetite on the dance floor. Best addition in a long time!

This is a happy hour review! Prices listed below are happy hour prices as of 4/29/15.  The Skinny: excited to try their happy hour menu items and they are all pretty good albeit not without flaws(3.75) service is prompt and efficient at the bar(4) value: portion sizes are very generous for a happy hour menu and the food is solid for the most part. Service was good at the bar. (3.75 bump up to 4 starred review)   FYI -  signage is poor in Caesar's Palace so it is hard to find.  Searsucker is tucked away close to the sportsbook and next to the Omnia dance club.   We were totally jived to try out Searsucker's happy hour menu. We got duck fat fries ($4), the farm bird lollipops, the Caesar salad, the Strawberry/goat cheese/walnut salad ($6 each),  the tuna tartare,  the squid ($8 each), the crab cake and the short rib ($10 each). We were slightly disappointed that the burger on the online happy hour menu was gone but with their sizable menu,  this was easily overlooked. We were surprised but the serving size was very generous for each of these dishes especially the aforementioned $10 items and the two salads. We probably won't order that much again knowing how big the servings are.   Here is the run down:  Duck fat fries with tomato jam ($4): satisfying with a nice smokey flavor from the tomato jam. The hubs would have preferred a slightly crisper texture but I found them to be pretty good in that regard. Would order again.   Farmbird lollipops + hot sauce + Bleu ($6): these were more like chicken meatballs on a skewer. The flavor wasn't really hot per se. It tasted more like sweet and sour rather than hot sauce like -  kind of like Swedish meatballs. The Bleu cheese flavor was rather muted. Overall, this dish was a bit too sweet for my taste.  Pass on this.   Strawberry + champagne + goat cheese + walnuts ($6): get this! Delicious and lightly dressed,  the flavors married beautifully together. Protip: the goat cheese is adhered to on the bottom of the plate so make sure you give a good scrape before you dig in. Portion size is generous and could easily make 2 side salads.   "Caesar" romaine + kale + egg + parm ($6): okay Caesar. Honestly, the dressing did not have that  garlicky, fishy (from anchovies) punch and missed that hit of acidity in the end. The dressing was a bit too salty as well. Serving size again was very generous and could easily stand in as a light meal on its own. Would pass and get an extra strawberry/goat cheese salad instead.   Tuna + radish + taro + spice ($8): pretty good but it is still tuna tartare. The spice is very mild. The tuna was pretty tasty and good quality and worked well with the taro chips. Would order this again depending on the mood.  Squid "sweet heat" ($8): the good -  exquisitely tender squid that melts in your mouth, delicious sauces; the bad - dressed too heavily with the Thai chili sweet sauce so we lost the crispness of the fried batter. Overall would be better if both sauces served on the side to maintain the crisp exterior layer. Good dish but needs some refinement -  maybe order again with the sweet chili sauce on the side to see if that changes the dish.   Short rib "the harlot" + horseradish + fried onions ($10): very good portion size and easily could be a main entree sized meat portion. Fork tender short rib with a hit of horseradish near the end.  Served over mashed potatoes,  this is a very comforting dish. Personally I thought the gravy could use a little more acidity but that I think is more personal taste. The hubs wolfed this dish down. Would recommend.   Crab cake jumbo lump + fennel + airlines ($10): if you like crab,  you will like this. Lots of crab meat in chunks with minimal filler. A tinge too salty,  it worked well when mixed with the aioli and a good squeeze of lemon. Would order again.   Overall,  our dishes were very good in general and portion sizes for a happy hour menu are very generous. There is enough variety to satisfy most people,  sample some good eats for a reasonable price (for the Strip).  Service was excellent at the bar -  our water glasses were promptly filled and check taken care of quickly. Food arrived swiftly to the table as well. A solid 4 star experience.
