This is a solid new restaurant.  The bar tenders are really nice.  Of course I stopped here during restaurant week and the menu was great.  For $40 I started with one of the most beautiful salads I had even eaten.  It had a puddle of what could only be described as goat cheese loveliness spread on the bottom of my plate.  Then there was a generous topping of assorted lettuces, plus lots of strawberries topped with balsamic.  It was so nice.  I then had the flat iron steak which was real decent, but the star of that was the chimmichuri.  I may not have spelled that correctly, but you know what I mean.  The end of the meal was AMAZING as I had the cookies and milk.  So delicious.  There were three cookies and they were chocolately amazingness with just a quick sprinkle of sea salt on top.  I have decided that if I ever make chocolate chip cookies, I am sprinkling sea salt on top.  Now, mind you, I already do this with my peanut butter cookies, but who knew salt would be equally delicious on chocolate chip cookies??  A quick note, I find the dining area to be EXCEEDINGLY loud as there are bare floors and lots of people squished into a small spot.  The music was awesome though, even if it added to it's loudness ;)

Conveniently located near Caesars Palace Casino, we stopped here for a small dinner and it was perfect. I had the duck fat fries and Brussels and my husband, at the recommendation of the server, Ordered the scallops. Scallops were tender and the creamy sauce was delicate. The Brussels sprouts were roasted in a wonderful sauce, I could've done with the walnuts. And the fries were an enormous order of fries, perfect with Parmesan and bbq sauce! Their Mai Tai (don't judge, I was on vacation) was a unique recipe including lime juice and almond syrup! Loved it. Only took off one star for the server that was very overwhelmed and the place seemed severely understaffed for the night. He did great with the recommendations though.

Food and service are both excellent. Came here for happy hour had the shrimp and grits crab cakes and Caesar salad. Plenty of food for 2 people. HH has good selection of food not just bar bites. Drinks for HH have plenty to choose from not limited to well drinks and crappy beer. Service was great attentive without hovering food cam out very quick. Good amount of seating options for HH will definitely be bringing friends and out of towners.

Hubby and I visited during happy hour a few weeks ago and had a fun time! All of the food on the happy hour menu is nine dollars. Personally, I think this is a little on the expensive side, so I went in with higher expectations. All in all, things were just fine.   Duck Fat Fries - 2/5 Perfectly fine fries. But I couldn't taste the duck fat at all.   Blackened Tuna Tacos - 4/5 I'm not usually a fish fan, but I actually loved them! Hubby, who ordered it thought they were only ok.  Mac N Cheese - 3/5 This isn't on the Happy Hour menu and was $18. The portion is definitely large enough to share and considering what else we'd ordered we couldn't finish it all. However, it wasn't $18 exciting. I could've used even more Cheese and I don't think I saw a trace of bacon the menu claims.   Another HH menu item that someone near us ordered were the sliders and those looked pretty good. Maybe we should've tried those.    The good thing is the service was attentive and friendly and the decor is super cool. Depending on what you want, this might be the place for you.

Originally it was a review in Seven magazine that sparked my interest in this spot, so I decided to check it out myself to see if it lived up to the hype. It met every expectation and more!   We were 20 minutes late for our reservation but called ahead to let them know and were seated right away (this could have been attributed to the fact that it was a relaxed Sunday night and wasn't super busy). The menus were pretty simple in that they didn't necessarily list all the ingredients in each dish. This was done to invoke questions and a more interactive experience, according to the server. Our server, Alyssa, was incredibly knowledgable and accurate in her descriptions of the menu items, and after much deliberation, we decided on:  -Duck fat fries with prosciutto bits (an absolute must- very flavorful) -Cowboy caviar (Rocky Mountain oysters with toasted kale and sweet potato with a balsamic drizzle- my favorite part of the meal!) -Pork butt with whiskey apples (melt in your mouth goodness) -Warm toffee pumpkin pudding cake (we didn't think we would have enough room for dessert but we're glad we ordered it!)  The dishes were as simplistic in their delivery as the menu had been, yet were still presented beautifully on each plate. This is not a restaurant that makes you question your knowledge of which fork to use- rather, it's a relaxed, inviting atmosphere where the servers are as unpretentious as the dishes themselves. Each bite was delicious, and the overall experience left you feeling happy and fulfilled. Would definitely return!

I've been wanting to try this place for awhile and finally had a chance to get here for dinner with one of my girlfriends. The location is kind of a pain to get to if you're a local and parking in Caesars self park. Be prepared for a long walk. Luckily the wait times were reasonable and the ambiance is sort of trendy and fun.   Now on to the stuff that really matters, the food. We opted to try some shareable items to get the most out of our stomachs. To start we had the beef tartare. Amazing! If I had to recommend any one item here it'd be that! The other food was good, but not in comparison to the tartare.   For dessert we got the milk and cookies which was warm and fresh just like mom would make them. I did wish this was a bit more shareable maybe with two milk glasses instead of just one but that's just me being picky.  I definitely want to come back again soon and try more of the shareable options. I noticed they also do birthday songs & dessert which is nice for birthday party groups.

Love the interior of this restaurant. Gorgeous. I've been to the Las Vegas location twice now and really enjoy it. Also been to the San Diego one.  It's a shame I have never had room for dessert here  last night, I got the ahi tuna. Delicious. Wrapped in prosciutto and had a delicious sauce. The tuna was melt in your mouth good.

We went to Searsucker with a couple of friends of ours and were really impressed by the decor and with Les, the GM. He was extremely nice and was definitely a service-minded host.  We tried and compared a bunch of different dishes, so I'll provide a little overview. Overall, the food was excellent. I definitely have a taste for some things over others, but everything was quality in its presentation.  Cheddar puffers = Mind-blowingly good. "Cowboy caviar" = I don't care what you think. I was also blown away by these. They taste like dark-meat chicken. Buttery rich. Marrow bone = A lot better than I expected. Would have no issue eating this again. Mussels = Very good, and I say that not being a seafood guy. Beef tartare = First time ever trying this. The meat was delicious. The accessories (quail egg, taro chips, etc.) didn't do a lot for me. Hanger "butcher's steak" = I ordered this for myself and after sampling the dishes of everyone else in our group, we all thought mine was the best. Excellent steak all around. Mahi = Not enough flavor, in my opinion. It tasted like your typical sea fish. Salmon = Far from the best salmon I've had. Didn't quite seem tender or flavored enough. Duck = Not sure what I was supposed to expect, but it was pretty rubbery. Fried brussels & walnuts = solid. Nothing extraordinary. Cauliflower = absolutely delicious. Would definitely get this again next time. Doughnuts & chocolate = very tasty. Probably would order differently next time, since I'm not big on dark chocolate sauce, but still good.

Just writing for happy hour.    This was kind of a giggle, my friends and I like to call this our Cheers bar.  You know, where everybody knows your name...lol, see what I did there?  Happy hour is from 400pm to 630pm, everyday.  The happy hour menu is pretty awesome because it includes your usual wells, wines, but for me, what I love is that they have different draft beers on special.  I'm talking $5 drafts on special.  On the Las Vegas strip, that is almost unheard of!  As far as happy hour menu, they have about ten items on special.  My go to is Shishito peppers and duck fat fries.  They just recently changed up the menu and added a few more items.  Last night I tried the pork chips.  It was okay, perfect for when your drinking and the right size portion for complimenting your beer.  For me, too sweet on the pork, but I guess that's to balance the saltiness of the chips.  Staff, always friendly and quick with service.  Service with a smile! Searsucker is awesome!

So overpriced, but what was I expecting?! My girlfriends and I came here because an Omnia promoter told us that we can skip the Calvin Harris line if we ate here. There's an Omnia package on the menu if you eat $75/per person where you can expedite the lines. We opted OUT of that option and just ended up snacking here.  First of all, the shareable appetizers are not shareable. How am I suppose to split ceviche with someone when it comes on one tostada? R u dumb. Skip the beef tartar, skip the $20 crab cake, and just get a bunch of the mussels. Super tasty mussels with andouille sausage. That's the only thing I would come back here for.

Underwhelming, to say the least.  My hubby got 3 oyster shooters and all them had shells in them, not just a few shells (this is expected) but a mouth full of shells.  My wine had something floating in it and the happy hour sliders were so disappointing. The saving grace was the bartender, she was super sweet and genuinely concerned about our visit. All in all, save your money and move on if you're looking for delicious food.
One of, if not the best, burger I have ever eaten. They say they only make 20 each day. Very happy I took advantage.  Great drinks too!

I hadn't been back to Searsucker since the Yelp event in January but when deciding on a location to have dinner with a group of my girlfriends on the night of my birthday it was my top choice. They have some amazing deals for Happy Hour (until 6:30) so those who got there early enjoyed some drinks and apps at the bar. I had a Peter Rabbit which was delicious as always and the other two ladies tried the berry vodka martini (they infuse the vodka in house) and a hibiscus rum daiquiri (refreshing but a bit tart). To eat, we ordered the hush puppies which were a tad too sweet for my taste but pretty delicious as well as the farm bird lollipops which were like hot wings but in meatball form (on a stick); I loved those. Both plates of food were gone right away so we also got some beer nuts to munch on while we waited for the others. Those are pretty darn good for only $2. I did end up also trying the cinnamon mule - I wouldn't recommend this drink unless you REALLY like cinnamon. Just stick with Peter.  Once everyone had arrived and we were seated for dinner the real feast began. Everyone at the table either ordered salads or else small plates to share. My absolute favorite was the squid. That was totally fantastic! It was cooked perfectly with just the right texture and the flavor of the seasoning used was amazing. I also sampled the shrimp and grits, fried brussel sprouts, and corn off the cob. All of them were delectable. Really fantastic food! We ordered the brie triple as well which is supposed to be served with orange and fennel. That sounded quite interesting but instead arrived drenched in hot strawberry jam. No explanation was given but that is not a surprise since our waitress seemed entirely unfamiliar with the menu and couldn't answer any questions about the food. The service in general that night was pretty disappointing. We had to wait too long for drinks to arrive and then there was a weird issue where the busser started clearing away all the dishes before we had even finished and then placed all new silverware in front of everyone even though we were done eating. I don't know what that was about but I really can't stand off timing. All was forgiven, however, when the waitstaff brought out a free chocolate dessert with a candle in it for me and also a round of champagne on the house for all of us!

My experience here was so odd and disappointing.  I was intrigued by the menu and good reviews on Yelp, so stopped in this evening for dinner.  We attempted to have a drink at the bar, but were told for 20 minutes that a waitress would come over and no one came. Whatever, still stayed strong and waited for our table.  We never actually met our waitress, but had the manager wait on us.  He was funny at first, until he basically lied and sold us sides like a dirty used car salesman.  He told us that the potatoes with the short rib and the corn with the scallops was minuscule.  He legit said it was 2 small slices of potato and that we needed to order 3 sides.  Because I didn't think we were at a seedy upwelling restaurant, we trusted him and were incredibly surprised when we received our huge meals (large helping of potatoes, not 2 slices) with no need for 3 $18 sides.  The sides were disappointing and in no way worth the price.  The Mac and cheese was apparently "the best on the strip" and stuffers tastes better.  The food was good, but I cannot get past the unprofessionalism of this establishment.  I felt uncomfortable when he came back to check on us, I told him I was disappointed that he misled us and he just laughed it off and we were later presented with our $350 bill.

We selected Searsucker for a large group dinner and were impressed with the service (they accommodated a last-minute party-size change with a smile), ambiance (cool, but not loud), and food (delicious all around). This is a great option for dinner, especially with a bigger party.

I love Vegas so much  I visit every few months.  Being a foodie, next to NY or ChiTown, Vegas is the next best thing to finding great food.  Yes everything is glamorized and every casino restaurant has a celebrity chef's name attached to it.  I only know Brian Malarkey from The Taste show.  His take on food is creative, yet comforting and not too out there.  Simple well known flavors that are combined and work well.  We only had three different dishes and all were delicious and tasty.  Brie Triple + Strawberry Jam - Not sure what the "triple" means, but you get three crostinin's, a nice size cut of brie topped with jam to even out the flavor and thickness of the brie.  Good starter!  Egg + Bacon (pork belly) -  This a similar take on eggs benedict.  You have a nice toasted piece of bread, layered with slow cooked tender juicy pork belly and topped with a poached egg and gravy.  Every bite was savory and sumptuous.  For our main entree we both had the Loin Filet (yah we are adventurous).  I guess these new age chefs dont like to call it filet mignon any more, but in essence thats what it was.  It was flavorful, tender and a good sized serving for $40.  The lobster butter and mushroom demi gave it that punch it needed to not make it the boring filet mignon served at your favorite steakhouse.  Service was quick and pleasant, but we didnt have the connection with our servers you can feel when they really enjoy their job.    I liked that it was casual and not stuffy, high end.  Nice addition to the vegas scene.
Terrible.. just to say that the toast was BLACK.. and food just overcooked.. terrible experience

The ambiance & food is perfection. We had a view of the kitchen & a clear view of the tv to watch the game. What more can I say than this is THE SPOT. My table had the short rib, mussels, shrimp ceviche, bavette flank, bone marrow, & lion "filet". Not a single frown at this table! Everything was delicious!! Our server was very knowledgeable & so was his assistant. Oh & I can't forget, a round of applause for their dessert menu. We each got one item..BOY! Was this the cherry on top to our experience. Make your reservations because I can see business booming for this hot spot!

I like this spot, it has a good happy hour considering where you are, but it does last until 7 pm which is great for a happy hour. The other Caesar Palace lounges tend to end at 6 pm if they even have one to begin with. I wish they had more vegetarian options on their menu is my only complaint but who wants to go there for food anyway...

Funky menu but one of the only late night options at Ceasar's.  We had the steak tartare which is very good with a raw egg- but not Paris good.  Not too filling either- probably good have doubled the portion.  Service was good but somewhat distracted.  Would I go back? Yes!

Restaurant or competition for the Gap?  One can't really tell by the name.   Slaughter House? Maybe...  Animal Farm-esque animals greet you at the entrance way, yelling, 'EAT!' They are painted in garishly bold colors.  As I walked passed the pig, I was afraid of an uprising.  Walking in the door to this posh restaurant, my suspicions were confirmed.  The decor, while clean and expensive, looks one dimensional on first glance.  As I sat and looked closer, the sweeney todd atmosphere encroached.   The red soaked accent wall by the kitchen stands out as if it were masking the excess blood coming from the fresh meat.  The rope hanging from the lights, posing as lassos, look  morbid and give an eerie feeling of a noose. And the giant painting of the gun handle fork, piercing through a piece of meat, with blood posing as ketchup rains down, definitely turned me off of meat for the night.    I am not a vegetarian but with the fear of an animal take over, I tried to stick to fish and veggies.   We were met by a friendly waiter with a searsucker apron. The service was good and friendly.  The food offered a lot of variety and was described as a collection of American specialties with shrimp and grits, chicken and waffles, scallops, burgers and other various meats.  It may be that I am a bad orderer, but my selections were not something I would go back for. The scallops were wonderful, the donuts were melt in your mouth good, and the duck fat fries were on par. The shrimp and grits were heartburn inducing and the cobb salad had too much going on leaving me unable to fully taste all the flavors or it just lacked a good dressing.   My companions enjoyed their meal and would venture back. I live in Belgium and will stick to my mussels and frites.

Food was amazing & infusion cocktails were unique & wife wanted to try them all.. Parking was a but awkward but I think that was cause of construction..   For opening night the service & food were amazing only can imagine it getting better..   We will be back.. Maybe this weekend!

Good food. Super, super, super slow service. Drinks and food were expensive (very overpriced) but that was expected because it's Vegas. Not sure if I'd come back or not but it was a good time.     P.s if you are with a bridal party and bring your own cake there is a thirty dollar charge.

The first time I came to visit this venue - I was surprised at how quiet it was. There wasn't a lot of traffic at this time. The service was professional - from the time my friend and I sat down until we closed out we were treated as if we were at a 5 star steakhouse. I ordered the Achilles Peel to start - although the drink was more potent than I thought I could still taste the sweet flavor or mixed berry. For an appetizer my friend and I started with an order of crab cakes. The order was smaller than we though and tasted salty - although the garnish on top of the crab cake helped take down our sodium levels. For my entree - I ordered the filet which was super tender and very easy to cut. I wasn't a fan of the sauce that was on top of the filet but the mushroom sauce on the bottom helped with the flavor. For dessert - we ordered the banana bread pudding which was sweet but still crunchy. The server was thoughtful and put Happy Birthday near the bottom of the banana bread. Our overall experience at Searsucker was okay but I would definitely try the place again. It's nice to feel like a VIP on your birthday.

This place comes with a great reputation so it saddens me to have to say anything negative. First I will start with the positive; the food! It really is divine! I had the salmon with Brussels Sprouts and my son had the Filet. Delicious and served in a timely manner. Now for the 'dislike' ...we ate at the bar (it's what I do and what I like) the bar wasn't too busy when we were there..4 guys behind the bar; 2 in the plaid shirts and 2 in the #teammalarkey black tshirts. Appetizer came and no silverware or napkins were delivered. Asked for both, silverware came but no napkins. Asked for napkins and the guy said 'let me go get them we are out of them behind bar' 10 minutes later (I have since grabbed the square drink napkins) we ask a different bartender for napkins...which he walks over behind bar and gets them for us. Other guy had forgotten ..(remember this bar wasn't super packed) Now on to the meal arriving; my son asked for pepper, bartender (same forgetful one) brings us s&p and says 'the pepper is empty let me get more' 10 minutes later and most of our food is consumed we flag a different bartender about the 'empty pepper' he checks it (we didn't since other guy declared it empty) and had a little in it. So at that point we tell the guy what has been happening. He was nice and apologetic. I have to say I am not a complainer but I was shocked at this one certain bartender...too forgetful when people are sitting right in front of you. I haven't had bar service this frustrating in quite awhile. If I had only been drinking I suppose it wouldn't have been noticed. But let's face it, a lot of people eat at the bar and even more so when a happy hour is going on. Again...the food was great and the decor is very neat as well! It is a lot like the one in San Diego which I have eaten at several times and had drinks at often! Never disappointed at that one even at their busiest. I am still giving 4 stars for this review because I can't let one bartender take away from the fact that the food was delicious!

Had dinner at this place. Loved the decor and the drinking cups it's a mixture of classy, relaxed and country not sure how to explain it. The service was good the food was awesome although the shareable tacos were incredibly small. Great dinner menu and not mad prices, located inside the Caesars palace which is great if you're thinking of going to omnia or Fat Tuesday after dinner. Bar was really good and the service was friendly I definitely recommend

Duck fat fries were really good. Grilled cheese and tomato soup was OK. The grilled cheese was good, bread was kinda thick though, the tomato soup was not.  I was really craving a burger and they let me order one even though it  wasn't on the dinner menu...I'm glad they did bc it was a tasty burger!  My husband got the short rib app and mussels. I got to try those as well. Both were done well and very good.  For dessert we opted for the sundae.  Service was great and we had a nice dinner with friends.

This place was pretty good overall. I had some good drinks, my wife had a good drink and one bad drink, and the food was pretty good. Overall for the price, it was a pretty good deal for a restaurant at Caesars Palace.

This place is awesome!!!! Right next to omnia, if you eat here you get Into the club for free. Ordered the pork belly, chicken lollipop wings and short rib. The wings and short rib stole the show!!!! So delicious.

First time diner. Nothing to complain about really. They had a peanut butter and jelly old fashion which was delicious, but everything else we ordered was pretty mediocre.  We asked for our steak sliced and it came cut in half, which I thought was odd but not a big deal.  From what I believe was a manager, came by and dropped off one of our drinks. Didn't say a word just put it on the table smiled and walked away. Which we both thought was a little weird.  And it was extremely loud.  Nothing really stood out, just another spot.  Probably won't return by choice

Definitely returning to this location- best service we received on this trip to Vegas.   Extensive cocktail list, very unique drink options. Our server Chris (wonderful server) recommended the PB and J old fashioned... I don't even typically order them and this cocktail was so delicious and different. (Pictured below garnished with a pb and j sandwich).  Boyfriend order drunken skirt steak- cooked perfectly, tasted delicious (he only let me have a bite :) ). Tender, full of flavor and so juicy!   I ordered the salmon which they do cook to the temperature requested. So nice tender but skin had a perfect crisp.   For appetizer we did order the cornbread muffins with the best tasting butter I ever had and duck fat fries. I'm a Midwesterner so requested ranch with the fries. "All they had was a house made bacon ranch." And the problem is?... it was delicious!   Ordered ice cream sandwiches for dessert with a snickerdoodle cookie. Delicious!   Foods great, amazing service! Wanted to speak with manager to compliment Chris and the staff but we were going to see a show. (I did send an email in case Searsucker does read this). Highly recommend! Will be back again.

Are there any restaurants in Vegas that suck?! My wife and I had the wild boar pasta and the pork butt after starting out with the short rib. Everything was amazing, especially the wold boar pasta and short rib. The short rib is topped with crispy onion strings, which serve as the perfect compliment with the hearty gravy and mashed potatoes. For beverages I went with a mezcal cocktail and the "strawpeno" margarita. Very excellent as well.

Terrible experience.Drove to Vegas to see my dad and let him meet the kids. I insisted on taking him to dinner at my favorite spot in San Diego; searsucker in Las Vegas. What a disappointment; service was below average waiter acted bothered and had attitude when asking questions; ordered the 145 dollar tomahawk that's was not seasoned and they had it sliced into strips and off the bone. Also it looked substantially  smaller than normal and no juice( ordered many times at del mar location) Not to mention the sides came 5 minutes after steak did and rest of dinner came in 5-10 after the steak arrived. About 30/40 minutes for a unseasoned and dry steak. Tomato soup was not hot; somewhere between cold and warm and bacon and egg dish was soggy. Major disappointment for owner who has top chef status. Oh let's not mention my old fashion was half maybe 3/4 filled. Lastly the bell hoy was in our face ever minute to collect dishes and took leftover chicken before I can take home. I spend 350 and waiter took time to add top of 20%. Major disappointment after putting a lot of talk into the dinner leading up to the dinner. Everyone left disappointed.   Update- management did reach out and was very professional and response. For this I raise you a star.

Excellent service!   Food--We ordered 4 small dishes since there are so many yummy choices and also highly recommended by the waiter.  -tuna tartar: excellent dish we might come back just for this. -bacon pork belly: it's served on a piece of toast and topped with a poached egg and hollandaise sauce (egg Benedict style). Overall it's good however we couldn't overlook the fatty layers. -short rib: it's basically s piece of roast beef, served on bed of mashed potato and topped with shredded fried onions. The roast beef is very bland.  -bone marrow: would not recommend this dish. The amount of bone marrow wasn't enough to spread on 4 pieces of baguettes. It's extremely fatty. I'm not sure how to justify the price on bones that otherwise get thrown away. The bed of toast Brussel sprouts were burned.   The habanero coriander pickles are very pickle-y. Pickle lovers would totally enjoy it. Thanks for the free Yelp checkin offer!!  Overall the experience would have been a lot better if we didn't order the fatty dishes (visible fat and running oil). The room temperature was soooo cold that having fat in the palette just didn't work.

A little disappointed. I wanted it to be soo much better, but still ok.  I wouldn't come back though.  Meza grill is a lot better. Don't order the ballerina drink. As for food the chorizo corn off the cob was the best, tasty and spicy. The filet was a too salty, but definitely much better than their Cesar salad. All in all ok, but I'd rather spend my money else where.

Cesar, our server was great so does Efren.  Very attentive!  We're so impressed.  However, the 2 hostesses tonight was !  They seemed to be checking something in the computer but were giggling while we wait to be greeted.  The other male host from Omnia who I thought was a guest was talking to them... I move forward to see what these two hostesses were doing in the computer and they were checking something on line!  While the line builds up!  When the hostess in black felt that I was checking what they were on... She changed the screen to the seating arrangement screen... Busted!!!!  And sat us.  They don't have name tags and we did not bother to ask.  So far food was good especially the crab cake and Mac and cheese!  Again,  just thumbs down on the 2 hostesses.

So disappointed in our visit here recently.  The food was mediocre at best and way overpriced.  The cheddar puffs are a dry, dense copy of Red Lobster's biscuits.  My friend's meal was overcooked, our salads were overdressed, and my entree was bland.  Portions were tiny all around, especially for the price.  We were so disappointed that we spoke to the table next to us about their meal and they echoed our experience.  To top it off, our server was inattentive and somewhat rude and the music was so loud you simply could not hold a conversation.  I won't be back to give it another go; there are plenty of far better options nearby.

I came to Searsucker for the first time for a pre holiday dinner with the family. My eldest brother was a big fan of the location in San Diego and highly recommended it.  The place itself is very well laid out, and the decor and lighting rendered itself as an 'old west' theme mended with more modern architectural design. The theme of rope and wood paired with the old time style light bulbs were a nice combination that were complimented by lots of warm cove lights and well placed accent fixtures. Very relaxing.  One of the first things said was that they were known for their cocktails. Damn you mean to say I have to sample a bunch of drinks? Count me in! My gf and I had the Lieutenant Dan because well, I sure as hell couldn't resist. Probably one of the most refreshing cocktails I have had in a while- not the strongest in the world, but I think if they had loaded it up it wouldn't have been that refreshing. Both of my brothers order the Peter Rabbit- served in a copper cup. The two that were ordered looked a little different. When they noticed they decided to swap and compare the tastes- they were also a bit different. When we told the waiter he explained that all depending on the pour, they can appear different but will often taste the same. When we said they also tasted different, he apologized and bought us a round without batting an eye. We told him he didn't have to do that but he insisted and quickly got us another round on the house. For those who are wondering about the customer service- um....yeah. Either way, I'm not usually a cocktail guy but if you're stopping in here it is certainly going to be a treat to yourself to try some. They won't get you all crunk- but you just may be pleasantly surprised.  The food is one of my favorite styles- American classic. Minimal but hearty plates that you can easily share with others at the table. We began with some starters- I HAD to order the Pork Belly as its one of my favorite cuts, but we also ordered the duck fat fries. The pork belly was some the best I have ever had. It was simple, and all the flavors stood out very nicely. The duck fat fries- well, if you've ever had duck fat fries you already know where I'm going with this but all I will say is if you come here: order these! You will not be disappointed. Entrees- my brother and I decided to share the Duck x 3 and the Tongue and Cheek. Some of the best and most unique cuts of meat- delicious and I highly recommend. My gf decided to get two starters for her entree: the Farm Bird Lollipops, and a 'chicken and waffle' dish that I don't see on the online menu. I only tried the lollipops which were good- but I would suggest getting them as an appetizer (the pork belly and duck beforehand didn't exactly give them their due). All around, the food is delicious. Although some of it may seem 'adventurous', I highly recommend trying something new here if you haven't had it. I think you'll find something you really like.  Overall, this place is great. The cocktails, food and ambiance are top notch. You will notice the four dollar signs on the Yelp profile- a few extra dollars will be spend here. All depending on your budget, I may not suggest Searsucker for a casual meal. However, if you're looking for a special occasion kind of place, or your budget just doesn't matter (I envy you if that's the case), Searsucker will act as a great solution if you're in the Scottsdale area.  Cheers.

Perhaps the kitchen was having an off night but the food in here was proactively bad. Short rib was dry/bland. Ceviche was sad/tired and lacked any citrus punch. Mushroom and buratta was flavorless. The only reason I don't give it 1 star are the brussel sprouts were delicious and the service was pretty friendly...although the server didn't ask why we left the short rib completely uneaten. Overall a huge bummer for what we were expecting.

Very overpriced!!! Food was good but not in any way outstanding. Service was very good but didn't make up for the other negatives. Won't go back. Seriously doubt if this restaurant is still in business a year from now.

Brought my girlfriend here for her birthday. The meal was awesome! My girlfriend is a vegetarian, although I've recently gotten her to try some fish. They made small plates special for her. First was a salad with mixed greens, strawberries, candied walnuts,  and a raspberry vinaigrette...very good. For me they brought the pork belly...delicious!!! 2nd round they unfortunately brought her another salad...not the ideal place for vegetarians I must say, nonetheless, the 2nd salad had figs and goat cheese and greens with a delicious dressing...she said it was excellent, I liked it too! With the delicious, spicy bread balls we had initially, we were already feeling full, so she canceled her main course and we split the tuna. My vegetarian girlfriend loved it! lol I also really enjoyed it! Sushi grade with the skin attached...really tasty! Overall, a great restaurant...highly recommend!

When I first heard that there was a new restaurant from one of the Top Chef contestants, I was very excited.  I'm a huge fan of the show, and everything that they cook always looks amazing!  So, I bought a Living Social deal and was excited to use it.  Then, I both heard and read mixed reviews, and I became a little less excited.  But, I'm very happy to say that I went last night and it was FANTASTIC!  First I must talk about one dish that was quite possibly the best vegetable dish I've ever put in my mouth:  the mushrooms with burrata and toast small plate.  Words cannot express how much my friend and I enjoyed this dish.  It is a small skillet filled with mushrooms that are cooked in something heavenly, and then you pile the mushrooms, burrata, and arugula on top of this perfectly thick, soft, buttery toast.  My only complaint was that there wasn't more toast!  But even that wasn't so bad because I could have just eaten those mushrooms for days.  This was about as flavorful of a dish as I've ever had.  The other fantastic small dish that we had was the chicken and waffle.  I was hesitant at first because the batter was made with Frank's Red Hot Sauce in it, and I am not a fan of hot sauce.  Much to my joy, the dish tasted nothing like hot sauce but just had a fantastic depth of flavor.  I am from the south, and I am not sorry to admit that this was my first chicken and waffle!  I hope they're all like this!  Also, it did not say on the menu, but I believe the chicken was stuffed with maybe ham or proscuitto and some sort of cheese.  It was delicious.  Our last small plate was the scallop with bacon and caramel.  This was the one that we were most excited about, but it turned out to be somewhat disappointing.  After the other two, we were expecting to be amazed again, and we were not.  It was good, but, I will probably not order it again, whereas I will be returning as soon as I can for the other two dishes.    To top it all off, they give you these fantastic cheese biscuits when you arrive.  They are vey moist and flavorful and a great way to start the meal.  I only have two things to complain about, one of which was my fault.  I ordered the $12 La Primavera cocktail, and it was awful.  It is made with berry vodka, St. Germain, and Campari.  I love St. Germain and vodka, so I ordered this, not knowing what Campari is.  Well, it's a bitters, and, man, was this drink bitter!  I hate sending things back, but I had to send this back.  I can't imagine that anyone would like that, but, I guess if you're a fan of bitters, you might.  Our server was nice enough to take it off my tab, but that was about his only redeeming quality.  He wasn't a jerk or anything, but he wasn't particularly friendly either.  Also, we hardly ever saw him.  The restaurant was not anywhere near packed on a Wednesday night, but, for whatever reason, we saw everyone else who worked there a whole lot more often than our server.  The table next to him even had to ask another server to hunt him down at one point.  Having said that, though, it certainly wasn't bad enough that I wouldn't return.  Overall, both my friend and I were extremely pleased with our experience.  We left raving about the food and were just full enough but not disgustingly full after 3 small plates and cheese biscuits.  I will be going back soon, and I only hope that their other dishes are as good as these!

I expected better, Searsucker!!  We came for dinner on a Sunday and ordered 3 appetizers, and 3 entrees over four people. The service was good, and our server seemed to know a lot about the menu and recommended some dishes that we ended up ordering.  Here's my report: crab cake jumbo lump + fennel + aioli - delicious  short rib "the harlot" + horseradish + fried onion - probably the highlight of the meal artichoke hearts + cheddar + mozzarella - this was a dip with poor execution - this is why. They gave us a very large portion of this cheesy dip with three pieces of bread. When we asked for more bread (more than half the dip left with no toast) we were told that they would have to charge us for it. pork butt - standard, nothing special butcher steak - did not try this, however the presentation was nice.  Sorry, but when you're spending $200+ on a meal I'd expect to receive a sufficient amount of bread to go with my dip.   Return Factor: None.

Dined here on a Saturday night for a party of six and had a great time. Drinks were tasty and refreshing. My favorite was the strawberry jalape√±o margarita. Our server was very knowledgeable and suggested some scrumptious dishes. For starters, our table had two orders of the following: bone marrow, calamari steak and duck fat fries. For the main course we had the 36 oz Tomahawk ribeye with saut√©ed mushroom side, New York Steak with corn jalape√±o, two orders of fish and chips, braised pork, grilled cheese and tomato soup for the kids. Everything was delicious but the Tomahawk was a tad too salty and cooked Medium rather than the Medium-rare we preferred.  The star of the meal was the bone marrow. We all agreed that the next time we come back we will just order ten of those bone marrow! We were too full to try any desserts. Our server gave us chips for free expedited access to Omnia. It was a busy night for Omnia being it was its two-year anniversary and Kaskade as the main dj but we did not have any problem getting in. I'm already planning on coming back when we go to Vegas again next month.

Incredibly bad service. Took 3 hours from when we sat down till they finally figured out our bill. The manager was busy flirty with all off the waitstaff. The entire serving staff was talking and not paying attention to our table. I had to go to the bar on several occasions to get our drinks.   At the end of the meal our server took 45 minutes. ( not exaggerating) to get the ticket right. I was added items that I did not order. Finally after asking the manager to fix the error I paid 20 bucks extra in cash just to leave.   Food was not worth all the hassle. Plenty of options I would stay clear until they fix the service. Ruined the night.

I wouldn't even waste money to go there again. The food is pretty horrible. I got a salmon and it was that worst I had in a long time. The location I would say is nice and inviting but that's pretty much it

My daughter brought me here after having attended a yelp event. I had the lobster roll and added the fries. The bread on the lobster roll is the best! It is just like you get back east and was perfectly toasted. The whole sandwhich was really great and the salad that comes with it had just the right amount of balsamic. The brown sugar butter sauce that comes with the fries is really tasty. I also had the lemon bar and fruit for dessert. It had lots of great flavor without being overpowering.   What really stood out was our server. Allard was so helpful and nice. He brought us a dinner menu since I wanted to come back and try more and aswered all the questions I had about what was on it. He really took time to help us and kept our drinks full and was very sweet. I can't wait to go back and try more. It was all so good!

Great food and atmosphere! My new favorite weekend brunch spot. The 'boring' breakfast was amazing. Maple bacon, potatoes were to die for, and everything was prepared perfectly. They also have live music and bottomless mimosas. My friends and I had fantastic service when we were here for brunch.   I have also been here for dinner- dinner was definitely on the pricy side but they have good deals during happy hour. The one time I was here during happy hour I was disappointed by the service at the bar (happy hour is only in the bar area) but the other times I've visited the service has been great.

This is the best new restaurant in Vegas!  It's also a rarity being an eating establishment on the Strip that has a Happy Hour!  We went to Happy Hour after reading the great reviews.  We were not disappointed at all.    The food we ate was tremendous.  The crab cake was as good as we have ever had, be in Boston or Baltimore.  The shrimp and grits, while advertised as spicy, is not spicy enough to keep my wife's delicate palate from loving it!  The strawberry champagne salad is unique and superb!  As other people have stated, the portions are better than most Happy Hour foods.  We finished the meal off with the pumpkin dessert, very good.    What so many restauranteurs don't realize is that a good Happy Hour draws people in to sample your food, service, and cocktails.  If you pass that step, then you have customers who are coming back regardless of being Happy Hour or not. That is us.  We will come back for the pork butt, the filet, the salmon entree, the mahi, the scallops, etc.  The prices on those dishes aren't outrageous.  They aren't the best, but if you have dined on the Strip, you know you are paying top dollar.  At least here you get fantastic, friendly service and exceptional food.    FWIW, I've owned a restaurant, been a general manager, a bar manager, a bartender, and a waitperson, oh, and along with a dish washer.  I am judging this eatery on one visit, but boy, it was an unbelievably exceptional visit.    We will be back!  Oh, forgot to mention a pet peeve of mine they overcame.  Sitting at the bar, Searsucker had more than one person wait on you, EVEN ask you if you want another drink or some more water!  What mattered to them was if you had good service, not whether a certain bartender waited on you.  Good job, Searsucker!

Fantastic food, great atmosphere.   Went for Restaurant Week so didn't get to experience the whole menu (Not a big deal, really my only complaint is that I was really looking forward to some bone marrow which they did not have on the event menu)  Started with Whiskey (as one does) then ordered Chicken Lollipops and Shrimp in bacon grits - Shrimp was great, Grits were amazing (I fully recommend ordering them as a side)   We then had the Crab topped Ono with horseradish and chimichurri and a perfectly medium rare filet with lobster butter as well as sides of brussel sprouts in walnuts and buttered potato (just think decedent mashed potatoes)  Both entrees were delicious but if I had to choose just one (which would be hard) I'd go with the beef - it was melt in your mouth perfect.  Topped it all off with red velvet cake and chocolate mousse while we polished off the bottle of wine and a perfect night out.  I'll definitely be going back again.

Went there yesterday for lunch. Not at all impressed with the food.  Portions were very small.  I am a small eater and ususally get filled up quickly.  But I left there yesterday still a bit hungry.  Nice salad of lettuce and strips of poultry.  Our menu said there were meatballs being served.  The meatballs consisted of just a couple bowls of them on a table which probably sat 15-18 people.  They were bite sized and most people got just 1 and some did not get any.  We were waiting for them to bring more out but instead they came back with the dessert.  A tiny, probably 1.5-2 inch square of red devil sponge cake.  No soft drinks, etc, only water was served.  I had been considering to go back some day for HH but at the size of servings I would probably have to order 5 of the HH menu. I had hoped that I would really like this place, but alas no.
Ahhhmazing food great service accommodated a large group of friends for his bachelor party great place to have dinner while in LV and waiting to get into Ominia

I don't know what the hype is all about. I wasn't impressed.   A. the location is awkward. Walk inside this weird building and then walk through a second set of doors to get to actual restaurant. It's slightly off the beaten path so it's not somewhere I would go for night-cap drinks.   B. Granted I was only there for happy hour with some friends, I just wasn't impressed with the food. I think it's overpriced for what it is. You can get a better meal at Citizen or Cowboy Ciao. Maybe I had too high of expectations. But isn't this supposed to be a Top Chef restaurant? The one in San Diego is supposedly amazing. I was really excited...and then I was let down. It's like when you're really hungry and you eat something and it just wasn't satisfying but you're full and can't eat anymore. We ordered a bunch of different things: shrimp and grits, meatballs, scallops, tacos, and some other stuff. Wait, did I say scallops? I mean SCALLOP. Singular. It was one. For like $10 or something like. It was good. But overpriced. The tacos were shortrib and they were just whatever. The meatballs were good. The shrimp and grits were whatever. They're better at Cowboy Ciao.   The drinks were just whatever too. I ordered the Peter Rabbit. That was good. But I wasn't sure there was booze in it. I ordered another drink and it wasn't great. It was meh.   C. The decor is awesome. I love how it's decorated. It's def cute. But those damn barstools at the little tables in the bar area are awful. Sitting on hard wood with no back support is not enjoyable. I wish we could've sat in those comfy looking couches. If that were the case, I'd probs sit there and booze it up for awhile.   I'll give it another shot and actually have a full dinner to see if things are different. But as of now, I'm just not impressed. Step up your game Searsucker.

Food was ok I was hoping it would be the same as the sear sucker  in San Diego but the food was just bland . The squid was good though just too saucy for me . We also had the duck fat fries nothing special , tuna albacore and spinach salad. This place is next to the omnia night club.

Seersucker is a case of "just fine" food in a great location. They're in a prime Caesar's location and offer (for Ceasars) pretty reasonable prices.   We made a reservation and I'd advise you to do that, since Searsucker seems rather popular. It's a good sized space with modern furniture and a menu that encourages sharing. We started with corn muffins ($5) and hot damn!!! these are some tasty bites - a bit spicy, full of bacon and served with sweet butter. Yum!   For dinner, I had a Cobb salad ($16?) which was ok - I asked for dressing in the side and never revived any at all. See: service, below.  My dining companions opted for more meaty choices and seemed happy. Our side of mac''cheese ($16) was overly salty but used wagon wheel pasta which made me happy.   Service...yeah, not the best. Our server was honestly kind of bitchy for no reason. I didn't get a side of salad dressing and didn't want to ask because she was attitude-y Judy & I didn't want spit infused ranch. I'm guessing with a different server this place would be 4 for me.
Really enjoy this place for business lunch. Great burger and good prices. 100% quality.
Nice selection of small plates and cocktails. The service was great, and we enjoyed our meal. I definitely will come back on my next Vegas trip!

Not worth the money at all! Their options of small plates are pretty limited but the dumbfounded aspect is finding out the grilled chicken addition to our salad was more expensive than the actual salad. It was $15 while the salad alone was $12. I wish the server told us prior rather than us finding out on the bill.

Interesting and fun but not quite delivering the goods for the price.  My wife and I stopped in for happy hour the other night to check out the new place in town.  We arrived around 5:30 and there were perhaps 20 people in the bar and restaurant.  We sat at the bar and ordered five appetizers and some drinks.  We tried some of their signature drinks and thought they were pretty tasty.  We liked all the appetizers, although they tended to be on the small side with the exception of the squid, which was a standard portion size.    The atmosphere is modern, hip and fun although I have to say it seems to be trying a bit too hard in certain respects.  I like a modern eclectic feel as much as the next guy, but sometimes they're a bit too creative for their own good here.  For example, instead of a napkin, you get a kind of quilted kitchen towel.  Sure, why not, but we're veering into the realm of the twee and the forced with this kind of thing.  The bar stools however seem to have been designed by the Marquis de Sade.  They are literally the most uncomfortable bar stools I have ever sat in.  They're a kind of rippled, heavy western style wood with no back. So you've got no support for your back and, worse, the wood cuts sharply into your thigh.  Looking around the bar, virtually every single person at the bar was standing next to their seat.    The bar began to fill up with single women and seemed to maintain a roughly 8:1 ratio of women to men, a phenomena I've noticed at other high-end joints in town.  The bartenders were very friendly as were the other patrons.  Final verdict?  Mixed.  In a town where every restaurant serves the same comfort food classics, it is definitely encouraging to see somebody dare to serve something other than cheeseburgers and the like.  On the other hand, the portions were really a bit skimpy, even at Happy Hour prices.  Five appetizers later, we were still a bit hungry and that's not really so happy.  (Try eating five appetizers at Wildfish or Rokerij. Go ahead, I dare you.)  There's a certain Scottsdale bimbo quality to the place (and I'm not talking about the clientele).  It looks great but it's not terribly comfortable and in the end, you may not be quite as satisfied as you thought.  Five appetizers, two cocktails, a wine and a beer were $50 bucks plus tip.  NOTE TO MANAGEMENT: Change the damn bar stools already!

First time- Great wine and food. I didn't take pictures of the apps but I highly suggest the. Calamari steak and duck fat fries. I had the 6oz filet medium rare and it was come to perfection. The creamy kale added to the flavor, which a happy mouth. My friends 2lb lobster was fabulous. It was juicy and easy to open up and eat.

A large group of us came here for dinner a few weeks ago. First off, our waitress (I believe her name is Lindsey - shorter and blond?) was wonderful!! She knew the whole menu, and she never missed a beat with our group.  Drinks: When Doves Cry - Two thumbs up Snake in the Grass - meh. Too sweet, it didn't taste like it had any alcohol in it. We had a taste of a syrah that was just terrible. Maybe it had been open too long, or maybe the wine was just that bad.  We had more cocktails and quite a few wines, but I don't remember enough about them to post anything.  Food: Braised Pork Butt - Tasty, more than enough food by itself! Scallops - Great, definitely worth ordering Bigeye Tuna - Very good, though it could have used a little more flavor to kick it up a notch Tacos - looked good but were itty bitty. Some of the smallest tacos I have ever seen. The warm spinach salad looked a little on the small side too. Though spinach really shrinks up with heat so maybe that is why.  Also, for those wondering...the things listed under 'Jars and Sliced' literally come in a jar. Not great if you are sharing, but fun if it is just for you.  Overall, a great option for dinner close to the strip!

Inside Caesars, you find this gem. Loved the decor! We all shared the huge (36oz) and amazing tomahawk steak - feed 6 people. Mac n cheese was bomb! Brussel sprouts and walnuts delish!  Service was good. You won't be disappointed with the food. Only gripe is that we could only do the happy hour drinks at the bar, not offered 5-7pm in dinning room.

This is the first time in Vegas and we arrived late to our hotel (Ceasar's). The searsucker was one of the only restaurants open at the time; the ambiance appeared nice from the outside, so we have it a shot. 1st look at menu revealed extremely high prices ($46 for fish and chips!). Our experience was that food was average at best and not worth the cost. Duck fat fries, which we were told was one of the specialties, was not savory. The best appetizer was the steak calamari. The best part of our experience at this restaurant was service; our waitress was outstanding, attentive, and very friendly. Also, food arrived fast. Overall, we felt food was not worth cost, and being from NYC, I am somewhat accustomed to pricey places but expect quality in return!
The pork butt was so moist and delicious, with the apple slaw on top it set it off. The Brussels sprouts were under cooked and did not have good flavor. The duck fat fries were amazing!

Very spacious and a very attentive wait staff (probably because there were only 4 tables seated at the time so with 2 managers, a few hostesses and multiple busboys and waitresses the service should be good).  Food was pretty good. The spicy pickle was excellent as were the sidedishes. The entrees and dessert were a little of a let down. Another negative is that while they do have some decent local beers available with their menu they could do a much better job at having a larger beer selection and they should include some Belgian beers like a wit or triple to go with the seafood.  Expect to spend at least $60 per person as everything is ala carte.

I was soo happy to make it this restaurant for dinner on Saturday... We missed our original reservation and had to change it several times that night... Luckily, we made it to the restaurant at 11:40pm and made it for the "late night" menu..  Everything we ordered was bomb, with the exception of one dish...   Need to order: duck fat fries + tomato jam,  "Caesar" romaine + kale + egg + parm, and short rib "the harlot" + horseradish + fried.. ALL TASTY AND YUMMY!!  One dish that was not on the "late night" menu was-- beet + radish + cr√®me fra√Æche + goat cheese WHICH the kitchen was able to make for us-- AWESOME!! VERY YUMMY!!  Dessert to order: S'mores Bar--  Graham + salted caramel ganache + honey  chocolate mousse + marshmallow + chocolate ice cream + cookie crumble... ABSOLUTELY SCRUMPTIOUS!!   I was disappointed about the-- farm bird lollipops + hot sauce + bleu.  I can handle spicy, but this was soo spicy I couldn't enjoy it.  We didn't ask for it to be taken off the bill, but the waitress should've asked when she noticed we didn't like it when only of the lollipops were missing from the dish (which was on my plate) when we asked her to take it away.    Other than that, our overall experience was great!!  I live in southern California and totally looking forward to visiting the San Diego location in the near future...

Had such an AMAZING dinner! The food was fantastic, ambiance was great and our server Chris made our experience. He was so helpful and gave great recommendations. Would definitely recommend the calamari, NY steak, and SCALLOPS. The craft cocktails were really tasty. Can't wait to try other locations. Will be back for sure!

One of the many, many places just around the corner within the giant maze that is Caesars.  Went here for happy hour.  Had about six small plates.  The spicy shrimp ceviche was excellent.  The artichoke heart cheese dip was not good (the artichoke hearts were tough).  The mushrooms were a little dry.  The duck fat dipped fries were nice and the ketchup had a little kick in it which was nice.  The shrimp remoulade was pretty tangy.  Overall, a nice place to get a bite right after work.  And our server was named Caesar; although I suspect they are all named Caesar.

What a great food!!!! OMG! We ordered so many things of the menu and absolutely everything was top notch. And what a cute waiter...^^ Also, if a person spends $50 you get a no line chip to get to OMNIA. Good deal for this amazing food and drinks!
We had a group of 10 and the food was incredible. The service was good but not great.

I had the Cobb with honey mustard dressing and it was fantastic and the ginger smash was perfect.  I watched a few people order happy hour items that all looked great!   Service (mine was Philip) was laid back not too slow but not all up in your business either.  I would come back.

The wife and I dined at Searsucker on a Sunday night.  We had no problem getting a table for two at 7:30.  We started off with a round of drinks.  Searsucker's cocktails and house-made infusions were solid.  I had the Kinda Old Fashioned ($18) made with Jack Single Barrel whiskey, Montenegro Amaro, Ancho Reyes liqueur, sweet vermouth, old fashioned syrup, and bitters.  It was boozy and bitter with the right amount of sweetness.  The wife's Jalaberry Strawpeno ($13) was a jalapeno and strawberry infused tequila with lime and agave.  It was a nice, fresh take on a margarita.  For our food, we shared orders of the Blistered Shishito Peppers ($11), Calamari Steak ($16), and Fish & Chips ($42).  All of the dishes were tasted good to outstanding.  The Fish & Chips, a beautifully presented fried whole branzino with waffle cut, sweet potato chips, was excellent, but I felt a bit overpriced.  The Blistered Shishito Peppers were the closest thing to a miss for me.  They were blistered, but possessed a wilted texture that seemed like they were more steamed than roasted over a fire or in a hot skillet.  However, the Calamari Steak, thick cuts of calamari deep fried to a perfect fork tenderness and topped with a chili honey glaze, was the standout dish and the best fried calamari dish I've ever had.  Searsucker was a pleasant surprise.  Frankly, given the lineup of celebrity chef-driven restaurants in Las Vegas, let alone in Caesars Palace, Searsucker seemed to me to be somewhat of an afterthought, a backup plan restaurant choice.  Searsucker deserves better than that as they're easily Caesars' best bet for tasty comfort food.

Went with a large party and had the chance to try tons of small plates. The pork belly appetizer is a stand-out item. We also had the shrimp and grits (good), squid (ok), tuna himachi (heard it was good, don't like sushi), and crab cake (very good). I got the scallops with cous cous. The scallops were perfectly cooked and a decent size. Tried the corn off the cob which was good not awesome, but good. I was stuffed by the end of the meal. Perrier Jouet sold by the glass made this place even better!

I am blown away! I loved Searsucker . . . but I have to admit that I thought it was a bad location from the very beginning. But, of course, no one asked me . . . so I kept my mouth shut  . . . well, except when I was enjoying a Peter Rabbit (no ice please!). My fingers are crossed that Brian will reopen in a much better location in Scottsdale. Please, please, please.

I had previously visited the San Diego location last year and declared the Peter Rabbit to be the best cocktail I have ever tried in my life!  I was excited to see that they built an outpost right in my backyard on Camelback, so my boyfriend and I went last Saturday night for an impromtu date night.  The atmosphere was more open than the Diego location, and it seemed more spacious.  It was DEFINITELY easier to get a dinner reservation too!  We checked in for our 8:30 and cozied up to the bar for my old love Peter.  The bar manager was incredibly attentive and when I told him about my love affair with Peter, even poured me a sample of his favorite cocktail "The Health Food" which had Pimm's cup and celery, among other things.  It was so good, my boyfriend ordered one once we were sat for dinner.  Definitely A+ for the bar manager, you could really tell he was proud of his establishment and excited about helping us discover new boozey treasures.    The ambiance of the restaurant is definitely trendy, and a little on the louder side, but I knew this going in and it was what I expected.  It would make a fun place for a group dinner, a girls night out, or an excuse to put on a black dress and heels for date night.  We wound up deciding to order all small plates, because we were in that kind of noshing mood.  The complementary cheddar puff biscuit things were good, but not as good as I remembered in Diego.  Perhaps because they were cold?  A little salty?  I don't know, we still ate them, and I do appreciate a departure from the normal boring bread basket so I'll take this any day.  We started with the shishito peppers, which were good, but to my disappointment, they were lacking any kind of heat.  My favorite part about ordering shishitos is getting that occasional renegade one like a game of russian roulette for your mouth!  They were about as spicy as a bell pepper, and our busser actually told us that they had to briefly take them off the menu because customers were complaining that they were too spicy.  How annoying!  Jesus people, don't order peppers if you don't like spicy things, and thanks for ruining it for the rest of us!  We also ordered the marrow, which I have never tried anywhere before.  I am adventurous so this wasn't a problem, and I found it to be absolutely delicious, once you get past the part that you are actually scooping out marrow from humongous bones.  It was a delicacy, rich, flavorful, and one of the highlights of our meal.  We tried the pork belly, which was nice, but I have had better.  I would have liked it to be rendered more, maybe a little more flavor.  It did, indeed remind me of breakfast since it was served with an egg and I think I would order it again for brunch.  Four our last tasting we had the spicy shrimp and grits and the jalapeno corn which were both delicious.  We were too full to attempt dessert.  I will definitely recommend this place to friends and I am excited to come back.  We even ran into the owner Brian while we were here.  Welcome to the neighborhood Searsucker!  You will fit right in!

Spend $50 or more and it gets you into the omini no line.  Tapas: Crab cakes: too salty, fishy & the crust was soggy. Strawberry pecan salad: over priced Habinero  Pepper & pickles: too briny with a kick of spice. Bone marrow: nothing special, fatty oily marrow with onion jam over two tiny pieces of toast.  But getting into the club without waiting was nice.

This is by far my favorite meal in Vegas! Take my advice, and go to this place around 5-6pm. They have a great happy hour menu.  I've had a lot of burgers in my life, and this HAS to be the best I've had. Upgrade to the duck fat fries for a dollar, trust me you won't regret that extra dollar.  This place is A++ in my book and would highly recommend it. For you whiskey drinkers, get the "Bad Bad." All in all, this place is fairly pricey, but if you go during the happy hour menu, you won't pay through the nose for a fantastic meal.

After finding several bars downtown were closed for New Year's day, we went back to the strip for happy hour.  Searsucker is a southern influenced gastropub, with a really great happy hour featuring $9 Old-fashioneds and $2 oysters (not just the standard bluepoints everyone is giving you nowadays.) We also had sliders and bone marrow ($2 per bone at happy hour.)  The star of the visit was the fried pigs ear. They are cut into small strips, marinated for hours and then lightly fried, for a more delicate texture than you're expecting. They are deliciously salty with an appropriate hit of tartness.   The oysters come prepared with a mignonette of micro mint and pomegranate. Each oyster rests on a thick salt bed, which we viewed as a little fussy. I also took off the mint leaves as they interfered with the oyster flavor. The pomegranate, on the other hand, is a great pairing.  The old-fashioneds were prepared classically and well-balanced. This is definitely the best choice for happy hour in Caesar's Palace and perhaps the entire Strip.

Every time I drive by this building, I look to see my car in the third story windows. Architects are cool.  Malarkey says visiting Arizonans encouraged him to open a branch here. Putting the daily operations into the hands of chef Steven "Chops" Smith, 37, who seems to have worked in every local kitchen, including Different Pointe of View, Olive & Ivy, Noca, Furio, Luc's and St. Francis.  Cooking style is divided into categories as Bites, Smalls, Greens, Ocean, Ranch and Farm. Having visited the San Diego "Gas Lamp" store, I was also impressed at the Scottsdale location which reminds me of an awesome bachelor pad.  Looks like from what I remember, Searsucker Scottsdale pretty much duplicated the menu and design of the Diego mother ship. But after a while I would expect Smith to put his own stamp on the menu.  In California I learned to enjoy stout from a beer knowledgeable gal at the tap room. So I see Karl Strauss Imperial Stout on the menu and since I have been to Karl's I go for it. It pours black. Coffee dominates with some cocoa and roasted malts. Taste is very smooth. $12 for the bomber, a 22 oz.  From the ranch I order the hanger "butcher's steak" with watercress, bbq, and blue fondue  $26. One of my favorite meals.

Happy Hour review:  I came here for Happy Hour. To drink, I got the bad bad t-roy brown. I don't typically order cocktails but I really liked this one. I ordered two. The first one was great. The second was good but it didn't seem like it was muddled/mixed well enough. I also ordered the potato fries, pork chips and short rib sandwich. The portions were much bigger than I expected. Everything was good. The potato fries were great. I liked the chipotle ketchup. The short rib in the short rib sandwich was good. I think the bread was a bit too thick so it wasn't balanced. I ended up picking out some of the meat and the onions. The pork chips were good but I thought the sauce was just a tad too sweet. I think Seersucker is a solid choice for Happy Hour.
This is a must eat place!!! Everything was perfection! Delicious!!!  Do it! You'll thank me later I promise
Got the roasted chicken and it was very dry. Was disappointed for how much it cost! Also our server was very snoody!

We took a group of ten and ordered virtually every appetizer on the menu. The cauliflower, macaroni, fig toast, hummus, and brussels spouts were pretty good. I wasn't a fan of the bone marrow or pigs ears (though the guy sitting to my left was). The caprese was ok (my wife really liked it, though). The bread part of the caprese was burnt and too hard in my opinion.   If all we'd gotten were appetizers and it hadn't taken 30 minutes to get them, it would be a four-star review.   However, and just speaking for my main course, it was nasty. The waiter did a good job selling me on the special--a portion of the 75 lb. pig they'd just roasted. They brought me a pile of pork, yes, but it was cold and very grisly. I couldn't eat more than a couple of pieces. Very disappointing.   The atmosphere was also very loud, and although the waiter knows the menu well, he spoke too fast and in a rote fashion--clearly a result of having repeated the same thing too many times, so between that and the loud background (music in addition to other people), we had to ask him to repeat himself several times.   I guess when you spend over $800 on a meal, you expect the food and service to be excellent.

Wow, this place is awful.   The atmosphere screams tacky sports bar. The whole place feels as if you're sitting in a food court with giant flat screens everywhere, including the cheap furniture and uncomfortable chairs. Poorly lit and loud.   And this is the sort of place where the servers try to jack up the bill as high as they can. You know, where they ask if you would like water and then charge you $9 for a bottle of Fiji without asking you. Or letting you order a $10 side of fries with an entree that already comes with french fries. As if the $65 steak entrees weren't over-priced enough.   The service timing is horrible, too. Despite the prices, this is NOT fine dining by any stretch of the imagination. These folks have no idea what they are doing when it comes to service.   And to top it all off, the food is bland and overly salty. Horrible. The $18 rib starter that we had was so dreadful that we scaled back our entire dinner plans and decided less would definitely be the theme of the evening.   The wine list is equally pretentious and over-priced. $125 for wine that retails for $15 at the grocery store. Other mediocre bottles that are priced in the $600(!?!?!) range. Please.  If you have very little experience with fine dining, you might mistake expensive for quality. Don't be fooled. Michelin is not going to be calling these folks anytime soon.

Best thing to order here is the bone marrow, well flavored with brussel sprouts and butter that along with the marrow, melts in your mouth.  The lollipop wings were good, chocolate sammies were delicious, duck fat fries were overly seasoned with not even a hint of duck fat taste, but the worst item I had was the braised pork butt.  The pork butt had no flavor besides the pickled tower laid on top.  It was confusing, the pickled vegetables dominated the flavor of the meat, not even letting the true taste exude through the anticipated braised flavor.  Even the smell of the pork had no inviting aroma, very bland.  Staff (such as our server, Cesar who was nice enough to have the pork butt and fries removed from our bill due to our dissatisfaction) and service were excellent, but the braised pork butt...was a bunch of "malarkey."
The staff was the best we had all week in Vegas! Great for watching March Madness games & the food was delicious!

Came here for the grand opening. I only sampled some of the passed hors d'oeuvres but they were all pretty tasty. The one that stood out the most was the beet scallop. The atmosphere is inviting, sexy, hip, and just straight up cool. The space is large but not too large. I am not a fan of big restaurants because they just remind me of chains like Chili's, Cheesecake Factory, etc etc. The drinks are amazing too. I look forward to having a real dinner here soon! I really think this is going to be the new "it" spot in scottsdale!
Mixed drinks are expensive but go for the Happy Hour and get the Bone Marrow (only twenty bucks) and DELICIOUS. Servers are very kind and the food was very good.

Definitely not worth the money.... food was cold  and awful I had the drunkenskirt steak..salty and undercooked I asked for med well and got med rare. Fries were awful as well. My husband had the Thanksgiving meal it was just ok but definitely not worth $49....at best I wud say $19.99. The service was less than stellar. Had to ask for stuff a minimum of 3 times before I got it. Needless to say won't be going back?

Came here after a nice day at the pool and my experience was amazing! Lindsey my waitress was so helpful and made great recommendations. I had the Duck which was out of this world! From the ambiance to the service to the food Searsucker Las Vegas is amazing!

Ugh, where do I start.   Went here as it seemed to be one of the more decently priced and more interesting places on the strip. Unfortunately it kinda sucked. Not the food but just about everything else.   There was a short wait for a table so we were offered a high top or the seats facing the casino floor if we wanted to be seated immediately. I like people watching so facing out was a great place to sit. We ordered the hamachi and jalape√±o plate to start along with a couple of beers. The beers took a little bit longer than they should, but the amount of time the hamachi took was appalling. The insulting part was that this dish definitely fits the description of a small plate, it was basically 3 crisps with a slice of the hamachi and vegetables/sauce. The dish itself was great, the cucumbers and jalape√±o  worked so well with the fish, tasted incredible. But for what amounts to 3 chips with a slice of fish on them to take over 20 minutes to prepare was pretty bad.   We had also ordered the Ono and a beet salad with goat cheese. The only odd request we had was for the goat cheese to come on the side which isn't a substitution or anything out of line. When the runner came out with them the goat cheese was breaded (not indicated on the menu) and mixed in with the salad. We politely sent it back and requested the goat cheese on the side and not breaded, and some silverware. Our waitress then came back with the salad sans goat cheese. She said she would get some for us and also offered to get some silverware. After waiting several more minutes I just turned around and asked the bartender for silverware. My Ono was no longer warm enough but it was very good.   Unfortunately lack of staff communication and attentiveness ruined this place for me. This is too bad as the food was awesome.
Good location inside of Caesars Palace, next to Omina night club, New style of American cuisine, food size big .

Long story short: how many times have you sat at home watching the Food Network or some cooking show on TV and thought 'wow that looks interesting' and wished you could try it yourself?    Some of the menu options and flavor combinations are definitely different and might intimidate those who like to play it safe but hey, youre in Vegas! Get out of your comfort zone, be adventurous, try something new! We tried a little bit of everything and it was all good.  No room for dessert.

I can't say enough about our dining experience at Searsucker! The staff was absolutely amazing- friendly, funny, knowledgable, and extremely attentive. The food was out of this world good. I opted to get a few starters as my meal because I just couldn't decide on what to get. The cocktails are equally as delicious as the food.   When we were planning our trip, this was one of my top choices, and it didn't disappoint. We started with the shishito peppers, which I would highly recommend. I got the bacon and eggs and the brussel sprouts. My husband got a steak and asparagus. He's a picky eater and not easy to please, and nearly a week later, he is still talking about how great the food was. We shared the cookies and milk for dessert, and it was such a fun, cozy way to end a fantastic meal.  The open kitchen only adds to the experience. You can see, hear, and smell your food being prepared, and it's such a treat.   I can't wait to come back!
Cheddar Puffers.  Duck Fat Fries. Mushrooms + Burrata + Toast. Crab Cake Jumbo Lump. Pork Butt. Cookies & Milk.  Fun D√©cor + Delicious Food = Happy Camper. :)

Wonderful experience. I loved everything we ordered from the shrimp and grits to the "drunken" opha fish. Don't miss the jalapeno-corn side dish. The cocktails are very imaginative - I tried their take on a pimms cup. The atmosphere here is very hip, loungy and dark. Our bartender was a little obsessed with another couple and it required us waving him down each time we needed something, but I'm sure service at the tables is better.

This restaurant was a good size and well decor with cool lights.   Bacon eggs (4/5)  Bone marrow (5/5) - I wish there was more bone marrow Mexican shrimps (4/5)  Mac and cheese (3/5) - the mac was not as soft as I like Calamari steak (5/5)  Bread pudding (4/5) Cookie ice cream (4/5)   Overall, great food and nice ambiance. I think the appetizers and shared plates section had better food choices than the main entrees. I definitely would come Back

I recently went to Searsucker with some work friends and it was great time! The food was great, the service was great and the atmosphere was fun!   The best way to describe the food here is that is something that you will recognize. It's not like some of the other Las Vegas restaurants where you have no idea what the dish consists of. We just ordered a bunch of different plates and shared. The Calamari steak was great! Sweet and tangy and cooked just right! We ordered the Chef's salad and the field greens and pear salad. Very simple salads, with the right flavor. The entrees were the NY Strip, scallops and scampi. The Scampi stood out because it was large, grilled prawns on a bed of squash spaghetti. Never had squash spaghetti before and that was pretty good! Light and overwhelming but a very pleasant flavor. Scallops were awesome! Not much more to say. The NY strip was cooked just right and came with a red wine sauce. All in all a great set of entrees. Desert was warm cookies and cold milk! An old classic but still delicious! The deconstructed key lime pie was my highlight of the night. Didn't expect much from it but it was an amazing flavor (Does come with coconut)!  Mark was our server and he did a great job taking care of us. He even recommended some drinks that had the same alcohol so that our group wasn't mixing! That's attention to detail!

A friend invited me to Searsucker for a late dinner on a Friday night. Our reservations weren't until 10PM, and the place was bustling when we arrived. We were seated within 5 minutes and led to a small table by a window. Our server and busser introduced themselves promptly and looked quite dapper, if I might add.
