The menu was filled with interesting choices, but the vegetarian selection was miniscule.   BALLERINA AND THE CZAR ($14): My friend started off with this specialty cocktail, which she said was tasty. I was content with my fancy glass of water. :) 4/5  HABANERO & CORIANDER PICKLE: This was FREE with our Yelp check-in. I hate pickles, so I didn't touch this small appetizer. My friend said they weren't that spicy, but cautioned that she has a heightened tolerance for spicy foods due to her Vietnamese upbringing. 3/5  CHEDDAR PUFFERS: Our server brought these out to us, and I assumed they were complimentary. They reminded me of the bread served at the Eiffel Tower Restaurant at the Paris Casino (except the ones at Eiffel are better!). I thought they were kind of bland. 3/5  QUINOA ($23): This was the only dinner entree option available to me as a veg head. I have difficulty describing this dish. My friend called it 'earthy' after she tasted it. I called it 'grainy'. It was a-okay. 3/5  HANGER BUTCHER STEAK ($32): She ordered the steak and loved it. Awesome presentation, too. 5/5  ERMAHGERD SUNDAE ($10): We shared this and settled on it mainly because the name sounded so hilarious. Not a fan, though. The brownies tasted stale and store bought. The 'gelato' tasted like regular ice cream. 2/5  VIBE: It was extremely loud inside the restaurant and difficult to carry on a conversation. The music was on full blast and the place was packed. I was yelling, not talking. As for the window view, at first we were happy to have the view, but that soured when guys waiting in line to get into Omnia next door began tapping on the glass window and gesturing at us through the window. :/ 2/5   SERVICE: Perfect! Our plates were cleared away quickly and we were checked on frequently. 4.5/5  Worth a Return Visit? I'm interested in trying out the Happy Hour menu but don't see myself coming back for dinner. I'm hoping it will be less rambunctious earlier on in the day.  YELP 100 CHALLENGE 2015: #176

Located in Caesars', and opened by managing partner Hakkasan to coincide with nearby Omnia, celebrity chef Brian Malarkey's fourth (actually fifth if you count the shuttered Scottsdale experiment) Searsucker bills itself as New American Classic Cuisine, and although the ebb and flow of such restaurants in major Casinos has become a virtual game of 'who's who, and who's new' an early visit seemed perfectly suited to a nearby concert, myself and three friends sitting down at the end of the open kitchen away from the hustle of a three-deep bar.  Undoubtedly courting the cool kids from the nightclub nextdoor with all sorts of clever libations and a late night menu that goes until 3am, but surprisingly pulling a wide demographic despite loud music ranging from VAST to Pearl Jam and Alice in Chains, it was with greetings from a server ported direct from the San Diego flagship that our dining began and with complimentary cheese puffs tinged in peppers whetting the palate it was not long until Chef JP Labadie stopped by to discuss the menu, a few of our desired items from the online version already culled as the kitchen ramps up to full speed.  Energetic, if not a little bit 'cramped,' with plenty of eye candy both on the walls and amongst the service staff it was with appetites gauged and questions answered that an order was formulated and requesting that items be sent out in trios so as not to overwhelm the service was nearly spotless from beginning to end, a high piece of praise in a city where such a thing is quite rare.  Starting with 'smalls' before progressing to greens, ocean, farms, 'and', and 'all milk + sugar,' it was in a trio of Malarkey's signatures that original opinions were formed and although the brie presented pasty and bland beneath the jam with a substantial delay for an extra piece of bread further marring the experience, no fault could be found in either the 'harlot' or the 'belly,' both of the expectedly rich proteins featuring great depth of flavor and textbook texture amidst accoutrements lent levity through the utilization of restrained herbs and spice.  Continuing the small plates it was once again a 'toast' that proved least impressive of round two, and although the burrata got lost amidst all the fungus and spongy bread just like the brie beneath strawberries both the Searsucker signature Shrimp and Grits as well as the Rocky Mountain Oysters were better than expected, the first for somehow finding a way to reinvent a dish done countless places as a spicy sort of cioppino while the second plated the lightly fried gonads with crispy greens and a tangy vinaigrette plus onion jam that was both smoky and sweet.  Taking a lighter approach, albeit only slightly, course three consisted of three plates focused around vegetables and although prior plates were good it was here that the first two 'stunners' arrived, the Strawberry salad a nice and refreshing share plate but the sweetbread salad and spicy pork-infused cream corn undoubtedly stealing all the thunder, the spinach beneath buttermilk and a poached egg with bacon selling itself like an gussied up Lyonnaise with the creamy bits of offal adding just enough funk to let you know they are there.  Onward to mains, savories concluded with a somewhat mixed bag, for as much as I commend the kitchen for serving the duck nearly rare I only wish the effort would have been rewarded by accoutrements that served to accent rather than overwhelm, a theme of sweetness and smoke also found in the braised Pork Butt and seared Mahi, though with far more restraint - the fish in particular perhaps the best of its kind with boozy cherries finding a deft dance partner in charred white flesh.  Unwilling and unable to forgo sweets, particularly at a place so routinely celebrated for its pastry program, it was with some restraint that I avoided requesting 'the lot,' but still investing heavily in 4/6 of the selections one would be hard pressed to name a single plate that failed to shine, even the seemingly overwrought sundae presenting a lovely blend of textures and flavors with more than enough to share while both the crostata and pumpkin cake were unassuming yet perfect, the heavy hitting S'mores bar a dish best shared, though so compelling as a result of the combination of honey, caramel, and chocolate that none will be left on the plate regardless of stomach capacity or party size.  Already functioning at a high level, and seemingly willing to take *some* chances without going 'all in,' Searsucker enters a market crowded with several similar restaurants and with longtime Las Vegas Chef Labadie at the helm an early look gives one hope that this won't just be another absentee landlord hotspot for pre-and-post-club noshing, a decision likely to be made by the powers that be in upcoming months as feedback and finances curate the cuisine.

This place was an awesome surprise. My husband and I stopped in for drinks, but the menu looked so great and the bar staff was awesome so we decided to stay for dinner. We split the happy hour sliders (ordered 2), the goat cheese salad (forgot the name), and the pasta. All were fantastic. We liked it so much that we went back later for dessert. We'll definitely be back.  Tip, eat at the bar during happy hour (4-7 PM)!

We went for dinner before a show after reading many good reviews and we're not disappointed! The food was delicious and the wait staff was incredibly kind and knowledgeable about bith the menu and pairing options. I would highly recommend this place!

Staff needs an attitude adjustment. We we greeted with a bitchy face and no warm greeting. We made it in time for happy hour, but our server took so long to get to us that we couldn't order it. One of my friends had the tacos and got FOOD POISONING because of the very questionable meat. The prices are too high for the amount of food. And service wasn't helpful when one dish needed to be sent back. None of the staff was smiling. Except Curtis the busser. He was incredibly kind and sociable. He gave our table more attention than our server.  We felt judged being younger customers since we didn't buy alcohol, but we could still afford to pay and tip well... We never got our beverages refilled.
I had the roasted chicken here. It was well seasoned. The decor is great here. The service was great.
Very disappointing as I had been there for lunch and enjoyed the food.  Even was a disaster.  Bad service, food arrived cold, waiter could care less, ETC.

It seems they spent all of their money making the restaurant look great so couldn't spend anything on making the food great. Don't get me wrong... The food wasn't bad.  It just wasn't great.  There isn't anything that I thought, "Yum" after eating. Cheddar puffers = cheesy bread.  Tasty but needed to be softer. I had the Kobe beef carpaccio for a starter.  Beef and bacon sounds amazing...  a little too salty for me.  It was still ok.   My friend had the crab cake.  It was good.  Baked crab in the shape of a circle.  Nothing amazing about it other than it's called a crab cake and not breaded and fried. I had the chicken entree.  It was cooked well and juicy.  The franks is Frank's Red Hot sauce and there was hardly any on the plate.  In fact, I was halfway through it before I found just a little line of it on my plate.  Was the chicken cooked in it?  I'm not sure, but there wasn't enough to taste it with my dish. My friends ordered the butter potato side.  It reminded me of box mashed potatoes with a pound of butter melted into it.  Great for 3rd grade; but my palate has changed quite a bit in the last 20 years.  The service was great and my drinks were good.  The ideas for the food seem exciting, but what is served is pretty boring.

I cannot say how fantastic our experience was! We went for an early dinner on a Saturday night and the service was great. We ordered a couple of items I read reviews about on Yelp and they were AMAZING!  I had the eggs and bacon and let me tell you I would drive across town just to have that again and again and again!  We also ordered the short rib. Excellent.  My husband had the Pork Butt entree based on our waitress, Tammy's, recommendation. He was not disappointed!  The table next to us ordered the bone marrow. Apparently, a waiter in the Austin restaurant started a trend of pouring a shot of bourbon through the bone to get any remaining marrow. Keep that in mind if you order the bone marrow! Sounds fantastic.  Dessert was good too. Interesting though that as stellar as the entrees and small plates were the desserts weren't quite as outstanding (and I am a dessert fiend). However, Tammy did recommend the cookies and we opted for the s'mores and sundae. Again, they were very good, just not as outstanding as the other food. Tammy said that she bakes cookies at home and the cookies there are the best she's ever had. Definitely trying the cookies next time.  FYI - the music is loud and there are no soft surroundings. Be prepared for it to be noisy.  We will definitely be returning!

Searsucker was good but I had higher expectations for it, being inside a casino on the strip. The service was good but not excellent. What upset me the most were the drinks. I got a mixed drink and the proportions didn't seem right and tasted horrible. The other guests at my table ordered different mixed drinks and had the same result to the point where none of us finished our drinks. The food was actually tasty and well-made. I enjoyed the scallops and their version of the Mac and cheese. Would come back again to give it another chance on the drinks.

Went on a Saturday night.  Service was good, not great but good.  We did the chefs recommended Apps for a table of 7, all of which were great!  Those were eaten quickly.  Entrees were pretty blah, seemed to be missing seasonings.  I would say check with place out for apps and a drink, I'd skip dinner.  They had Calvin Harris playing at the night club next to the restaurant so it was extremely loud and noisy right outside the restaurant.

went here for dinner one night and it was AMAZING! the service was great but the food was even better!!  we got the bone marrow, duck fat fries and some beer braised short ribs. it was literally like i died and went to heaven once i ate the bone marrow! it was so rich and sweet! the short ribs were so tender and melted in your mouth.. & you can never go wrong with duck fat fries ;)  would definitely recommend to anyone who is adventurous with food! i will be coming back when i'm back in Vegas.
This place was actually great we had some Habenero pickles to start off then we had blue cheese chicken skewers   Drinks were a little expensive but good

Much better than I was expecting. The beer list included some interesting options. The bartenders were fun and lively and engaging. The crab and avocado appetizer was killer... big chunks of crab and fresh avocado and nice subtle spice. I wish they included more than 4 chips, but that would be my only complaint. The short rib entree was cooked perfectly and dwarfed the short rib I had at Gordan Ramsay's a couple nights prior. The portion was very generous. This is a strong contender.

Great addition to Caesars... Do not walk in w/out a reservation during meal times.  Beef tartare and biscuits were amazing, along with the short rib and desserts.  Only negatives were the service is hard to come by if eating at the bar and can be a little slow (but attentive). Once brought to our server's attention, Charles came over to help and he was an amazing server. The only other negative were the drinks were not strong.. which is sad because they tasted great!
Perfect. Soup, appetizer, food all delicious. I am very picky person and don't give 5 Star easily. This place, ambiance,servers,kitchen all 5 stars. This is the one Of the best place for a dining.

Went there for dinner last week and boy were we not disappointed.  The Pork Belly with egg is so yummy.  The chicken lollypops are a nice twist on a chicken wing.  Very flavorful.  The albacore with prosciutto was very nice.  A different twist on Tuna.  All the cocktails are great, but my favorite was the honey badger which was made with  rye and fresh lemon + honey syrup.  MMMMMMM

A little pricey in my opinion for the food here. The servt and everything was fine, just the food was ok. The scallops I get were good, but not great   Also I hated the roasted cauliflower. Both my friend and I who ordered it barely ate ours. The seasoning was awful on it.

Not really a great place for vegetarians. I can usually find something pretty decent to eat at most restaurants. However, I was pretty disappointed with my menu options. The only entree was the quinoa dish which was basically a soggy mound of quinoa with a little bit of steamed spinach underneath, topped with a few shreds of raw carrots and some micro greens. The dish was very bland and disappointing for $23. The beet salad was pretty good. It had golden beet chunks with a creaming dressing. And there were these two little fried cheese balls that were a nice surprise! Overall, it had a Nice sweet flavor but was a very small portion. The best dish was the side of brussels spouts with walnuts. They were charred with balsamic, tangy and tender.   Service was average, and food was average as well. Nothing stood out about this experience that would warrant s repeat visit.
I always heard about the one in San Diego so I had to come in for the grand opening, let me tell you this is what vegas needed! Great food, drinks and service!

Unbelievable Old Fashions!  We stopped here before seeing Celine at Caesar's and their world famous Old Fashions are incredible.  The food was fantastic and we had a great time.  Try the PB&J Old Fashion...it's their most popular drink.
Outstanding. Tasty. Great staff and service. So good to have this in CP.
I shared a couple of plates with my friends.  The short rib with mashed potatoes was the best dish out of all the ones we ordered.  If you are eating here, you have GOT to try it!

Good service but food was AWFUL.  I called a week in advance to make a reservation for our big group (party of 25).  I was told that all big parties are required to order off their Banquet Menu.  I told the person on the phone that this was just a regular dinner (family from out of town) and she said it was ok to order off the regular dinner menu but our food would take longer to come out.  Not a problem with our group.  I called on the morning of our reservation and was told we were not on the system.  The manager, Beth, was very helpful and was able to accommodate us anyway but was once again reminded that our food will take longer to be served due to us having a big group.  When we got there, the general manager, Les, came to say Hi and was very nice.  Prior to ordering, we asked our waiter what are the other customers' favorites and his recommendations.  He told us the seared albacore tuna, shark, and Brussels sprouts for side.  So we did order those 3 items and they were HORRIBLE!  Tuna was not seared, it was OVERCOOKED!  Shark was OVERCOOKED and CHEWY like a rubber!  Brussels sprouts was SALTY!  We did expect a longer wait on our food but we did not expect it was going to be AWFUL.  And lastly, there were two COCKROACHES on the curtains that divided the private dining areas!  GROSS!  It was totally embarrassing to our out of town guests!

Food tasted good, but the menu wasnt specific as to what was included in each item. For example, my companion had a burger that had a little bit of a green spread on it. Turns out it was an avocado spread and she is allergic to avocados. The server was not very attentive as we had to track her down for the bill.

The BF went to Searsucker to celebrate our -1 monthaversary (ha) and because we had a living social deal. I must say, there were many great things about the night and other things that weren't so great. We pulled up to the restaurant, and they had valet, but it wasn't complimentary, so we decided to pull the car around to a self park area. I'm not sure why they even have a valet, especially on a weekday night when they aren't so busy. Anyway, that started the night oddly. Then, as the BF was parking, I went in to the restaurant and there was no one at the host stand. I waited for a few minutes before anyone came by. The place wasn't that busy....not awesome. Then, when the host did come he awkwardly asked me if I wanted to go to the bar while waiting for the BF instead of being seated.....so I did. The bar was nice and I got a peter rabbit drink on happy hour...it was really tasty. The BF got there almost immediately, so we sat at the bar for awhile and then asked to be seated again. For food we decided to share the chicken and waffle, the royale with cheese, and some bacon grits. Very healthy...ha. As we were waiting, we got some cheese poppers, which were ok. Not amazing, but not bad. All the food came out at the same time. The chicken and waffle was really good when it first came out, it was a little spicy and a little sweet, but really needed to be eaten right away, because it got soggy and not so good quickly. The burger was good and giant! It was like two patties with bacon between them. It came with a tomato jam, which was ok, but could have had more flavor, and also an onion jam, which was good. It also came with fries, which were ok, but not as crispy as I would like. The grits were good, but they came out cold. They were super indulgent, creamy and cheesy and bacony. If they were hot, they would be a real winner. So everything was pretty good up until this point, so we decided to get dessert. We got the chocolate terrine. It was a huge disappointment....it was bland and didn't have the espresso kick I thought it would have. The ice cream it came with was good. Anyway, it wouldn't be a place I would frequent because the flavor and experience didn't live up to the price. I would suggest going here, maybe for happy hour.

********************* 1341 *********************      Searsucker Las Vegas is located right next to OMNIA nightclub at Caesars Palace hotel. It's by the Celebrity Chef Brian Malarkey. Designed by critically-acclaimed interior designer, Thomas Schoos, Searsucker's comfortable living spaces, retro Americana vibe, New American Classic dishes and specialty cocktails set the mood for an epic night ahead. We'll plan your entire dining experience; what happens afterwards is completely up to you.      Happy hour in Las Vegas never tasted so good! Why would you stay in your room when you could have a Peter Rabbit cocktail, instead? Searsucker is bringing you the Las Vegas happy hour you always wanted. Alongside our specialty cocktails and house infusions, indulge in a few of our signature dishes at discounted prices.    Chef Brian Malarkey's playful dinner menu sets Searsucker apart from other Las Vegas strip restaurants with its imaginative twists on New American Classics. Share plate including Duck Fat Fries and Beef Tartare, or be a little selfish and try the Ribeye "Tomahawk" all to yourself.      Satisfy every taste bud with our Las Vegas late night menu. The end of your night will taste a lot better with our classic Green Eggs + Ham dish. Stop by after your Vegas adventures and take a peek at our Las Vegas late night menu in our main dining room, as well as in the bar and lounge area. Tuesday & Thursdays - Sunday from 11pm to late. A perfect spot to grab a late night bite before hitting OMNIA.

This is a must if you are going to Vegas. The delivery was flawless both in the service and the food. We started with Beef Tartare & Sourdough, Hummus & Toasted Pita, Biscuits and Calamari Steak. For three that was a ton of food. The Tartare was a huge portion and wonderful taste, the Hummus was perhaps the least exciting offering but still good. The biscuits were to die for and you have to use the infused honey, you'll want a bowl! The calamari was served in steak finger fashion rather than old boring rings and again the sauce was excellent. We then ordered a filet, short ribs and fish and chips. The fish and chips get served as part of an art deco arrangement of the whole real fish, very impressive. The short ribs were so soft you could have cut them with your napkin and the filet was cooked perfectly. I warn you every dish came out piping hot, get your drink ready. You will have an unbelievable visit!

Had the pleasure of coming here one night after Seeing NERVO play at Omnia Nightclub. I didn't even know they had late night. One of the Cocktail server assistants told me about it while we were in Omnia. It had to have been around 3:30am or so. Pretty awesome how the place stays open late when the club is going on. We hurried up and ordered the chicken & waffles as we heard they were amazing! Service staff is on point! Our server Steve was highly knowledgeable about the food and also vouched for the said Chicken & waffles. They were indeed worthy of the hype surrounding them, haha! Food was brought out quick! Matt (food runner guy) asked if we needed anything and made sure we got al we needed to devour the luscious food (I said luscious). I would highly recommend coming here again and we probably will come by during normal dinner time as well. Food was awesome as well as the service. Now you guys know where to head after going to OMNIA!!! Ha!   (Sorry no pics, I lost my phone before the night ended)

Sorry but, I will never eat there again! Not that the food was terrible, but just over priced. Service was lacking and the food was weak. Everything was spicy, which was ok for me but not my mother. She could not even get mustard for her 26$ hamburger, and there is something wrong with that.

Came here based on a mix of Yelp pictures and their menu offerings. Our Party of 9 had an 8pm reservation and was seated promptly. I was actually surprised the place was only half full and felt a little concerned I made a poor choice in restaurant especially since it was on the expensive side. However, it turned out I had nothing to worry about.  I split the Chicken Cobb salad and Mac n Cheese with a friend and both were super delicious. Especially the Mac n Cheese. And the portions were surprisingly large we couldn't finish either. Also tried their Habanero & coriander pickles which were free with Yelp check in and as strange as they sounds they were actually really good.   it wasn't happy hour but they had 2 drink specials going for the night. A cosmo and a "bay breeze" which was basically vodka and tropical juices. It was tasty and on the strong side for only $8/ I came in expecting to spend over $100 but between the drink specials and portions large enough to split I managed to come in under $60, so just know this place doesn't HAVE to break your wallet. It's also right next to Omnia so well placed for pre-turnup meal and drinks. I will definitely be returning in the future.

Interested to see that the only menu they offered was the Restaurant week offerings. Not sure if this was supposed to be the case, but OK. Appetizers were the best course. I had the calamari which were by far the best I'd ever had. Husband had the short rib which was also good but not as good as the calamari. My entree was Filet with lobster butter. When it came out the butter was still a frozen disk on top of the meat - eew! Fortunataly manager came over and corrected this problem, but stated when he came back -" we usually serve it cold on top" - what? Husband had the seared ahi tuna which had no flavor whatsoever. Desserts were also just meh.  Does no one make real chocolate mousse anymore as opposed to a blob of frosting-like chocolate covered in ganache?   Might try again with regular menu, but wouldn't go out of my way.

So, funny thing....I have recommended Searsucker San Diego to many friends, who have loved it. But I have yet to go myself! So, when a location opened in Vegas, I knew I had to check it out.  First things first - park in the Forum shops valet or self parking, both are convenient to the restaurant.   The restaurant was easy to find. If you continue past the sports book and poker room, you'll see Omnia and Searsucker is just next door to that.   Note that they are only open for dinner (currently - not sure if that will change). They do offer a decent happy hour menu Monday - Friday.  The d√©cor is very rustic and warm. When you enter, there is a large bar area with booths and seating. I was surprised at the size of the restaurant. While not small, it was smaller than I expected (in a good way). I love the open kitchen concept and that there is actually seating at the counter.  Here's what we had for food:  Duck fat fries with chipotle ketchup ($10) - REALLY good. Do yourself a favor and order these.  Shisito + ponzu ($7) - They say about 1 in every 10 is really hot, so be careful! I got a hot one and survived, but I love spicy stuff. There was tremendous flavor on the peppers and I'm glad I tried them.  Egg + Bacon "pork belly" ($19) - This was tasty as well, although the bacon was a bit too thick cut (IMO).  Cowboy Caviar ($11) - I've had Rocky Mountain Oysters before (at Coors Field) and swore to never try them again. Although, they were not properly prepared there and these were PHENOMENAL! Really, really good. You would have a hard time believing that this wasn't a fancy chicken nugget.  Shrimp "spicy" + Bacon grits ($17) - Delicious! I am not a huge fan of grits, but these were well made. The spicy shrimp was really delicious and basically the star of the dish though.  Beet salad ($16) - I've had an obsession with beets lately. This was really good and I especially enjoyed the fried goat cheese.  I would say that it's best to get a bunch of plates and share. The main entrees are on the high end, pricing wise. We were all happy with the smaller plates.  We also had a couple of signature cocktails, which were good. The beer list was decent, but nothing spectacular, which is a bit disappointing for a restaurant based in San Diego.  They will be offering a late night menu, on the nights that Omnia is open. I would expect this place to be a total shit show on those nights! The staff were all super friendly and knowledgeable, and Chef Malarkey was quite nice as well. I look forward to going back soon for a visit and trying some of the things we didn't get to try this time!

One of the best meals I have had in Las Vegas.  Specialty drinks were tasty and not bad price for the Strip.  Crab Cakes are the absolute best I have ever had and a must try!   We also had the steak tartare & pork butt both very good. The Chefs use of sauces and flavor combinations are wonderful!  Our waiter Chris was great as well as the rest of the wait staff that assisted. a very nice atmosphere.

Fabulous!  I recommend ordering tapas style to try many dishes.  We all got to try so much more this way. Loved the braised short rib, ceviche, mac n cheese. All incredible.  Didn't save room for hot chocolate chip cookies and milk, but ordered them anyway. No regrets! Service was excellent, but rarely saw anyone smile. That was the only thing missing.  I highly recommend this restaurant and can't wait to go back again.

I was excited to try one of the newest restaurants in Las Vegas and it did not disappoint! Great atmosphere, amazing menu selection, spectacular food! This restaurant is a MUST TRY! And request Lindsey...she, by far, was the best server I've ever had...very knowledgeable about the menu, attentive to our needs, and pushed this great dining experience over the top!!!

Seersucker is a great place to find an interesting and yet accessible meal on the strip and in Caesars palace. This place has some awesome staff and a great bar team that takes care of the patrons across the restaurant. They have some cool and tasty signature and craft cocktails that are certainly worth a try (or two, or three!) The food is well prepared and very well presented - they put their time into the dishes and make sure that it's done to your liking. The pricing is a bit high, but for an on-the-strip option is a great choice and well worth return visits. Happy hour is great and you can get some nice deals too - so keep an eye out! All in all this is a win win for me!
I love the ambiance and the cocktails. Chef Malarkey & Hakkasan Group have really done a great job  taking a see and be seen San Diego "locals restaurant" and turning it into a viable global brand.

We were sat promptly and the hostess was very nice.  Then we waited and waited.  Finally a server showed up.  He was very nice.  We ordered drink and they were good.  We then ordered appetizers and they were expensive and TINY.  I know that appetizers can be small, but they were smaller than I have ever seen.  The server was not attentive, never checked in on us.  We constantly had to ask the bus boy to get him.  The sliders were 2 tiny burgers and were tasty,  the ahi tacos were the size of those deep friend mini tacos from the frozen section at the store.  They were just ok.  The Ceviche was good also.  The guy who filled the water glasses was fantastic.  We drank a lot of water since we had to wait so long for drinks.

I have had dinner and drinks here with my husband a few times and loved it so much that I decided to host an event there recently.  The staff went above and beyond to make sure the party was a success and the food was unbelievable!  We had a brunch and it was to die for, especially the chef's special maple bacon!!!  I highly recommend this venue for anything from cocktails with the girls to a large event!
Great food, small portions, bad service.

Top notch food  Relaxed but upscale atmosphere Friendly, knowledgeable waitstaff  Jenn took me to Searsucker for my most recent Birthday dinner. We enjoyed sharing several offerings starting with the Blackened Ahi Tacos- small but packed with flavor. Next was the Calamari Steak with Chili Honey Glaze and Apples- strongly recommended by our server-- thank goodness. This is NOT typical fried Calamari O's you could get at any ordinary chain place. No no no!! Think more of the difference in canned tuna and real fresh Ahi= yes now you get it! The Calamari Steak will change your life-- or at least your expectations of seafood for bit. Lastly we shared The Braised Pork Butt Entree- a tower of flavor power! So melt in your mouth type tender. Whiskey Apples, Brussels Sprouts and Prosciutto round out the experience.  Also worth mention is the wide variety of hand crafted cocktails- especially the Jaleberry Strawpeno-- tequila with fruit and heat.

Ok, here is my update for a recent visit. They have changed chefs from our Meet up, and have also adjusted the menu, taking away my favorite Pork Belly Benedict which I send people here to try. Also gone, my Ballerina and the Czar cocktail. This makes me sad. :(  I had the eggs and bacon, and also the grilled cheese and tomato basil soup. The eggs and bacon was disappointing, the pork belly here was so dry and crunchy that it was almost inedible. The grilled cheese and tomato basil was pretty good.   This is one of my pet peeves with restaurants, and that's taking good items off the menu. I'm sure there are numbers that say this wasn't selling or whatever. Looking over this menu, I really didn't see much that I enjoyed from our Yelp event left. I was definitely disappointed with the selections.   Alas, I won't be back nor recommending it again. I'm sure people will still enjoy what they have to offer, and they have a great location. Time to find a new Strip restaurant to enjoy and take guests from out of town to.

I was invited by Brain Malarkey for his hospitality event, I had such a great time! The food the drinks the atmosphere was just great, he was very involved and answered all our questions, I had a little sample of the small eats such as duck fat fries and chipotle ketchup , shishito peppers, cheese and meats, eggs and pork belly and shrimp and grits... All was very flavorful and my favorite was the cowboy caviar!!! Aka BULLS BALLS lol... Best tasting balls ever! Also I had the Chardonnay it was very smooth... I had the Peter rabbit and jalaberry strawpeno!!!! I'm definitely going back for my 1 year wedding anniversary and my 30th birthday!!!
Very nice restaurant and great decor inside. Hanger steak was awesome and the whipped potatoes were delicious. Biscuits I could take a whole batch home if you like sweet honey biscuits.

You need to try this place and if you have go back!!  The staff was great. Eric was our waiter and was spot on. Had the opportunity to meet nick, asst GM, was a pleasure. Really s class operation. The food was great. Crab cake is straight crab meat.  The calamari steak with apple I wanted all to myself. We had other dishes and I enjoyed a Peter rabbit drink.  Best part of the night, milk and cookies. Can't wait to bring more clients and friends back. My go to for Caesars!!

This place is fantastic! The service is great and the food is outstanding! The cheese puffers they bring in the beginning are delectable and a perfect introduction to the food. I had the tuna and it was cooked perfectly, the grapes provided the perfect balance of acidity.  My friend had one of the steaks and I tried a little, it was amazing, totally melt in your mouth delicious.  For sides we had the corn, mashed potatoes, and brussel sprouts.  This was my first time having brussel sprouts and I have no idea why people don't like them...they were absolutely divine, and I want to try them everywhere now.  The corn was perfect and a little spicy.  The mashed potatoes were really creamy and delicious.  For dessert we had the donuts and chocolate which was a perfect ending to our meal, little bite size pieces of heaven dipped in chocolate.  The drinks were also very good, I had the cocktail on draft which was a rum based drink...it came to the table on fire, which is awesome.  I recommend getting this when it's darker to get the full effect.  It wasn't dark when I got it, so the flame was hard to see.  Mostly, I can't wait to go back and try more dishes!

We selected this restaurant for our party of 6 based on the reviews and food selection. We wanted something a little different, and the selections and review pictures looked quite interesting. It was an early dinner by Vegas standard, around 7pm. Hostess was wonderfully friendly and promptly seated us.   The dinner started with an introduction from our server, Cesar.  He was really great from beginning to end.  We really enjoyed his friendliness and appreciated his attentive service. We wanted to have some fun during dinner, and Cesar played right along!  The entire service was great, perfectly timed and we were well attended the entire time.   We chose a few share plates; Tomato and Burata (super delish), short ribs (succulent and tasty), and the duck fat fries (nicely seasoned and presented).  For our main courses most had the hanger steak.  It was perfectly cooked and tasted great. One word of caution: You better love garlic, like I do!  One person in our party had the burger, which she said was "amazing", and another had the Salmon (perfectly cooked).  As if that wasn't enough, we finished off with the awesomely decadent ice cream sandwich. Man, the flavors there were unbelievable.   All in all, we each enjoyed the food and Cesar's excellent service.  We'd all recommend the place for a slightly different take on American classics.

I was highly disappointed during my visit.  I would somewhat consider myself a "foodie" and will spend some cash on a GOOD MEAL.  Searsucker was anything but.   In hindsight, I wish I had walked across the street to City Hall Steakhouse.  I could have had a delicious meal for the same price.  My friend's order of duck came out cold and after she sent it back, it returned cold again.  The waiter didn't check to make sure it was better, we had to flag him down to acknowledge us.  Another fellow diner ordered the shark which the server raved about.  Plain and simple, it wasn't good and the portion size was terribly small for a $38 plate.  I had the Mahi Mahi.  It stated it had a horseradish crust however, I found it to be lacking flavor and was quite dry.  A side of potatoes was ordered and they weren't cooked.  The best part of the dinner was the end when the table next to us looked over and said "looks like your food was as bad as ours."  They too, were not impressed.  I really wanted to like Searsucker but it was not worth our $260 tab.  I do think the restaurant has potential but it would take me some serious convincing to return.

This was our second visit to Searsuckers and each time the good was excellent.   The fish and chips are some of the best we've ever had. The mac and cheese is superbly made and the lollipop buffalo chicken wings are finger licking good. We ordered multiple items, all were very good.   Dessert is great too, we ordered the rocky road bread pudding and the chocolate chip cookies.

The appetizers were delicious. I had the buffalo wings and calamari, not disappointed. My meal was the skirt steak. It was a little salty, but the chimichurri was good. I would definitely recommend this place for its bar environment. It was a very social scene and the people were friendly.

I tried Searsucker with a group for a friend's birthday.... This was a great experience cause we got to try a variety of items! For my cocktail I chose the Jalaberry Strawpeno - which is a strawberry jalapeno tequila + lime + agave. This was a great mix of spicy and sweet! For appetizers we shared the cheddar puffers, mussels + chorizo + beer, brie "triple" + cranberry jam, "cowboy caviar" and the shrimp "spicy" + bacon grits.  I have to say that my favorites were the mussels and the shrimp with the grits! YUMM! For my entr√©e I chose the scallops "east coast" israeli couscous + almonds + citrus vinaigrette- this was fabulous! We then shared a variety of desserts- I have to say my favorite was the warm cookies with milk.  I absolutely enjoyed the entire experience at Searsucker! Will definitely be back!

I've been putting off writing this review since I was such a big fan of the restaurant in Scottsdale (which is now closed) but unfortunately my experience at the Vegas location was not a good one. A big issue was the staff; everyone from the hostess to the bussers seemed to not want to be there. Our server was very short with us while ordering and never really came back after that. Another dude brought us our food and he wasn't very friendly either. I burnt my hand pretty badly (it bubbled into a blister the next day) on one of the metal dishes they serve the food (straight from the oven?!?!) in and it took us forever to find someone to give us some ice since our water glasses were never even refilled.  The food was a disappointment as well. The menu was probably half the size of the AZ location so there wasn't much variety. Since it was late we decided on a few small plates to share. We got the corn (cooked well but very bland), the Mac and Cheese (really awful... the sauce was white and curdled) and also the small fried blobs they tried to pass off as tacos.  The decor in the place was nice but it was loud since it is open to the casino and also very dark for some unknown reason. Just not a pleasant experience. There are other better and cheaper places to go in Caesars so I will not be back.

Review is for happy hour at the bar.  I can't believe this is my first time back here since the YEE two years ago! We were seeing a show at the Colosseum and came a little early for some appetizers and drinks. It was surprisingly not busy for a Sunday night so we grabbed a seat at one of the hightops in the bar area. Our server Emily was right over to go over the HH menu and take our drink order.   HH at Searsucker has some great deals. All food is $9 and drinks are $4-8 depending on if you order beer, wine or cocktails. I had the house chardonnay for $6 and it wasn't bad. We ordered the duck fat fries, lollipop wings, sliders and ahi tacos.   The food starting arriving very quickly. The ahi tacos (3) came out first and they were fantastic. The ahi was super fresh and served in a wonton shell with limes and guac on the side. Next out was the lollipop wings. 9 wings covered in buffalo sauce served with blue cheese, carrots and celery. Another excellent dish. The fries and sliders arrived last. The fries were hot, fresh and crispy. Dusted with prosciutto and parmesan they were a perfect match for the sliders.   Although the sliders were our least favorite of the four apps, they were still good. Slightly over cooked and quite small but the flavors were good. Debating on getting another order of the ahi tacos the dessert menu was brought out. As soon as I saw the rocky road bread pudding I knew I couldn't pass it up!   The bread pudding was delivered with the marshmallows still on fire, melting on top of the chocolate bread pudding. With a side of fresh whipped cream and chocolate gelato this was an outstanding dessert that we quickly polished off. The food and service here is as good as when it opened two years ago and Im glad we came back.

I wasn't impressed. I've been to the Searsucker in San Diego.  First of all, I expect good service.  After being seated, no one came to our table for literally 15+ minutes. I had to flag someone down, and although she wasn't out waiter, she apologized and gladly took our drink order.  Wish she had remained our waitress. Peter Rabbit cocktail was tasty.  Got a bunch of small plates: eggs +bacon, chicken &waffles, and shrimp + grits, and side of brussel sprouts.  The plates were interesting in concept, were good, but nothing great.  Brussel sprouts were the most flavorful thing we got.  Atmosphere is kind of weird in the bottom of an office building and they charge $5 for parking.  Between the service and food, I won't be rushing back.

Wanted a small bite so split the lollipop wings and tomato soup with grilled cheese. The wings were okay but the tomato soup was stellar, lots of flavor and that grilled cheese was the best I have EVER had. Service was great and food came out fast. I love the interior decor and all the different light fixtures especially the chandelier in the black cage. Really cool place! You won't be disappointed.

Lots of good small plates here - the goat cheese toast and calamari were great.  Wait staff was helpful and allowed us to order bit by bit so we could try several things without over ordering as small plates can sometimes be tough to judge. Tried the p, b & j old fashion, pretty good!  Mule was the hit drink of the night.  We will be back!

Loud. Couldn't hear the people we were with. Food. Meh. Service was strange. In a hurry to give us our check when we were ordering everything on the menu!!! We weren't campers! We were spending lots of money! We all agreed we would never be going back to Searsucker. Also, our friend Jim is no longer allowed to pick restaurants.

Nice stop for a pre-show bite! I thought it was located in the forum shops but it's in the casino. Service was friendly though a little slow - but it was pretty packed, probably due to the concert. They have a great happy hour - my husband got dogfish head on tap and I ordered the blueberry smash cocktail. We were running low on time so we ordered the lollipop chicken wings and tomatoe burrata. Both were tasty and a deal for the price! Next time we're gonna try the fries - we would definitely return to try their full menu.

Dinner on a Friday evening just a few days after they opened and Searsucker already had a decent amount of people seated, enjoying their food.  We were seated in an awkward table in a walkway on the way to the restroom so my chair got kicked and bumped on a number of occasions. If I were to return I would ask for a more secluded table.  I had the pleasure of enjoying a meal with several dining companions which gave us a chance to order and sample a number of items from the menu.  For a new restaurant service already seemed on point, but that may just have been our good fortune to get the only server in the restaurant that came over from the Searsucker location in San Diego. He was knowledgable, friendly and very attentive.   Our plates came out in a well-balanced manner. Never inundating us with too much food so we were able to sample at a leisurely pace.  My favorites from the evening were the mahi, pork butt, egg and pork belly and surprisingly the strawberry salad. Each of these dishes were well-cooked and the flavors were on point.   The rest of the food was good, but didn't leave a lasting impression with me. I love brussel sprouts but these weren't as crispy as I like and seemed drowned in garlic, not really allowing me to enjoy the flavor of the vegetable. I was in the minority in my opinion of this dish, so it might just be a personal preference.   Of the desserts we sampled, the smores dish came out as a table favorite. Even I, who am neither a huge fan of chocolate or smores, enjoyed it, though I couldn't take more than a bite since it was rich. This dish is best shared. The rest of the desserts didn't really do as much for me, but they were decent. Again, I was in the minority on this opinion, so it may be due to my lack of sweet tooth.   Searsucker is already ahead of the game after opening so recently. Good service, excellent location and decent food to boot. With their eclectic menu and late night availability I see them being successful in catering to the pre-show and after clubbing crowd quite well.

This restaurant owned/created by celebrity chef Brian Malarkey is just awesome!  I have been there twice on lunch at both time where great with good service and nice tatsting food for an affordable price   *Pulled pork sandwich is served with an amazing apple slaw and baconaise.  Really juicy and supertasty. Price around 11 $ (its a lot of food!)   *Mahi mahi sandwich with bacon and avocaod.  Almost as good as the pulled pork this little sandwich of goodness had flavorful blackened mahi mahi that went good with the salty bacon, again the famous baconaise and the creamy avocado.   My inside tip is to order the Cheddar Puffers (2 $). This was 5 fluffy and cheasy delicious small breadpuffers that was oooh so good! Order them now, thank me later! = )

Shared the loin filet, salmon, shark, duck, duck fat fries and squid. Everything was very tasty with great flavor. The duck fat fries and squid appetizers were a great start, the duck and filet were outstanding as entrees. Great presentation of dishes.  Service was unbelievable slow considering it was on a Wednesday night with not many people dining.  The biggest question is the extremely high prices of the entire meal.  The portions are small and the prices are through the roof.  For overall food quality, I would give this place 5 stars, price would be 2 stars and service would be 2 stars

Probably my 10th time eating dining here......Service can be on the slower side, but the food is always consistent.  The tomato soup and grilled cheese is my absolute favorite and now they are doing it table side. It's a big enough meal to not need anything else!! Tonight we tried their newest "melon tomato shrimp" salad. Amazing! Yellow watermelon, yellow and red heirloom tomatoes (a little skimpy on the shrimp-only 3 and for 24$), but a total must try!  They also offer an expedited Omnia nightclub entry when you spend 50$ on dinner which is pretty enticing if your looking to head there.
